Title: "Constant Transformation"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
(FROM A GBS PERSPECTIVE)
Respectful, inclusive culture for entry, low, and middle
The legacy that IBM'ers feel a sense of purpose is alive though weakening
Choose your own adventure-- many options for internal movement if you go for it
Broad perspective to business and technology
New leadership may represent a fresh change that will unleash pent up potential and capability
Cons:
Culture: legacy direct and open culture has become aggressive and punitive.  This was once a competitive advantage for IBM.  It can be again.  
Consistency: constant change has not been directed by a single strategy or perspective-- as a result, many approaches and tribes have been brought in each with the expectation they will save the company, or consulting.
Finance and legal are too empowered, limiting smart risk and protecting leaders who just barely succeed with incremental results.

Title: "Welcoming, tolerant, professional culture with big company red tape and politics"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
Welcoming, tolerant, inclusive, all genuinely so. No bullying, shouting, sour grapes etc. Those attributes at IBM are not manufactured or beat into your head all day like they are at places like Google, rather, it is just how it is. Very professional. At the same time, casual dress, flexible work hours depending on manager.

Complex, relevant technologies. Opportunity for promotions and growth for those who take initiative, ask questions, push for progress, take a stand.

Upcoming CEO Arvind is a huge step above Ginni. Things are looking up for IBM from the inside. Positive things are happening.
Cons: Boring culture, global teams can leave people feeling isolated, big company politics in executive management, executive management is fair to poor. Yearly cash bonuses are pathetic, no stock comp.

WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Flexibility and very challenging work assignments in CIO organization.  Company has improved in many areas in the last few years making it more inviting to "junior" level workers.
Cons: Bitterness from IBMers that have been through the difficult times and worked under poor leadership are at the surface.  Conflicting internal processes and lack of willingness to accept certain facts as roadblocks makes certain roles extremely frustrating when attempting to enable processes through IT delivery.  Company will have skilled employees train and coach less skilled employees and then lay them off, using their complex band and role matrix to avoid the appearance of certain lay off practices.

Title: "A fallen giant"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The name is instantly recognizable and still holds some good will.  The company itself can probably coast for ages on their patents and long term contracts.  I really learned a lot from 2005 to 2011-ish.
Cons:
I was told once that the mission statement from the CEO was to double the stock price every 5 years.  I don't know if that's true, but it does feel that way.  The mission isn't about happy customers, or great technology or bringing out the best in the employees.  It's about spending as little as possible even if it means laying off everyone over 40 and replacing them with fresh graduates.  

IBM are famous for their 'resource actions' or massive layoffs.  Severance packages used to include one week pay for each year of company service.  They cut that down to a max of 30 days no matter what.  I guess that makes it cheaper to lay off folks with decades of dedication.  

Maybe they'll recover some spirit with new management, but if I were looking for a job, I'd wait a few years and see.

Title: "Great place to work"

Cons: IBM can sometimes be overwhelming. There are many business units and moving parts that it can be hard to keep up! This business is a very complex machine that takes time to fully understand.

Title: "You get what you put into it"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: I personally enjoy who I work with and how understanding my co-workers and managers are.  For example when I give input or suggestions in team meetings I feel that what I say is valued and taken to heart.
Cons: I feel that the apprenticeship program has still has quite a bit of a ways to go. However, I am thankful I was chosen to be part of it. With that said, I think IBM needs to think about having more training "hands-on" and less video watching. Rather, try to have apprentices shadow people more often and see the role they are training to do. Videos can only help so much before the brain turns to mush. Changing things up helps the mind stay active.

Title: "Poor management, no respect for employees time or goals"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: The biggest pro of a entry level financial analyst at IBM is simply being able to put the IBM Name on your resume. Other than that I did not find many benefits to working in this finance center.
Cons:
Poor management: The managers in the finance center have little to no training, they are simply Financial Analysts that have been with the company too long and want to get promoted. They have no experience or skill in managing employees. 

Time on the "Bench": You have little to no control over your career in the first 2-3 years at IBM your manager will have full control over any horizontal/vertical movements you desire to make as there is no internal job application platform. Some employees will be put on the bench after being hired, meaning you will have no job to do, in my case I was told to watch Netflix on my first day. 

Poor work culture: Older employees are constantly afraid of getting laid off, entry level employees will work very hard and not see any recognition, some employees will sleep at their desk and nothing will be done.

Title: "IBM was great, now they aren’t"

Title: "Exactly what you'd expect"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: The amount of people that you will meet and interact with (especially working from home) is phenomenal because there are over 400k of them around the world. If you're young enough, this can be a crash course-- almost a business degree and the inner workings of a very large company, from the terminology, the bureaucracy, and networking in general.
Cons:
1) It's an old company and quite a few people are still holding out for retirement, so it’s not the “freshest” mentality. 
2) Lay-offs are extremely common, products are pushed out or sold before they're even built, and my personal biggest issue was that female managers trying too hard to be in the "boy's club" that is IBM. This results in a lot of unnecessary competition and jealousy between females over ridiculous stuff, but it’s really only a problem when that female is your manager. In other words, there isn't a lot of support amongst the females because there are so few and the glass ceiling seems to be on the first floor at IBM. I normally wouldn't even notice such a thing because I’m not a raging feminist, but it was cut-throat there. One or two instances, okay, maybe it's me, but it was rampant. Consequently, by the time I left, I worked for one of the best bosses I've ever had (a man) and was happy to leave on a good note. 
3) There's also a lot of nepotism because a lot of the younger people that do come to work there are almost always the offspring of someone who's worked there for most of their life. The higher up the parent, the better the gig or building address/location (NYC/Austin) for their kid. 
4) If you want to move to another position in the company, there are usually plenty, but you have to network. I held several positions in my four years there, mostly due to layoffs or complete dissolution of my department due to the whim of some organizational consultant, but I rarely landed another position from someone I hadn't networked or dealt with before. They like to do "informational interviews", which is just another way of finding out if they like you or not before they go through any of the enormous red-tape to do an official interview or bring you into their department. There’s absolutely nothing wrong with that, but I can imagine there are some people who aren’t really good at networking, but are phenomenal at their job, who don’t get to move up, or on, because the ONE person on the other end of the phone has written you off before you’ve even applied.
5) Used to be able to work from home, but they started changing it when I left in 2016 to making people go into unprepared and ill-equipped open-office spaces. Working from home made people more comfortable, which reflected in their work attitudes.
6) Last, but not least, were the times (too many to count) where I was instructed to work on something that was of utmost importance and urgency, only to be told hours or days later that they had completely scrapped the idea and moved on. It was hard to ever feel accomplished when what you toiled and slaved over for days was thrown out the window. I literally would stay up all night working on something my boss had told me was an emergency only to be told in the morning she’d changed her mind. Calls from Caribbean islands during a cruise were not unusual, either, as she HAD to have my password to get into a system immediately. How is that even okay?!

Title: "Just Fine."

Title: "Young grads — stay away. Join if you are lazy and complacent or a Boomer/Gen X. This is a complete sinking ship."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Work life balance is the only benefit that IBM will provide you. Work from home 1-2 times and work for less than 30 hrs per week all year round. Maternal/paternal leave is supposedly good. This should be a major perk for people who are 35+ and plan to sit back and watch the company steadily sink to demise in the next two decades until they retire.
Cons:
1. Lack of talent and work ethic. Every time you try to do things a different way, people will either yell at you that “that’s not how IBM has done things” or question why you’re adding their workload when they will be paid anyways every two weeks. Pure laziness, complacency, and dumb hierarchy. Countless people start their sentences with “I’ve been at IBM for X amount of years.” 

2. Inappropriate Boomer jokes that include unjust comments regarding gender, race, and sexual orientation are made both during and outside meetings.  Even 33 year old men from Connecticut behave like they are in their 50’s living in Wisconsin. Lack of respect for themselves and others. 

3. You will be paid below the market.

Title: "Good company to work for if you are successfulat at your job and like it."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Reputable company, looks good on the resume, and treats it's employees well.
Cons: Work life balance is tough. It is really difficult getting another position if you don't like or are good at the current one. 401K is applied one time annually if you make it that long. Annual reviews are weird and can result in a performance improvement plan possibly resulting in termination. The reviews can make it impossible to move, and comparisons are necessarily restricted to others in same pay grade. If you don't like what you are doing they will bring it up, you'll get bad reviews, and because of those bad reviews you won't be moved to a better fitting position. I was forced out based on reviews against peers at higher pay grades because I didn't like the work but because of my reviews I couldn't get moved. Also when I was forced out was really close to the 401k distribution date rather than just after the review.

Title: "Red Hat acquisition will not save IBM"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Global projects provide incredible insight into company or client business processes
The employees hired by IBM are driven and motivated to deliver excellent results
The IBM brand opens many doors
Cons:
Employees are valued less than any other company I have worked for.  I have worked for 5 companies in my 30 year career.  All the companies were Fortune 500.
Morale is very low.  My comment in the pros section is when an employee starts.  After the first project the employee basically understands that IBM would trade them for a dog if the dog could write code or architect a solution.
Watson is a myth.  It is not ready for prime time and IBM is marketing cognitive like there are not limits.  I'm sure someday IBM will market 'cognitive' toilet paper.

Title: "Poor Senior Management Which Lacks Both Technical/Business Direction and Concern for People"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: Until recently, lots of freedom to investigate a variety of worthy research topics. Great colleagues, lots of smart people. Lots of flexibility, able to work from home.  Many opportunities to publish. I loved my work and colleagues.
Cons: Can you say red tape? Ridiculous overhead involved in the most basic of business operations. Basic operations are outsourced, and this complicates things even further. Lawyers who do not understand technology have too much freedom to restrict everything from travel to research direction, to publication, and place unreasonable restrictions on all of those things and more. Senior management isn't doing its job, and hasn't provided coherent direction. They  allowed the sales force to sell what couldn't be delivered.  How many times in my career have I seen the same mistake? Hint: it's a good idea to consult with technical staff BEFORE pursuing the sale and signing the contract. Good technical people worth their salt will tell you what the risks are and what can be done to mitigate these risks.  How do you enforce that? Easy. Sales staff should be rewarded on successful completion of contract, not just the close of the sale. That should mitigate some of the arrogance on the part of those in sales and contracts. Public business articles show many failures to deliver on contracts, contributing to poor reputation. A poor reputation contributes to fewer contracts in the future, and lower revenue.  With respect to the direction of the company, senior management is lost and scrambling. There are lots of nice speeches, with all the best buzzwords.  But sorry, the substance is not in the plan, and it's painfully clear that the senior management doesn't really know what all of those buzzwords mean, and doesn't know how to execute on them.  Redirection takes more than articulating a handful of areas of emphasis. The boat is sinking. Time to get a new C suite for this company. Finally, and most concerning, is the way that the company treats its greatest asset, its people. This company has a history of cutting an entire project, and firing everyone associated with a project, without examining the individuals they are firing. Senior management will make these decisions without consulting the line managers who know the staff.  ADVICE TO THOSE SEEKING POSTDOCS: insist upon severance pay if they terminate your contract prior to the term on your contract. Have it written into the contract before you sign. Insist on this. Make it enough to either sustain you through a search for a new job, and/or to break your lease. You will need it when IBM decides to downsize.  Why? They consider postdocs to be a way of maintaining an "elastic workforce."  The default contract is written so that they can show you the door with no notice (the typical 2-3 year "duration" in this "contract" is legally meaningless), and this can happen even if you are a star performer. They will cut your position before they cut a permanent staff position. You are vulnerable. Do you think it won't happen to you? It happened to me. And I was not a slacker. In 1.5 years, I was an author in 5 publications, wrote the technical content for a grant, delivered technical content for a contract, gave many public presentations, contributed to many existing projects, launched my own projects, and had external partnerships.  Senior management did not consult my manager in the decision. I had to break a lease and move, and this alone cost about $10,000, not to mention the lost income of 1 year of potential earnings, and the time between jobs. That's not chump change. Management didn't care about me, and they won't care about you, either. Someone at C-suite level issued an order to downsize my department, and that was it. Then, management tried to hide when I tried to address things with them directly. If you are a postdoc just starting out, with no financial buffer, this could put you into debt very fast. Don't sign that default contract. Negotiate it to protect yourselves, or seek employment elsewhere. Got it? Spread the word, and protect yourselves. Universities, educate your graduates, and protect them from this please.

Title: "Great people, good flexibility, highly bureaucratic"

Pros: People, flexibility, work/life balance is pretty good in Austin (might be different in other markets), culture in Austin is really good, lots of opportunities to move around the company if you want to, salaries are pretty competitive, incredible paid family leave policies and good benefits and 401K match
Cons: Heavily matrixed, highly bureaucratic and political. The "escalation" culture is a problem in many parts of the business leading to poor decision making and sub-par work because someone more senior demanded.  It is very challenging to get into senior leadership unless you're willing to participate in the politics. Success often means taking on 2-3 different jobs at a time. Bonuses are non-existent inside of marketing.

Title: "One Company. Many Career Opportunities!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- Endless career paths you can pursue within one company (imagine not having to enroll in new benefits again!). 
- Everyone has personal accountability and are trusted to get work done (read: no micromanagement). 
- Work/Life balance is practiced, not just preached (I'm WFH as I write this review).
- I'm encouraged to bring my whole self to work each and every day.
Cons:
- Company is so large and complex it's hard to get your arms around it.
- Office environment is a little lacking (/uninspiring) if you're not at a strategic location (Binney Street > Rogers Street in Cambridge, MA)
- Benefits are not competitive with others in this space (bonuses are unreliable, if non-existent; no RSUs, etc.).

(1) IBM has some great training programs and developmental opportunities.  
(2) Your Team will be experienced, professional and dedicated to customer success
(3) Depth of resources...  You can reach out to >400,000 people in IBM and most will be willing to help you out
(4) Good compensation and benefits
Cons:
(1) Leadership has struggled with "Strategic Initiatives" and what it wants to be in the next transformation.   Every part of the  business needs to look over their shoulder - where might the axe fall next?
(2) Weak Manager Skills - I've been in many organizations and by far managers in IBM are not trained or prepared for the roles.   They need improvement in managing their piece of the business and they need improvement on people management skills.  
(3) While they are good at acquiring software solutions - everyone of them seems to have withered on the vine and never achieved greater success than what was initially procured.   Will Red Hat be different?

Title: "Excellent focus on diversity and investing in employees early in their careers"

Title: "They just don't care anymore...."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Huge company, so a ton of positions and various jobs/responsibilities
Lots of training material, but it's all Web-based (they cut actual classroom, onsite education years ago.)
Lot's of good, smart people to work around and learn from.
Name still carries some clout, but not like it did in the past.
Cons:
They no longer care about their most valuable assets - people.
Leadership only concerned with stock price.
When I was laid off (2016), I had 20 yrs with them and got ONE MONTH severance.
They are shooting for 75% support staff to come from overseas.
Slow to move and keep up with more agile competitors.
Benefits keep getting cut and are worse now than 5 or 10 yrs ago.

Title: "Great If You Can Get In, But No Job Security"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: As with anyplace, it is the team you end up on that determines the real work environment. Every single individual I worked with was supportive and lovely The benefits are good. Health insurance is not so good unless you get promoted enough to afford the more exoensive offerings.
Cons: There is little to no job security, you are pretty much a disposable cog in a giant machine and your redundancy is inevitable. In such a rapidly changing industry, IBM sheds the employees of the companies they merge with every year, as soon as whatever agreement to keep the staff employed for expires. They view people as the most expendable and renewable resource and will throw yu away as soon as your sector starts to hint an losing profit.

Title: "Depends on how lucky you yet. Minimal managerial support."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
There are some very cool projects that are actually useful to the government - FDA records classification, simplifying searching through HHS database. As IBM is really banking on AI to pull itself into the future, you will be exposed lots of AI techologies like NLP, computer vision, some element of creating models for classification and prediction.

The DC office is on F and 14th so very conveniently located one block from metro center.
Cons:
The mentorship opportunities are little to none. Everyone who has the technical competence to be a mentor is overworked and overstressed, and you can only really get them to spend time with you if you happen to be on the same project. I have been on several projects where I, with less than one year of experience, have been the lead on a project simply because everyone else is too expensive or unavailable.

While you are exposed to these AI technologies, it is unlikely you actually get to work with them hands on. Most AI in our projects depends on Watson APIs (whose accuracy is definitely not cutting edge), so you're mostly making API calls rather than building a model yourself, so there's little opportunity to gain experience or understanding.

A lot of the projects they deliver to the client also often have pretty low usability because we are severely lacking in front end engineers and rarely talk to the Design team because they're too expensive.

Title: "The trouble was not worth the resume entry"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Generic benefits of working for any big company. Name recognition, lots of training materials of varying quality, large network of people who may or may not be willing to help you at all
Cons:
I’ll address the most probable rebuttal first: Client Innovation Centers are not a complete representation of IBM, but any company that creates and enables a facet of their organization with this many issues should seriously reevaluate.

They do not pay enough for the work you do. This is not just a subjective claim, simple research on the job title at other companies tells you you’re getting underpaid. 

You do not get the experience/flexibility in experience they claim you get. If you stay with the company for 20 years you may be able to get the exposure you want. But the first 5 o so years, you have virtually no control over what you learn. You can be as motivated and outspoken as you want, but they will put you wherever there is a need.

Management is patronizing and disrespectful of our reasonable complaints of being underpaid and (contractually) overworked. 

The job I accepted listed 50% travel, but the CIC is at the whims of their big clients, so you will probably travel 100% (every Monday - Thursday or Friday). Somehow though, the fault comes back to you as the little pawn of an employee for not reminding everyone higher than you of your travel limits. 

During Christmas time of 2018, we were asked to forfeit our “use it or lose it” vacation time because “IBM is not doing well in Q4 because of consultant vacation time.” This is the epitome of disrespecting work life balance. Do I think the CEO would have agreed with this, had she been there? Probably not. Does that matter? No. How did a game of bureaucratic, corporate telephone result in multiple managers in multiple different meetings asking employees to not take vacation during the holidays to see their families? Horrible tone at the top.

I got the privilege of working with people I trusted, and knowledgeable seniors. The procedures overall were pretty well defined meaning there was a solid structure to lean back on. The system is proprietary so took some learning, but it was pretty easy to pick up and learn.
Cons: The environment can really stress you out, and they hire people fresh into IT because the automation's so easy to learn. Your co-workers are going to be hit or miss as a result. When I was there they were transitioning from Softlayer management to IBM management which put the managers on edge.

Title: "Terrible opportunity if you care about being valued/appreciated/not being lied to (IBM Baton Rouge CIC)"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Good resume filler (that’s it)
Cons:
Management so disconnected from the actual work, truly unbelievable. All they care about is hiring enough people. Placing people in rolls they are prepared for? Nope. Paying people what they are worth? Nope. Overall interest in the employees and their lives outside of work? Nope.

When leaving, my manager told me I was making a “big mistake”. What kind of manager does that? All they would push is the hiring number they had to reach. That’s it, you don’t matter to them at all.

The leader of the office once said “I sometimes forget you guys have families” to us employees at the company picnic. Awesome! Way to reassure me that this place is a terrible work environment. 

Terrible training plan, huge disconnect from “core” IBM. Embarrassing to even say I contributed to that office.

Title: "No job security - no loyalty"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Good breath of technology
Decent benefits
Cons:
IBM has ZERO loyalty to its employees, particularly in the US.
Work goes offshore -> fire US employee
Cheaper out of college resource available -> fire US employee

Also, as documented in various lawsuits and industry articles, if you are over 40, there is a target in your head. You work hard, and get good reviews throughout your career, so that you reach a decent salary band. Great, right? Wrong. Because now you are too expensive for IBM to make a good profit margin, so you are a top candidate for one of the many Resource Actions. That's when there is an arbitrary order from the top for managers to cut a certain percentage of people above a certain band.

For the record, I'm still employed by IBM, and managed to survive many rounds of cuts. But I have absolutely no illusions that my job is safe.

If you are young and need a relatively low starting salary, IBM is probably hiring across all fronts.  So you can make a quick buck. But if you're interested in starting at a company where you can grow, look elsewhere.

Title: "IBM Retaliated against FMLA"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: None that I can think of.
Cons: IBM retaliated against me for taking FMLA leave, beware!! The moment I returned from FMLA leave due to a disability, I was retaliated against by a VP. I contacted HR on two different occasions, and they did nothing. I ended up having to contact the EEOC and they have given me permission to sue IBM due to them retaliating against me for taking FMLA leave. If you have a disability, don’t expect this company to honor protected FMLA leave even though it’s against the law if they treat you the same way they did me!

Title: "Awful and sad"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros:
If you’re recently hired at the director+ level they pay well because no one from outside the company wants to work there.
Director+ gets you and administrative assistant which is exceedingly outdated but it’s nice not to have to do your own expenses
Cons: It’s hard to describe just how sad it is to work at this company.  It’s collapsing under the weight of overly complicated, inflexible business processes. There are two types of people here: people that actually do some work and walk around looking traumatized and people that fire out emails all day, clogging up everyone’s inbox or sit on 30 person conference calls and produce nothing. It’s pure lunacy. The co-location thing they did was one of the stupidest moves anyone has ever seen in business. In fact it was downright abusive and heartbreaking to watch people struggle with that decision.  Directors and above spend most of their day inspecting or being inspected using these Byzantine metrics reports.Everyone is constantly worrying when they get laid off too.  Within two days of working here I had decided to pull the plug and walked away from a huge paycheck. Seriously I don’t know how anyone works at this company it’s miserable.

Cons: It is hard to find a role at IBM for people who would like to work 'hard'. There seems to be a lack of higher level strategic direction of the organization and ithe uncertainty is sensed by the sales reps and marketing teams. I do not think the company does a good job managing early career talent either. I experienced very little direction given since I was first hired or presentation of common options for progression. Sales, if anything, does this development somewhat better than other roles I've experienced through their training program. Workplace demographic is split. A lot of older workers and a lot of brand new employees out of college. Not much presence in the middle, illustrating the lack of opportunities for advancement from entry ranks.

Title: "Don't work here, there are better options"

Work elsewhere if you want to be happy in the long term.

Title: "Don't waste your career"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Got to work mostly from home for 10 years... til they tossed me aside for cheaper offshore replacements.
Cons:
As a consultant, you are required to work 106% or more of billable hours in a year, and you have to make up any vacation time that reduces that percentage.
They offer lots of training but a lot of it is garbage, and you are required to take a LOT of mandatory training that isn't even in your area of expertise.
Mgt offers help to get your job done but when push comes to shove they cannot really help at all and all they tell you is "well, we just need to get it done!"
Horrible raises!  Might get 1-2% in the "good" years, zero in others even when you get a good review.
When they terminated me they said they didn't have any more jobs for me yet when I look on their career website they have 15 open jobs... offshore...

Title: "Cutting Edge"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: As many other reviews have pointed out, the company has been going through many reorgs and transformations in the past few years, some of which were quite painful. However, the fruits of this hard work are really starting to show. The company now is almost unrecognizable compared to where it was just 5 years ago. Bureaucracy has significantly reduced. Many teams, even those in legacy business units such as Systems, have already fully adopted the most advanced industry best practices such as Agile, CI/CD, Design Thinking, etc. to great effect. Since IBM touches almost every technology that currently exists and employs people of almost every skill set, the opportunities are endless. Work-life balance is also extremely good. Most teams are very flexible with working from home or working from another IBM office.
Cons: There are still great disparities between different teams, even between those within the same business unit. Many teams, especially those that have been around for a long time, have developed their own culture as well as very idiosyncratic ways of doing things. While this is not necessarily a bad thing in of itself, it does create confusion at times and present a learning curve for new hires.

Title: "AML jobs in Denver are not really with IBM - don't be fooled!"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Access to IBM continuing ed online modules. Okay place to hang out while you look for something better.
Cons: The AML jobs available in Denver are with an IBM subsidiary called Promontory Risk Review that IBM acquired a few years ago. Promontory is a horribly run company that runs an AML white collar sweatshop with a call center environment. If you've always wanted to work in close proximity to 60-80 other people of varying degrees of professionalism, this is for you! No career development, no raises or performance based bonuses (everyone gets the same bonus), and no possibility of moving up in the organization.

Title: "A lot of good people were Co-located!"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The  benefits were good.
Cons:
In 2017 and 2018, IBM decided to co-located their entire US Marketing department. This is where they asked their entire Marketing team to move to one of the 6 key cities that they had selected. If you didn't up and move your entire family, then you were without a job. 

This was completely unfair as there were so many GREAT marketers who had been loyal to the company 20 or 30 years, and were now without jobs! The only ones who could truly co-locate were younger people with no families or roots established.

So, if you were in your mid-30s and up, and not currently located in 1 of the key cities, you were basically going to lose your job.

This was a cheap way to layoff a lot of great older workers, and IBM should be ashamed of themselves!!! STAY away from IBM unless you're under 30 years old!

Title: "Massive Skill Growth - Losing Talent Due to Wall Street Focus and Heavy Top Down Culture"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
1. Strong learning culture for skill growth

2. Renewed focus on open source with Red Hat Acquisition - more opportunities

3. Great for college grads who can get a somewhat competitive offer from the high growth areas: Blockchain, Cloud, and Research Product Team OR Cloud Garage (non-GBS or GTS) for the consulting side.

4. Easy to move within country on same salary especially if your department is important to IBM's strategy

5. Competitive paid parental leave

6. On average, IBM is known for their People Management skills and are very good at resolving conflict. IBM will help you grow your soft skills more than most other companies.

7. Hires people without college degrees / bootcampers
Cons:
1.  Executives  continue to cost cut in the wrong areas. Renewed focus on employees is needed if the next (final?) chapter will succeed:

- Little emphasis on retaining talent (Watson system for retention is a joke) due to uncompetitive offers  for the average or above average employee - especially with experience - unless your top in your field like in AI Research. Expect ~10% below market, small sign-on bonus, and ... no stock / rsu unless your Band 10, Research, or a few exceptions like retention.

- Benefits like health care are no where near as good as they once were. HSA match doesn't help. ESPP used to be 10 - 15% now its 5%.

2. Lack of technical managers. Non-technical management have too much influence on highly technical projects which is the reason why IBM has been struggling for years with unrealistic expectations (Watson) due to lack of deep understanding. 

3. Too many levels of management, knock off two layers and empower your Offering Managers and 1st Line Managers

4. Needs a lot more of Red Hat culture

5.  Too marketing heavy, enable and empower IBM Research to help lead the company forward in a realistic fashion while working with other departments.

6. Arbitrary resource actions that cut critical senior people that eventually kills momentum of core cloud services .. yes ... cloud!

7. Ageism

8. Apprentices, Bootcampers, Interns will achieve low pay to match offshoring but even with the "skills" could never match experienced professionals ... if there are any still left around to train them from resource actions or departing to competitors

Title: ""It's not always about the money Spider-Man""
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
-Opportunity - So much opportunity to do more than just your job, passion projects, giveback to community, working with schools, internal groups, external groups.  My development job at IBM is a very small amount of the work I do, I do more for IBM outside of my lab/office just in the external giveback and working with outside organizations and groups.
-Work Life Balance - I think it's termed "integration" now, which i prefer, I've raised three kids here, it's never a perfect balance but that's ideal, because I get time to work when I need it but also time to drop kids off at school, go to kids sports/games, and help with homework.  I do work a lot, but it's driven by me.  There's tons of projects and things I do when the kids go to sleep or on a quiet evening because I love to do this stuff, and that's just me. 
-Community outreach- there's a huge sense of giveback at IBM.  IBM has a portal for registering volunteering and giveback and gives grants to organizations you work with.  IBM encourages and gives us a lot of autonomy on this so there's no real limit to how much you can work outside of IBM giving back to community as long as it doesn't interfere with your business commitments, and they will provide computing/tech resources/educational kits to help support it.
-Mentoring/networking-the most underated feature of IBM is mentoring, as a senior engineer  we're encouraged to be mentors to junior engineers, and while it's not required, it's extremely helpful to have a mentor, it's allowed me to navigate and plan my career progression based on their advice and experience.  Because you're in charge of your career the mentoring is the perfect amount of coaching and self-accountability that I need to stay motivated and on track in my career goals.
-People- People are awesome, I've worked with many people who work tirelessly with time they don't have to help me, or other people, to work with high school groups, to help people they don't even know within IBM who need help.  The part that makes IBM culture and values amazing is every single person you meet who is a living embodiment to them.
-Overall - The thing I love about IBM is that there's so much to do, I'm never bored, and always feel like I have an impact, but most importantly I feel like my impact is greater outside the company, and helping make the world better by being me and defining how I can give back to my community and help others. Is the pay comparable to the other big companies trying to recruit me?  No, but like Kingpin said "It's not always about the money Spider-Man"
Cons:
-Big-, IBM is B-I-G, so there's no list of steps for things like career progression, establishing internal support groups (like a gaming group for example), how to establish a community outreach event, etc. and that's mostly because no one defines what/how you do any of that, and really the way it's done is different for everyone so it's really up to you to figure out how to do all that. 
-Money - They pay well, is it great?  Not compared to the giants like Facebook, netflix, or Google, I've talked to those companies just to know what a move would look like and the money difference can be quite big if that's your motivation.
-Getting things done- I'm not sure I would do anything different for this given IBM's size, but IBM has a much more organic approach to starting things, getting things done, innovating side projects and community outreach etc, where you can start groups and projects you're passionate about, but you have to gather the support for it, you can get support and funding, but you have to originate the idea and figure out how to make it work and do the leg work for it, which is great if you're a type A personality and passionate about something.  But also means you become the project manager, recruiter, and communications person for your particular cause so its easy to take on too much at times.

Title: "Expect to be let go between 50 and 60 yrs old."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
The managers I worked for were excellent.   Had a voice in proposed changes and improvements.
Built a personal brand over a 21 year career.
Cons:
Agist.  Started recieving emails at age 55 asking " Have you considered IBM early retirement Plan" : never responded becaus I had no interest.
Three months before my 60th birthday got an email "Why haven't you chosen the IBM early retirement plan?"
There was a link were you could explain.
I clicked the link and explained that due to a divorce I could not financially afford to retire and I love my job and have no interest in leaving.
IBM layed me off 4 days after my 60th birthday.
When I went to a initial meeting with an outplacement agency that IBM had hired; sitting with 30 people I asked " Who is from IBM, and who has 15 or more years of service.  All but 2 hands went up and those two were from different employers.
I did not ask anyones age but based on physical appearance no one was under 50.
We all had to sign the "Will not sue" document to get one months severance pay"  I had 21 years there.

Title: "Disappointment in dysfunctional corporate sales environment"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: The health insurance benefits are good.
Cons: I attempted to get hired by IBM for over twenty years.  After nine interviews I finally received an offer from a good boss and mentor.  However, after only 2 months this boss changed roles.  My new boss immediately assigned me a new sales territory.  My sales quota was $2 million annually.  After only being with IBM for 2 1/2 months, this boss called me, out of the blue, and assigned me a requirement to build a sales pipeline of $455,000 EVERY week!  This pipeline would equate to just under $24 million annually.  After our call he asked if I had any questions.  I asked two questions.  First, the weekly pipeline requirement seemed high, does anyone else who works in my role have this high of a weekly pipeline requirement?  Secondly, how can you justify a pipeline so high to a new employee?  The answers I received were the following.  To the first question the response was you are a very experienced sales person and you should be able to build the pipeline.  To the second question the response was you are responsible for achieving the pipeline and if you don't you will be let go.  As an additional comment, I sold deals after only three months on the job, but my new boss did not care of even mention the sales success that I had achieved.  At first I built the $455,000 per week pipeline.  One week was only four days, because of a holiday and I did not achieve the $455,000 pipeline goal.  My boss called me with a human resource employee, who had only recently graduated college and was new to Human Resources.  The call informed me I had three weeks left of employment and then  I would be let go.  Another side note, my bosses, second line manager had a meeting to discuss cleaning up our sales pipeline and ensuring that deals put into our CRM were true deals and realistic.  My problem was I needed to add $455,000 in pipeline every week or lose my job.  I also called my peers, in the same role and asked if they had ever heard of a pipeline requirement of $455,000 per week.  Every sales peer I spoke with stated that is an unattainable pipeline requirement. In short, I was let go for not achieving my weekly pipeline requirement.  My former boss still works for IBM.  I do not know how people like this person have a job with any responsibility.  I do not wish this person any ill will, but feel they need help.

Title: "GBS & CIC: Good for recent-grads but don't stay long"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: If you're looking to join IBM GBS in their CIC unit, they offer a good "party platter" of different jobs and roles you can try out. Its is suitable for recent-grads or folks new to IT and software engineering. In this Center, you'll learn a lot of things, and you'll earn a lot of hotel/airline miles from flying every week to client sites. The CIC's clients have a range of demanding jobs. But you're never alone as you'll have the backing of a massive company behind you, ready to help. There are so many experts and SMEs within the company directory to reach out to and ask for help. This is a good place to work for people who are looking for fast paced work with changing demands, you'll end up playing all kinds of roles from dba, sysadmin, IT levels 1, 2, 3, and general programming. If you end up on a project that you dislike after a few months, you could switch to other projects if they have seats available and you get management approval. Projects are very liquid, so if you don't see something you like this week, something else might pop up next week. Your IBM assigned laptop can be Lenovo or Apple Macbook, with the Lenovos offering choice of Windows or a few Linux flavors like RHEL. But some projects require client-approved laptops that are entirely up to them. Lastly, but most importantly, you'll meet lots of smart and dedicated people. Connect with them early and keep in touch. I would only recommend people work at an IBM CIC for a year or so until they can find something else more stable or in their specific career field.
Cons:
Client projects available to pick from are mostly legacy and maintenance "keep the lights on", and not a lot of actual programming. (Workday, SuccessFactors, RPM systems, etc.) 

The utilization reports are all that matter. You have to record your hours every week on Thursday by 4pm or managers will hunt you down, but their time-recording tool won't let you pre-set hours for the coming week. 

Your progressions are tied to how many extra hours you can bill the client, and since you're salary you won't earn OT. Progressions to the next band level are only allowed once per year. Its not merit-based. If you're ever sick and looking to take a sick-day, you'll be pushed to work-from-home instead to continue billing hours to the client.

The minimum expected billing is 44hrs/wk but it wasn't unheard of to work 70hrs/wk. Every so often, there will be a competition to see which worker can earn the most hours in a month. Some folks worked 150+% utilization during this time. The winners of these competitions would get a $25-$50 gift card. 

If you're one of the few that actually works in the Center, the office supplies are non-existent. Good luck if you need a pen, paper, whiteboard markers, or other basic supplies as they don't stock up on anything. Including coffee. And no, we weren't allowed to bring in personal coffee makers. 

Conference rooms are constantly being squatted by managers, which forces everyone to make conf calls from their cubicle in an already loud open office. You don't get an IBM-assigned mobile phone, so you'll have to share your personal phone number with managers, coworkers, and clients. 

Projects come and go on a whim. Your project can get pulled out from under you one day and the next you'll be assigned something else entirely. That next project could require travel, so starting next week you could be in New York for the next six months. 

Sometimes the bill codes for a project will stop working, so your utilization will plummet while PMs scramble to get new billing accounts in place. Which triggers your name to show up on reports other mangers see, and then they'll ask why you're not billing hours, and you'll explain the bill code doesn't work, all the while your PM is not communicating this to the upper managers in the first place. 

Even if you're not affected by RAs (mass layoffs), you'll hear about them every year. It wasn't uncommon for PMs and coworkers to disappear. It seemed a lot of seasoned workers would announce their "retirement", only to update their LinkedIn that they're working for another company. Again, make connections while you're here and network with these people as soon as possible. You'll never know if they'll be RA'd or retire unexpectedly.

Title: "Terrible company to work for."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: It's big, so it pays on time.
Cons:
1. Leadership is negative. I have personally heard VPs yell/scream/use profanity at their direct reports in front of 50+people on a call.
2. A large percentage of your colleagues are incompetent. So many times, I had to chase people to do their jobs. Though, for IBM, hiring incompetent people seems like a great way to create manager jobs.
3. Upper management (at least HR) tries to 'inspire' through fear-mongering, and this trickles down to the lower levels. Employees are afraid to ask for simple, reasonable requests in fear of backlash from managers. I've also heard them directly mock their employees in front of others like a child on a playground.
- Like other service companies, IBM offers a wide variety of industries for your interest. However, management appears to 'block' most movement. Some of my colleagues were patient enough and waited 5 years for a change. Others gave up and left the company for a higher pay position in the industry they were looking for.
4. The individual target bonuses are high, but the company is leaking money, so rewards are low. On my last year, I received the highest rating possible, and received a formal IBM pdf stating my bonus was $0. What a slap in the face...
5. Disorganized - IBM has become so large that it is nearly impossible to really work 'as a team'. Like many consulting firms, IBM has resources in other countries (mainly India) due to cost. Unlike other consulting firms, the travel 'legislators' do not work well; they are not flexible. On an internal deployment, IBM travel refused to grant approval to even APPLY for a visa for my Indian colleagues because the IBM criteria of X days was not met. 
6. Too much time is spent on administrivia. Things which should be simple like time cards, expenses, booking travel require so many hoops, IBM has pages-long documentation on how to get one travel request. Just think of how much time is spent for each new project manager reading through this documentation just so they can do their actual jobs.

Cons:
Feast or Famine, you are either busy or not.

No one will explain all the links on the websites or the multitude or things you need to keep up with and you are just expected to figure it out.

Resource actions/WorkForce Reductions are becoming a yearly or quarterly thing, so dont expect to stay in a position for long.

In my case my Manager was in a different city, hours away, so i only seen them a couple of times, during new hire, round table meeting (bad), and when someone would quit to collect their company property (ie laptop and cell).

Title: "High level vision blinds low level planning"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: It's big and can do what it wants
Cons:
Over and over and over again I've seen my leadership plan a process change, an org change, a tool change at a 10,000 ft level and say "we'll figure out the rest when we get in there." And over and over and over again they seem mystified as to why they aren't seeing the target results.  They have vision but lack the ability to think through the details.  Changes are rolled out without a thorough stakeholder analysis, without adequate warning, and without adequate training.

There is also no accountability for decision making.  When changes have been rolled out that didn't work well each manager's response was "Well, this issue is above my pay grade".    When issues that could impact our team came up the leaders had to be prompted to push back and make sure the change was really necessary.

Bonus and raise structure was aweful

Title: "Very unstable company"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: It's a job and a paycheck
Cons:
*This company has no idea what they want to do or be in this  would of technology.  Sr. Management wouldn't know innovation if it bit then in the butt.  They buy different companies and suck the life out of them, run thier customer base off and then layoff all the employee's. 

* The insurance is high we less coverage

* They don't pay a bonus unless you're in sales

* Yearly merit increases or 1 to 2%, even if you are a top performer... what a joke.

* They only paid their percentage of 401k incentives on December 31st. which means if you work for the company all year and get fired or leave before December 31st they won't contribute anything to your 401k for that year.

Title: "Going fast down the disappointment slide"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: There still remains an element of social conscience and ethics that gives a few occasional moments of pride.
Cons:
I have been with IBM for 12+ years - started as a Band 7 and currently a Band D. Here are my challenges over the last few years:

1.  Too much red tape - worse than some governments. I spend more time on internal issues (approx 60%) than client facing issues (40%). My measurement is 100% client facing. Anyone see the disconnect ? 

2. Too many people asking questions and reviewing - very few willing to do work. While it is great to get feedback and empower people - it is amazing how much time I waste listening to people who have no idea what they are saying all under the umbrella of empowerment. Results - delays and poor quality.

3. #MenToo - the company has swung too far towards promoting women. Some of my best managers have been women and my mentor is a woman. As managers, I am not sure how to deal with non-performing women as I fear the wrath of other women executives. It is becoming increasingly difficult to operate openly and be fair to all now.
IBM has become pretty much a WomenFirst company and being a woman is a clear competitive advantage now. Talent is now a distant second. Compensation, promotion, recognition - everything is looked at critically through this lens. 
4. Finally, growing up my mom used to say - empty vessels make more noise. At IBM, the age old adage is modified as "empty vessels make more noise and get recognized and promoted".

Title: "Don’t do it! It is a sad dinosaur!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
When I joined IBM, I was excited, however I encountered so many burned out and disgruntled  employees it was sad. IBM does not value their employees and really feels as though they are doing you a favor by employing you. They have reduced benefits offered every year. For example, they eliminated group universal life insurance and offer term insurance only ( it’s not a fixed term like a standard policy but month to month and only good as long as you are employee- if you take leave or get sick forget it! You might as well buy a policy from your own insurance agent ).
They no longer allow people to work from home to force collaboration. Employees who used to work at home now sneak into their offices and talk to no one, they sneak out again as soon as they can!
Contrary to what they state, they do not promote or support women! When I got pregnant they told me I was on the mommy track and would not get promoted ever.  Raises are slim to none, so my advice to you is negotiate a higher salary than they offered because you will not get more! Average raises are 1%! Additionally they do not pay out their bonus!
Cons:
Low salaries
Continues to eliminate benefits like remote working and group universal life 
No career path or promotions.
Most employees are struggling to just make it until retirement
Not innovative 
Run down buildings 
Bullying

Title: "Run, do not walk, away from this company!!!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Literally nothing....except maybe the flexible schedule.
Cons: There are WAY too many cooks in the kitchen trying to make themselves relevant by making completely irrelevant decisions that do absolutely no good whatsoever for the overall well-being of this company or it's employees. Processes are a joke, it takes 72 years to get anything accomplished, every time you attempt to seek support, you're pointed in 62 other directions and no one can give you a straight answer. They 1000% do not value their employees. The running joke around here is you get paid more if you leave and come back than you do trying to grow your career here (seriously, find someone you know that's works here and ask them about that). Employees are SEVERELY under-paid and when you're lucky enough to find a manager who will go to bat for you to try and get you the increase you deserve, it has to go through 12 approval processes only for the manager and employee to be ultimately be told "too bad, so sad". Why do I still work here you ask? Believe me when I say, I am ferociously trying to leave. It is a terrible, de-valuing place to work and I advise you to run, not walk, away from this dumpster fire!!

Title: "Great opportunity to start, harder to grow"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
I worked at IBM for close to four years and had a lot of wonderful memories there. Some of the perks:

- Amazing benefits. Even after 2-3 years there, you will go a long way towards retirement.
- You meet so many people. Met close to 200-300 in three years, definitely more than most companies.
- Lots of opportunities to travel for trainings and different events on their dime.
- Fairly flexible promotion process - if you do the work and make a good case, can get promoted in close to 6-8 months, depending on the manager and division
- Household name. It will do wonders for your future career just by having it on your resume.
Cons:
- Very dependent on where you work. If you're in consulting, you could be doing anything from leading Blockchain or Watson projects to leading a project that will rarely get noticed by management.
- Some managers there have been promoted because they've been at IBM for 10-15 years and not necessarily because they're good managers. Does not bode well for turnover with younger staff.
- It's a huge company without a core product - If you ask Google, Facebook, or Amazon what they're known for, most will have a consistent answer. Very few people can properly articulate what IBM is known for. (Cloud? Technology? Services? Computers?)
- You'll do a lot of things at IBM that are not transferrable to future opportunities. Design Thinking and Agile are all done the "IBM Way" and they'll give you certificates and badges for completing classes on "IBM Essentials to Blockchain". Something that feels good in the moment but worthless when you're looking at the market.
- Huge company. Good luck meeting your boss's boss. After two promotions, I was still almost ten levels removed from Ginni Rometty.
- Until you specialize, you're mostly stuck. Generalist consultants don't go too far at IBM, outside of Project Manager roles.

Title: "All depends on the group you are in"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
IBM has amazing people and there is a culture of constantly reinventing the business to adapt to the market. I hear of other people or groups doing some exciting work in AI or Cloud or even Mainframes and it's great to hear those stories. A friend describes his group as if it's a startup in a large company, with all the innovation and activity associated with that statement.
In addition, the training is almost overwhelming and you feel like you can learn anything here. The internal training is incredibly well-produced and quite slick. You actually almost enjoy learning a topic you aren't interested in normally.
Work-life balance will be business unit and job role dependent, but IBM wants everyone to have a great work-life balance and most people seem to based on who stays in the office.
Heavy HR promotion of career growth (see cons).
Great management philosophy.
As an engineer, you might find a lot of places to move to if you don't like your current role.
Agile, modern tools are plentiful.
Cons:
If you are in a stagnating or failing business unit (like mine), you feel left behind, and your career feels like it is rotting from slow inertia. The disparity between a functioning and non-functioning business unit drives morale down heavily. It's like you don't work at the same company as others do.
Career growth is not even possible in various parts of IBM.
Lots of little or big layoffs. All the time.  A lot of moving jobs overseas.
Bonuses are paltry.
Raises are weak or non-existent, though the salary bands are generous.
Managers will find it very hard to try to move to a better job in IBM unlike engineers.
Ancient, legacy tools are plentiful.

Title: "Sad to see a great company in decline"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
* Career advancement for the right personality type.  IBM could work for you if you are a schmoozer and you value moving up the ranks more than product quality or ensuring long-term success.
* Pay is competitive.
* There are pockets of great people.  Finding the right group is critical.
Cons:
* What IBM says publicly does not match how they actually manage their business.  If you care about honesty and long term success, IBM will not work for you.
* IBM is totally focused on short term results.  This is frequently achievable only through constant cost-cutting, making it impossible to produce competitive products, particularly those that require long term vision and development.  
* This cost-cutting approaches ridiculous extremes.  By the time I left IBM, it was essentially impossible to acquire extra RAM for my workstation.  I had to buy my own copies of productivity software such as MS Office so that I could work with the formats required by our customers. 
* IBM incentivizes upper management to change positions frequently.  This results in those execs having no long-term investment in their business unit.
* IBM does not support remote employees.  Yet at the same time, they build teams consisting of people from multiple time zones, requiring everyone to be on conference calls all day and work ridiculous hours.

Title: "Customer Service Rep / Service Desk Agent"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: IBM hires people to work in Service Desk / Customer Service with very little or no experience. It is a decent way to get into tech and get experience working at a large corporation. If you have valuable talents and strive to learn, you will be given many different roles which will give you experience and bullet points on your resume.
Cons: The work environment gets very toxic in service desk. If you have talents they will abuse them and you won't get much of any raise or a different title. Leadership doesn't value much of anyone in service desk. If you try to apply elsewhere at IBM, management will often do whatever they can to sabotage your attempt at moving to a better job. They act like slave drivers, don't often listen to feedback given by agents and talk very unprofessionally about employees behind their back.

Title: "Would rate 3.5 if I could"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Flexible on job location (i.e. remote work), and setting your own hours.  Plenty of opportunities to work abroad.  There are training/education/certification opportunities, but all are virtual and self study.  The company is large enough where lateral moves can be easy to find, and offer new career challenges.
Cons: Finance runs the company, and they will frequently (and suddenly) put in place strict spending cuts.  To the point where it is nearly impossible to do any non-customer travel.  For group training, conferences, team meetings, etc.  There are people with whom I have worked for 10+ years, and have never met face to face.  Management puts little effort into career guidance.  There are some exceptions to that rule, but not many.

How can she get a bonus when the company is performing badly and the other employees don't get any?!

Title: "This isn’t where you want to be."

Cons: I don’t know where to begin. There are very few people who enjoy working out of Keyser, WV. Management doesn’t value developers- you’re basically a code monkey with zero room for growth, while getting less benefits than the staffing folks or the people with jobs far easier than development work. It’s really backwards and kind of shows problems at the company level. Giving worse benefits to the people making your products really isn’t the right move.

Title: "IBM GBS is a technology vendor, not a consulting firm.  Not a peer to Deloitte, Accenture, etc."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Great exposure to leading technologies, lots of very smart people
Cons: Does not value business expertise--in fact, it devalues it.  No investment in business-oriented solutions.   Can't talk to the CEO about real business challenges, so only sells shrink-wrapped solutions to the CIO (cloud, blockchain, security)

Title: "Good company to work"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Staying on top of technology changes
Cons: Lots of traveling to administer ourselves

Title: "Trending down since 2013"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Remote work is nice due to the flexible schedule, comfort of working from home, and leaves plenty of time to apply for other jobs. Saved a lot of money on gas and car payments. Extensive travel helps keep those reward points high. IBM still looks great on the resume because most other employers don't know what a wreck it is. The company is so large that depending on the role, comp plan, territory, and manager you may actually not hate your job.
Cons:
Where to begin? Let's start with the top 5... 
1. Management's "strategy" can best be described as: Let's constantly implement broad, sweeping changes with little to no warning, put our employees in impossible situations, brow beat them when they fall short, then lay everyone off 3 months later. Oh, and then wonder why moral is at rock bottom. 
2. Culture... there is none. Unless you consider infighting, back stabbing, and a general "meh" attitude toward colleagues a culture. 
3. Get ready for an earful of dishonesty and broken promises from your managers. Managers are constantly trying to oversell employees on a job, project, move, etc. when the reality is they need someone to fill a garbage job that no one wants. Once you're in the role, they'll do nothing to help you. And every time you go to them with a problem, they'll put it back on you. Really atrocious management all around. 
4. Semi-annual changes to comp plans and quotas to put full attainment just out of reach. Did you do well last quarter? Guess what, your quota is going through the roof so save that last commission check because you won't be getting another one any time soon. Did your whole team do well last quarter? Expect the department comp plan to be adjusted... IBM is always looking for ways to pay you less while relying on the complacence of their employees to keep them around. 
5. Mediocrity, laziness and bureaucracy abound. I touched on this in #3 but it's really amazing how many people here will not lift a finger to help you, actively oppose outside-the-box thinking, and are obviously here just to collect a paycheck... if it's not in their job description, it's not their problem. At some point you'll realize that attitude begins to drain you of your motivation and work ethic, and you'll either make a choice to fight it or accept a mediocre performance from yourself. Don't expect this to be the company where you do your best work - use IBM to build your resume, put in a couple years, then move on to bigger and better things. As for jumping through hoops, get ready for a lot it; nothing gets done here quickly and without approvals, modifications, and pointless review by a dozen other managers and analysts.

Title: "Good one"

Title: "Incredible Place to Start Your Consulting Career"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
When I first joined, I heard conflicting stories of love and hate for the job. Keep in mind, IBM is a massive company with over 400k employees so there will naturally be a mix of those in any big firm.  

IBM is undergoing a major transformation right now, and it is an awesome time to be an IBMer. From Watson AI to cutting edge digital transformation project partnerships with Apple, IBM is involved with a lot of cool opportunities. I joined straight from undergrad and can confidently say that I have learned immensely as a consultant and even now senior consultant. Overall, I am extremely happy with my decision to start my career as a consultant at IBM. 

- IBM = High Prestige and Brand Name... Great exposure to different industries, especially early on in your career. (been here for almost 3 years and I have worked in Pharmaceuticals, CPG, Electronics and Foods)

- Incredible support and colleagues, some really smart people work here and the educational resources/training  can be used to further your skills greatly

- As for work-life balance, it has its ups and down (way more ups for me). I've had a lot of opportunity to work remote, but also times where I'm working through the weekend on 12 hour shifts... (client dependent)

- High percentage increase in pay when promoting ( got around 38% when I went from consultant to senior)

- Flexibility in living location (anywhere as long as you have weekly access to an airport)

- Option to alt travel to another city if it is less than or equal to the cost of flying you back home (huge plus for me)

- Opportunity to earn status and free miles/points on airline/hotel chain and car rentals (I've funded numerous international trips via points I've earned from client travel-  for me huge plus)
Cons:
- Make it your own culture. Sometimes you have to be a go-getter and network to get the next project. Don't expect to get handed new opportunities, other than your first year in (unless you have a proven track record). 

- Consultants here tend to get lumped into a specialized area. For example, I am in SAP and everyone in my group works in SAP. Once you are identified as a skilled and experienced user, there's a high chance of getting pigeonholed into one specific area of consulting making it hard to change down the line. 

- High travel requirements. In the client's office by Monday, home by Thursday night on normal weeks (work remote Friday). Every once in awhile expect weekend work that can be very long (although periods of remote work make up for this in my opinion)

- High utilization targets for new/newer inexperienced consultants. Being on the bench is all dependent on what you make of your first opportunities when you start. Sometimes these factors are out of your favor when you start, especially during seasons of minimal client demand. Once you gather the appropriate skills to become client facing, tons of opportunities arise and I have barely been on the bench throughout my 3 years here.

- Small raises and/or bonuses. However, big pay jump when you promote 

- Less face to face management  (I have never met my IBM manager in person)

Title: "You're a consultant, but you don't make consultant salary."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: IBM is a great place to start a career in consulting, but most people leave after a year.
Cons:
The center has a very high employee attrition rate and struggles with retaining top talent. Center employees are put under the same client pressures as their core counterparts, but make a fraction of their salary. Despite being a high performer and delivering value, you'll still feel micromanaged. You're only allowed 2 work from home days a month which is quite frustrating if you travel.

If you probe enough, you'll discover new hires are making more than seasoned employees at the center.

Pros: The products and services are superb.  The co-workers are all wonderful, smart people.  The benefits are quite good too.
Cons: If you're over 40, your days are numbered.  Mass layoffs every 90 days, mostly targeting anyone over 40 who they will throw out the door with only one month of severance pay regardless of tenure.  You have to be employed on December 15th in order to get your 401k company match.  This is a toxic environment.  Upper management is only focused on feathering their own nest.  You've been warned about IBM.  If you get whacked its your own fault.

Pros: People on the software side below management are good, R&D capabilities are wonderful, Lots of roles, compensation is reasonable,
Cons: Long term declines in revenues, stock value, and brand strength, Shedding people by the thousands every 6 months to maintain profits, Targeting older people and expensive people, Selling off parts of the business, Enforced watching of inane training videos (Sometimes hundreds of hours per year), Offering pricing too high, Too little investment in solutions specific to industry issues, Administrative tasks required are onerous, Sales objectives are crazy, Services strategy of land-and-expand is ugly, Can't convert good R&D into viable offerings because of unrealistic expectations, Too many more to list...

Title: "Good company"

Title: "Dysfunctional from top to bottom"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I am surrounded by good people who know how to deliver high quality software. The salary seems higher than most others in the area, with a fair amount of vacation, if you include floating holidays.
Cons:
Those same people who know how to deliver software are hindered by terrible processes and decision making, some of the worst management I've experienced in more than 20 years of working in this industry. They will definitely lay off huge swaths of people at the drop of a hat. Considering that they don't seem to have much mastery in developing worthwhile products, you would be well-served by keeping some money liquid in the event of a layoff. 

Hilariously, *every* piece of software that we use internally is worst in class, including IBM's own products. Every process is ill-defined and difficult to navigate. Knowledge is not shared except through social networks.

There seems to be opportunities for software engineers to move around internally (discovered after layoffs), but I have yet to find anyone who was happy with their move. Opportunities for managers are nearly non-existent.

The benefits are terrible. I hired someone and was able to give him a sizable increase, which he lost (and then some) when he had to pay for health benefits.

Title: "It's all about your management team"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Vast world wide network of brilliant colleagues.  Most of the people are super helpful and are there to make a difference.  The compensation is competitive and there's a wide variety of assignments you can explore over the course of your career.  There are still some great managers at the company.
Cons: The executive management style is increasingly coercive and toxic.   Flawed architectural assumptions and unrealistic business case expectations, by narcissistic senior executives, drives insane employee workloads, and contributes to a depressing high stress work environment.  There is a growing tendency towards micromanagement.  Too many budgetary allocation decisions are made by financial people instead of those responsible to get things done.

Title: "Baton Rouge Leadership dont care about your career"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Working remote is great especially working from home. Many of the co-workers are great and fun to be around. Many of them are really smart which begs the question why are they still in the CIC. If you need an opportunity to get in the IT segment (especially college grads) and do not care about your pay or career growth, this is the place.
Cons: The pay is low and worse arethe people who have been there 3 to 5 years (that are absolute work horses and valuable to the CIC) and have gotten minimum raises.  You learn in less than a month that IBM Baton Rouge is not the place to stay more than a year. Everyone seems to be placed outside of their discipline meaning Java doing SAP, SAP doing Microsoft, Microsoft doing Java, etc. Projects come open and you're placed where ever your are needed not where you want to be.  My manager never once sat down with me and discuss his expectations or mines.  There is no real strategy for growth and any learning or training you have to learn and study on your own. No live instructors or bootcamps to get certified in different areas. They will pay for the cert test but you have to prepare on you own  via online even if that means buying your own books. All in all the worst experience ever working for corporate America.  The CIC is ONLY concerned with numbers: hiring 800 people like they promise the city of Baton Rouge; utilization of their employees which means you are actively engage on a project, doesn't matter what it is and those that are working are claiming enough project hours to cover those who are on the bench/not on a project (yeah think about that one); and REVENUE for the CIC! That is all the leadership is concerned with, not your development , growth or pay.
