Title: "IBM Cloud Support Engineer - Get in, get experience, get out ASAP."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
* Liberal vacation/sick day policy :

5 sick days off, 2 weeks vacation, 4 days personal choice holiday in addition to the observed holidays in your region.

* Free cloud account. 

As a Cloud Support Engineer (in whatever functional block/technology domain), you will have the ability to provision infrastructure and lab things out for free. This means that you will have your own lab in the cloud to experiment and learn as much as possible. This is by far the best benefit as otherwise you would be paying thousands of dollars for the opportunity.

* Direct exposure to insane amounts of enterprise technology.

If you want to become a system admin, this is the perfect place to gain the chops to do so. You will be exposed to NFS, iSCSI, virtual networking, high availability protocols, load balancers, CDNs, the full 9 yards. You can learn to be a VMware guy, a Citrix guy, a Storage guy, a Juniper/Cisco guy.. whatever you want. Exposure is accelerated based on the functional block you are placed in, which is the tech that your team will focus on.

* Free snacks and drinks in the break room.

If you love stuffing yourself with junk food and chugging Mountain Dew, you will enjoy it.
Cons:
* Zero career growth. 

Your career will die here if you let it. 

IBM loves to pretend that you have a future with them. They have its managers hold these things called 'Career Conversations', and these serve as just ways to fool you into thinking that they care about your career growth when in fact this is not the case. It's just to try and inspire hope in you and try and keep you around for another year or so.

When you apply for jobs internally, you will never hear back from the managers, and the job postings will just sit there more months and months without closing. Preference for actual hires is given to external people as opposed to internal people.

* Zero useful training. 

They try and train you but it is all reading based as opposed to  experiential, and what you will end up dealing with is never what you read about. 

In this job, you are essentially being thrown out to sea. If you swim, good. 

You will -always- have to learn new things on the fly. 

* This job is essentially a call center. The 'Engineer' title you're given is just to impress customers.

This is a stressful environment and people will be calling in all the time, demanding that you treat -them- as special, and to treat all their issues as a Sev 1.
God forbid that you work in either the Network or Security functional blocks - you will always be overworked even when the other blocks have downtime, and will be dealing with WebExes day in, day out.  

* No recognition at all for your personal progress and learning efforts. 

You could become a GOD OF TECHNOLOGY still no one would blink an eye, least of all management. If you are expecting to be rewarded for going above and beyond, this is the wrong company for you.

* No raises. 

Whatever you are offered in the beginning, that's it. If you are even offered a COL adjustment, take this as a hint that your direct manager loves you and bothered to even fight for it.

* Insane amount of scope creep.

In theory, this job is supposed to be 'Support', and the customer manages their own environment. 

In practice, you are now the underpaid and overworked systems administrator of thousands of different companies, especially if you are dealing with a VIP. If that customer so much as hints at being unhappy, the technical account managers will come in and harass you until you make them happy, even if it means that what you end up doing is far out of the reach of the terms of service.

* Management does not understand your pain or what you are dealing with.

IBM is saturated with managers and middle managers who have no idea about the tech their teams deal with, and just exist to serve as an additional link in the chain. When you explain something technical to them or why something didn't work, their eyes glaze over. 

What you have to understand is the following: 

If you just want a job where you can clock in, cruise and clock out, this is the job for you. To survive in this environment, you have to be emotionally dead inside.

You can't care about anything or take anything personally, because this is the environment that management cultivates even if they refuse to recognize it. 

The customers are the priority always, even if it means that your quality of life or mental sanity takes a hit. You have to learn to tune out the angry customers, the lack of career progress and apathy by management. They do not care about how good you are. You are a meat puppet to them, make no mistakes. 

Management does not care at all about talent retention or paying you what you are worth. They will hire some college kid with no clue what SSH and DNS are to take your place.

This is a great place to start your career. This is a horrible place to let it end.

Title: "Stripped of every benefit"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: You will have good people to work with and a big brand name for your resume. The work load isn't too heavy.
Cons: Raises and bonuses are non existent and have been for years. If you perform well and you are not in sales or an executive, your bonus may be $800. Also, as of 2019 IBM eliminated out of network health coverage. None of the plans offer it though they still call the plans PPO plans, but read the fine print. You are 100% out of pocket for out of network coverage. But the costs go up every year while the coverage declines. IBM used to allow work from home but in an effort to streamline that option is gone, so you will pay to commute (not reimbursed) and work in an open plan office with picnic tables as desks and not even a coat closet in some locations. Worse case you end up at a WeWork.

Title: "Great Benefits and Work Environment"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: IBM is an ever evolving company as any company has to be to survive for as long as it has.  The work environment is healthily challenging and the benefits are top notch.  If you push yourself, make your career desires known and dedicate yourself to achieve your goals, then anything is possible. Yes, there will be challenges. Nothing worth having will come easy, but with diligence and tenacity, you can make things happen. It will be important to have a good relationship with your manager as they are the gate keeper to many things.  It's important to keep a pulse on where the business is heading as well. You may  need to switch roles every 5 years if you'd like to remain with the company. Always move to the groups where IBM is investing. You will have more safety there.  IBM overall is still a great company and offers an array of benefit options and matching 401k up to 6%.
Cons: Sometimes you can feel overwhelmed with all of the information that you receive via email with the different initiatives. You feel spammed by your own organization. The company match now comes at the end of the year instead of with each paycheck. As with most big companies these days, a lack to meet the quarterly goals could be dire. Due to the history of layoffs, employees sometimes feel stressed that their days could be numbered if your group isn't performing well.

Title: "Dissapointing"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Flexible work option (2 days per month). PMP certification reimbursable after approval by management.  It is possible to gain a secret clearance (to move to the DC area).  Descent entry level experience. 401k vested at start and employer match at 6%. Medical and dental benefits. Pretty stable environment.
Cons: They say because the cost of living is lower they offer a low wage. Entry level starts between band 1-4 which is around $12.50 and $18.50 per hour. If you want to transfer to another department, be prepared to be low balled through your IBM career.  It is extremely difficult to transfer, get promoted or obtain a substantial pay increase.  Employee portion of medical benefits are expensive! The local area is not good. IBM is operating at model in which they acquire low cost resources and bill the client high; they want they want to invest as little as possible in their employees in low cost areas.  Someone else said they are trying to hire locally because they can't attract or retain good talent outside of this black hole. It is the truth.

Title: "Great company"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: IBM is a company that values the expertise you can bring in.  If you are an experienced professional with a knowledge that IBM considers valuable, there's no better place to go.  IBM will compensate your experience like no one else.
Cons: It's hard to grow your income.  The company will lay you off without hesitation if your expertise is not needed any more.   It has a high personnel rotation.   Many thousands leaving, many thousands coming in.

Title: "Work-from-home creates very productive, efficient, and drama-free environment"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Most people work entirely from home which makes for unusually high productivity and high efficiency and keeps drama to a bare minimum.   This leads to increased job satisfaction and performance.  It also allows IBM to attract top talent without having to worry about attracting "acceptable" talent just because they happen to live in a certain location.  Most people are extremely helpful and service oriented.  Salary is competitive.
Cons: Very top heavy, especially in GBS.  In some areas of GBS, you'll have a VP, reporting to a VP, reporting to a VP and below them might be just 5 lower level employees.  Getting promoted in GBS is nearly impossible once you've hit a band 10 (which is lowest level of management).  Raises amount to 1% at the very most, if at all.  Annual bonuses are 1% to 2% at the most, if it all (but the ability to work from home with high productivity makes up for that). Company talks about valuing diversity but doesn't have practices in place to honor that talk.

Title: "Times are changing"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Salary, work flexibility, great managers and team
Cons: Very little recognition, low yearly bonus and raises as of the last few years, consistent layoffs due to company transitioning at this time. Would like to see more accepted tuition assistance for employees. In some areas, it can be difficult to advance.

Title: "You do not want anything to do with the Cloud Innovation Lab"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Some cool tech in the stack and the tools used to build the CI/CD pipeline.  Good cafe in the building.
Cons: No Onboarding, No Engineering Documentation, Poor Collaboration and Communication and a hostile work environment.  When my manager was replaced with a new one, he proved to be an inexperienced and a bully and as he was assigned to work for a manager who was also a bully, I had no choice but to file a formal complaint with HR and with the head of the business unit when without giving any negative feedback, my new manager singled me out from the group as the only person that was not allowed to work from home several days a week as had been promised by the hiring manager.   I was also singled out as the only person in the group that had to work specified hours.  My formal complaint generated a witchhunt.  I provided digital proof of my case  that made it clear that anything negative that was being said about me was false, but it was ignored.  During the witchhunt, the head of the business unit even interviewed 2 employees who had worked with me 15 years earlier in a different type of Engineering group (QA) to see what they had to say about my performance at that time.  My Employment Lawyer stated that a court would not look kindly on such an inappropriate tactic.  I was not alone in my concerns about our new management chain as our Architect left the company shortly after the change in management and others left the group over the next few months as well.  Worst work experience I have ever had in 36 years in the industry across companies of all sizes.

Title: "They're trying, but it's too little too late"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: For those afforded the opportunity to work from home, there is great work/life balance.  The company does have some decent benefits, though healthcare benefits have waned dramatically over the past few years.  The biggest benefit of working in a company like IBM, however, is the ability to move into different roles and try new things. The company is vast, and opportunities abound.
Cons: I've worked at IBM for many years.  The culture has shifted dramatically, and not all for the good.  The executives clearly don't care much about the individual employee and are focused, quarter to quarter, on the stockholders only.  They have yet to realize that treating the employees well will result in better results, better profitability.  The shift to "co-location" within the past couple of years has done a lot of damage to morale, even for those not directly impacted.

Title: "Good and bad"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Benefits: Good Medical and excellent 401k. CEO Ginni Rometty is an inspiring leader. I've had some excellent managers and colleagues over the years, as well as terrific products and projects.
Cons: There is little work/life balance. The company lays people off so frequently that one always feels a bullseye on one's back. The morale is not good as colleagues are dropping like flies as part of quiet layoffs.  And good people are laid off too, not just dead wood.

Title: "Don’t let the big name fool you."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: New technology if you can find a way to get involved with it.
Cons:
No motivators other than “be lucky to have a job”. 
No yearly pay increase. Once you’re hired in, getting a raise is next to impossible even for stellar work. You get great reviews but keep the same salary, year after year, so you’re in essence working for less money due to inflation and when cost of living goes up each year. I’ve been working for ibm for 10 years, hired in at 100k, gotten great reviews for doing more, growing my skill set, advancing IBMs client base and technical position, and in the 10 years, I’ve gotten a couple 1200$ profit sharing bonus and a 1% pay increase and one 2% pay increase.......in 10 years. So I’m in essence making about 17% less less than when I started. (My money doesn’t go as far as it did 10 years ago, doesn’t pay the same amount of bills). And manage always says “maybe next year” year after year, until burnout sets in, our careers have been damaged from the emotional and mental torture that working for a company like this does to you.

Title: "Leave While You Still Can"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: They have decent pay, some flexibility when it comes to working from home, and you will enjoy the company of most of your peers.
Cons: Even though it is decent pay, living in Rochester is very expensive so it is still difficult to save up money. There are very few opportunities to climb the ladder towards management and even though they encourage you to be open about your professional goals, they will not let you pursue them unless it benefits your manager personally. There is an extreme lack of women and the pay and opportunities are not equal (though they claim it is). They expect you to work until the job is done but there is no overtime to compensate for the 60-70 hours a week you put in. Also, the turn around on employment is higher than anywhere else in the area (most people leave within their first 1-2 years).

Poor benefits due to insuring large numbers of retirees.

Title: "Full Time Consulant"

A lot of the new grads that have gone into CBD practice complains saying IBM just chose their career path for them and they can't change. I haven't seen this to be the case. You just need to have the balls to have an honest, yet hard conversation with your managers and delivery leader, to let them know what you want out of your time here. 

Overall a dope company.
Cons: The company as a whole seems to be just playing catch up in the terms of technology and outlook. This causes some tension because it's hard to plan your long-term future with the company.

Title: "OUTSOURCED"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Flextime, remote, lots of resources
Cons: Companies fancy they can concentrate on their core competence by outsourcing IT to IBM and along the way save big money (mostly cost cutting).  IBM retains original IT employees for a year to two then most of them are laid off after doing knowledge transfer to overseas and regardless of seniority (from prior host company) get one month of pay severance.  The reason you are outsourced to IBM in the first place is because of cost and the reason IBM removes you from that client is also because of cost not because you are underperforming.  In order to be profitable, IBM can't be keeping and paying the same number of people right?  Because everybody at the top wants to be more  profitable and got his or her year end bonus.  You are encouraged to look for other positions within IBM, personally I haven't known anyone who successfully landed another position for any meaningful length of time, like longer than three months.  Once you are on the bench and don't have a client you are underperforming as you don't generate any income for IBM and your performance appraisal would state just that now it's kind of your fault and a very good reason to get laid off . . . .  The way I see it most application support jobs are outsourced as the pay there is like 1/3 of what the US pay is.  Judging from the reviews here there are lots of good happy IBMers.  IBM is a big company so people's experience might vary quite a lot.

Title: "Any monkey can do this and they are the only ones promoted"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: IBM tries to 'train' any idiot to do any job. It's a good place for interns because those are the only people IBM wants to actually employ. Be an intern and if they give you a regular job, take it but for no more than 1 year.
Cons:
They typically do. They've dumbed down and check-boxed everything so pervasively that people who work the desk at the DMV have more autonomy. All you're ever ordered to do is paperwork and process. The job doesn't matter. 

But because pay is so low and they have a million reasons why you never get an increase, the reality of being a monkey is liberating.  Any job you do hear is do-able in about 90 days. But after that it's just the same 90 days over and over. The real downside is if you make the tiniest mistake in your process you will have 10 people chewing you out and complaining.

Title: "Intern Hire"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: IBM is a great company as a whole. That's the main reason I've stayed for over a year after being hired as an intern. I have gotten some great projects and exposure right out of college. There's also an insane amount of free internal learning and it is highly encouraged and mandatory in some cases to learn new things on the job. Work-life balance is great. I can work from home many days. The benefits are excellent. I have amazing doctors and the actual insurance companies offer many extra resources to IBM employees. 401k matching is also very ideal, I've saved quite a bit in a very short amount of time. There are also other nice perks like being a preferred employer at apartment complexes where I lived. Overall, you're covered if you're at IBM and in truth, they prepare you for a career in- or outside of the company. All of their certifications are transferable skills.
Cons: I still don't have an official title since my projects are all over the place. Unfortunately as an intern hire, I didn't have the flexibility to negotiate my salary or have a say in what position I wanted to be in. As a result, I am extremely underpaid. Also, I was placed in a team full of managers as entry-level, so that means I didn't have the chance to get a real raise. This is an unfortunately situation since I don't think I can get the pay jump I need unless I leave the company and then come back.

Title: "Very Low Salary"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
This is in regards to the IBM business center in Lansing, MI only-
The work experience is very fast paced and with multiple teams and projects.
High profile clients.
The benefits are good.
Cons:
Lower than the average hiring salary.
Very low bonus amounts given annually after a rigorous application process for them. The bonus is so low it only comes out to $20-$50 more on your monthly paycheck. No option for title promotion or any bonus given. If you work with all remote clients (which the majority of us do) the manager of the building still requires you to come in and work. So you waste time in the morning to go to a building where you work with no one and sit in an open office environment to work remotely. Highly distracting and not productive.

Title: "Software company or consultancy?"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Watson brand opened many doors.
Cons: IBM is unsure if it wants to be a software company or a consultancy firm...so unfortunately it does neither great. The cost to customers far too often outweigh the value once you add in all the software costs and people required to implement and support. Lack of teamwork and job descriptions/accountability makes it nearly impossible to work. Travel and hours is extreme (often more than 5 days/week when you account for travel and often more than 80 hours/week). Rotating door in management and strategic direction. Billing rates are astronomical, when combined with requests to overstaff as a means of training new associates, makes the price unreasonable to win new business.

Title: "I would describe my experience with IBM so far as interesting, but precarious."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
1. Great people. I enjoy talking to my coworkers and all IBMers. I have been able to get guidance and help from anyone I ask and it’s great. 

2. The benefits are decent as well, it depends on what you’re looking for, they could be better on the health insurance side and the profit sharing bonus side.

3. Flexibility. You can move to a new team, organization, or role if you don’t feel like a fit in your current place, but find a new place that is better.

4. Most teams seem to allow for a good work/life balance (although it is variable by team, my first team was pretty bad in this regard).
Cons:
1. Management is hit or miss. I have had 3 managers so far, the first one was a nice guy, but I didn’t feel like he was interested in managing (he was more technical and only met with us once per the quarter, the minimum times, sometimes even missing that deadline). The other 2 managers have been great and really seem interested in me as a person as well as an employee making me feel like I have a chance to grow in the company.

2. There aren’t many day-to-day soft benefits at our location. What I mean is there aren’t typical tech company comforts like free coffee or snacks and such. This isn’t a huge problem, but other companies in the industry do more in this space.

3. Variability in how things are run from team to team and organization to organization. If you’re not on a great team or in the wrong organization at the wrong time, that might be the reason why you have stress in your job like, bad work/life balance, bad management, constant fear of layoffs, etc.

Title: "Big 100 Year Old Company Mixed Bag"

Title: "CBD Consultant"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Amazing past legacy, great diversity and some bright people that try their hardest every day. A lot of career oppurtunities if you are self starter and motivated. Provides great working experience with some big name clients.
Cons:
Graduate entry consultant program (CBD) is horribly mismanged. Consulting practice is focused on good at selling and bad at delivering. You are very likely to be assigned a manager you will never ever get to meet, who probably doesn't care about you or one that is being forced to act as a manager now that he is at a higher band level. They have annual layoff cycles and you may end up getting caught in them even with good performance. Company is way to big for it's own good and somehow the CEO still incharge after six years of revenue decline. 

In closing, I honestly don't know if it was the right move to join IBM out of college. Sure the pay was great and so was the experience while it lasted but the badly mismanged entry level training program and overall disorganization definitely threw a wrench in my career plans.

Title: "Summit Program (Full Time)"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: 6-12 month paid training with benefits.
Cons:
Salary is lower than what you could get in other sales/technical sales roles.

Prepare to do a lot do a lot of busy work. Some of the training is not relevant or helpful to the role you'll be doing and the important stuff is given a very surface level overview. If you want depth, that will be up to you, and your time and money. 

Because there are so many layers of management, you are often given very conflicting advice on what priorities should be and what you should be working on. "It depends" comes up a lot for answers to what should be simple questions. The phrase "I'm By Myself" is very much true and you will have to spend a considerable amount of time to find people who can give you meaningful help and guidance in your professional career.

As for co-workers, some are very nice and smart, but overall, many are  incredibly cliquey, arrogant, lack maturity and do not embrace the goals of having an inclusive and diverse work culture.  If you do not like networking or working on team projects with people like this, you will have a very difficult time in this program.

Title: "Work here at your own risk. Bullying, harassment and layoffs every quarter are the social norm."

Cons: Zero autonomy if a first or second line manager. Who has budget? No one know. Lay-offs every quarter. Massive outsourcing. No opportunity for technical advancement. Old technology, command and control management. The good leaders quit or are laid off

Title: "Perfect for some, not for others"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Work/life balance is amazing. You can work from home almost 100%. In sales, you're judged only for your results. Office politics is as low as a large company can get because it's just about what you product. There's something astonishingly refreshing about it.
Cons: The company is on a downward spiral and the fact that they are (i) not producing good products/services, (ii) not recruiting top young talent is an issue. It's a company of (to be brutally honest) old white men. Also, there is very little mentorship to new hires because it's so remote work culture.

Title: "OK entry-level, but going down the gutter"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
CbD used to be a slightly better program, but there have been significant management issues that have made it go down the gutter. 
- Great work life balance
- Decent breadth of experience
- Good resources/training
- Much better diversity at the younger level than other huge companies or banks, etc.
Cons:
- They pay market rate, but then you cannot get a raise for 2 years (no exceptions). 
- No year end bonuses (I don't count $200 as a bonus)
- Not a rotational program
- No say over your staffing/career goals
- Somewhat diverse but not enough... tons of younger women but not many female executives because no women want to be high up there...
- Ivy league school grads get paid $75k or more to start. Other schools will get $70 or less. YOU CAN NEGOTIATE PAY AND LOCATION AND TYPE OF CONSULTANT. Do it!!

Cons:
Benefits decrease yearly.  For example, now the 401k match only done if you are working on Dec 15 of each year.  They laid me off in Aug so I lose match for entire year.
Used to be a good place to work for a long career but now with layoffs happening 2 times a year, your chances of lasting long are slim.  I would recommend working here only 3-5 years then finding a new employer.  Just come in to get experience and move on.

Title: "IBM US Federal Software - Look before you join - BEWARE!"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: Fellow IBM employees are usually great to work with and add to the spirit of teamwork.
Cons: Left IBM in latest round of layoffs announced in March, 2018.  IBM sales management creates a hostile work environment.  Constant pressure to sell software with little regard for customers needs.  IBM Cloud Private is not ready to sell nor does it have required certifications.  IBM Sales Management micro manages employees with weekly and individual daily sales reviews at the end of the month and quarter.  IBM delays commission payments to employees as they see fit.  Recent sales closed in June were only paid at the end of September, almost 90 days.  Even new hires have little chance to be hired into full time positions when they complete training.  Obvious effort to get rid of longer term employees in favor of younger new hires.  Don't plan on moving ahead at IBM US Federal let alone getting paid on time.

Title: "IBM trying to un-do the sins of the fathers"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Training, if you can yank yourself away during the first 6 months of the year. EVERY single year the put a moratorium on vacation [which you lose if not used] and training so every client facing employee can focus on closing business.
Best marketing company in the world. If they sold toilet brushes IBM would still be a 100 billion dollar company.
Cons:
If you're not female or minority, FORGET about promotions of longevity. IBM had always been a middle age white guy enclave, now that demographic is actively kept down as other less competant protected classes fly up the ladder. If you're a white male, you WILL eventually be 'restructured'.
Too many Indians. I was sitting in the audience in Vegas when Palmisano said - and I quote - "Why SHOULDN'T we hire off shore workers?" [his emphasis]. At least 1/3 of the employee base is now in the wretched subcontinent. 
Too much occurence of 'demo dolls' ... that is, sales women who have degrees in 12 century French art, but amazingly are always at the top of the quota-attaining pyramid.
Every client-facing employee has a quota. Period. They can call it what they want, but a quota is a quota. And if you attain the quota too early in the year that quota will be raised. Ask Ross Perot about this: it's engrained in the long time culture. 
Bonuses are determined by first level managers ['FLeMs'] and are capricious and arbitrary, so you're forced to find out and then do the utter bidding of your paper pusher boss. 
Too many bosses: there was one year where I had 9 different managers as the company continually reorganized to try to improve revenue.

Title: "System Administrator"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Its a Job and it pays
Cons:
I worked for a company that outsourced its IT department to IBM a few years ago. The current IT staff was re-badged as IBM employees and told we had 3 months to find a permanent position at IBM or we would get our 10 weeks severance package. After a month they hired almost all the staff on full time so they could avoid paying the severance package. Then they started laying us off in groups until almost no one was left. They back fill some of the positions with staff from India and South America. The new staff is untrained and seems to have no experience. The reporting structure is a mystery even to the long time IBM staff. 
 I spend most of my time fielding request from users that are so frustrated they could scream. Helpdesk requests go unanswered for weeks for very basic requests. Everyone is very frustrated. 
The IBM benefits,  timesheet and vacation system is built in such a complicated way that is easy to get underpaid, lose vacation time, or get screwed on your severance package. There is no org chart very little communication between silos. I have friends that have quit without another position because they can't continue to work in this environment. those of us that say have had to put aside job satisfaction in favor of a paycheck. If you are the type of person that cares about the job you do or the people you support you will not be happy here.
If you are looking to outsource your IT department plan on losing our most qualified staff due to their frustration dealing with IBM. The only way i can see that IBM is getting 4 and 5 stars from these reviews is they are either faked to bring up their rating or all the review  are all from other divisions or 3rd world countries

Title: "Avoid their consulting practice"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: Global business, household name, corporate discounts, and competitive compensation.
Cons:
Worked in the consulting by degrees program for two years out of undergrad.  They grossly over-hired entry-level consultants and eventually people were fighting to get on projects. 

Managers are not invested in your career development. They just check in with you to check off another box on their to-do list. You have to network within the practice to even find work and you have very little choice in what you get staffed on. When you do get work, it's usually tedious and you don't learn a lot from the experience. 

The opportunity for bonuses and 401K matches are promised when you sign on and then you don't get anything.  The company is struggling and you can feel it when you work there. Just look at IBM's revenue from the last few years: revenue has consistently declined over 22 quarters.

Title: "Short-lived job, resigned"

Cons: The HR team is invisible if you aren't a senior employee, even the exit process was hard to navigate.  Job wasn't what the company promised. People will try to dump work on you, resist it. Stand up for yourself. You'll need patience.

Title: "Fair experience but the giant is crumbling"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Many great, intelligent, and helpful people. Competitive benefits and offices all over the world. Great place to build skills working on mainframe systems so you could easily learn here and then walk onto any job with a company using IBM mainframes. If your interests lie outside of that forum though, look elsewhere.
Cons: Unfortunately, this list is growing. Multiple large layoffs have crippled the company and the loss of that experience is not recoverable. The current philosophy to "constantly reinvent yourself" from the CEO breeds a deep and constant sense of confusion and lack of cohesive direction. All of that and it seems (in my experience) as if it is the developers vs. the management. The culture is an aging IBM-pention-promised set of grumbling and disillusioned people. I am sure there are plenty of good managers here but if should not be part of the job description to seek out the few good teams on which to work. Three of my four colleagues who started with me are no longer here (1 laid off, 2 quit).

Title: "Good company"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
- great work-life balance
- freedom to do any relevant research
- great colleagues (well, most of them)
- lots of resources
Cons:
- inefficiency. Too many meetings that don't lead to anything.
- afraid of moving forward with new ideas.
- snakes are getting all the credit and the management loves those yes men.

For example, there are people who are great at organizing meetings (one of my projects have 3h of regular meeting on a day and 5h for the week) and reporting other people's work, but don't do anything themselves. At meetings, those people are the loudest voices and the most frequent interrupters. Sometimes they interrupt others just so they can repeat what their colleagues say, showing that they are actively participating. In fact they are contributing nothing more than annoying all the hard workers and wasting everyone's time.  Instead of putting a check on those people, the management praise them for their contributions and leadership. When receiving complains about those people, the management berate the whistleblower for being difficult and suspicious. This is very unfair and demoralizing. Some managers need to work on their management skills and ability to read people.

Many unnecessary tasks that contribute nothing to company revenue. Expenses cut to the point that job performance is impacted and employees are not respected as they should be. Not a good company to work for any longer.

Title: "Low pay is High Attrition"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Flexible Hours, decent "Off the books" benefits like unlimited sick days (As long as you get your work done) and the option to work from home. The area can be a pro if you like living in the middle of nowhere.
Cons: Pay is quite low, especially considering the mandatory 44 hours a week. Any time you talk to someone about their project, people will respond with "Dumpster Fire". Every is overworked and feels like their project isn't going well. Attrition is extremely high, you can see cubes empty almost every week.  The area can certainly be a con, if you aren't used to living in the middle of nowhere. Most things are an hour or so away. Cost of living isn't very low, especially not as low as a recruiter may try to make you think.

Title: "IBM CIC (Baton Rouge)"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM  for more than a year
Pros:
Educational Resources (maybe)
I am finally out!!!!!!!!!!!!
Cons:
- Below the minimum industry compensation
- Weak benefits
- Long hours 
- 100% travel (Contract specifies only 50%)
- Terrible management (care only about numbers and will tell you whatever you want to hear) Never share anything and never trust them. I've seen people get burned because they were naive and trustworthy
- Baton Rouge, LA (No offence to this city, but NO thank you, never again. This city is the kingdom of boredom and depression) I bet if the center was located in New Orleans it would have been less depressing.
- Almost no chance to transfer (Beware, the unspoken policy to transfer is that you have to spend at least 2 years in CIC. Never specified in your contract. So was caught totally by surprise)
- No career path. You will be hired as a developer and will perform analyst work instead or/and vice versa. 
The list of Cons can go on even further, but I just wanted to highlight the major issues with this specific location.

Title: "Invaluable Work Experience & Looks Great on Your Resume!"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I've never been surrounded by so many smart people, who genuinely enjoyed their work, and worked on some rad stuff. IBM is such a massive company, they truly are International. I lived in the US but my teammates were in Canada, China, and Israel. It was awesome to work with so many different people from all kinds of cultures. I got to work from home a lot because of the time zone differences. Also, IBM has some pretty cool research projects. And they really do encourage your personal development-- there are databases of excellent presentations that you can watch to teach yourself new skills.
Cons:
Working from home makes it harder to maintain a healthy work/life balance.
There is a proper procedure that must be followed for every little thing. Everyone gets hung up on bureaucracy to the point where it severely limits your productivity.

Title: "Software Advisory"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Company is changing a lot, employees get new mac books, HR is changing, even the tools are all changing. We have adopted Workday, Travis, GitHub, JFrog, etc.  

New employees get decent market salary. 

It's flexible and lay back unless you're in a hot project.

If you work in emerging technologies with teams that are using latest tech then IBM is definitely a fun place to work at. Our leader is very flexible and allows us to build things from the ground up and use any technology necessary for our solutions. I often get to develop tools and products from end to end.  (Disclaimer: I've only experienced this with my current manager/director and team. Most people in IBM aren't as lucky to have a leader like mine) 

The company is trying hard to get new blood who are passionate and talented but it's hard to keep them with the package they offer and specially the salary. 

If you are a new parent or are expecting, IBM would be perfect to work at. Like I said, it's very flexible and lay back. Most people work from home on Fridays and leave early when ever they need to. 

 IBM is also great for new hires! Most new hires last 2 - 3 years.
Cons:
• Annual Bonus is nothing ($500 - $600 after tax)
• No stock options unless you are executive
• No annual increases even with excellent annual reviews (top performer)
• Hard to get a promotion unless you have a good manager that is respected and fights for you
• Some employees are really old school and outdated - they make it hard to innovate and work on new ideas. They are really outdated, some can't even code and aren't technical. It's really surprising that a  senior "technical" worker is not technical. Stay away from employees who have been in IBM for more than 6 years. A 10 year IBM employee is a huge red flag.
• Most employees lack drive and passion. They do the minimum. (hard to innovate)
• Not enough resources to kick off awesome projects
• POLITICS (specially from people who aren't technical and are all talk)
• I often feel like we develop demos and prototypes too often to make our managers, VPs and overall upper management happy and making them feel like we are doing awesome rather than focusing on building really good products. As long as the UI is beautiful, they don't seem to care.
• Managers and senior people always play the game... it's like if they have a play book. They don't try.

Cons:
>IBM is BIG, really BIG.  Which means that it can be like turning an ocean liner to get things done when what you need is nimble

Title: "Lots of instability"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: IBM encourages employee learning and development. Their Think40 program requires employees to log 40 hours/year in personal or professional development, and supports this requirement with a seemingly endless library of webinars on an array of topics. You can also log your own activities towards this goal (books, conferences, professional webinars, etc).
Cons: Joining IBM means becoming a small piece of a giant organization. As such, when IBM's financial situation becomes unfavorable, they will reduce costs, and an easy way to do so is to reduce headcount. Staff who are laid off receive 90 days’ notice and one-month severance pay, regardless of tenure. Client facing roles are not immune. Remaining staff are told to "lean in" and are left to pick up the pieces and take on additional workload.  Re: benefits, IBM's 401k contributions are made at year end, so if they eliminate staff during the year, they don't have to contribute as much money.

Title: "IT Analyst"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Ability to work from home
Cons: I worked in IBM Global Services whose only focus was on cost reduction that was done at the expense of their employees and their customers.  Experienced, knowledgeable, highly competent employees were laid-off and replaced with inexperienced resources from other countries.  As a result, productivity and the quality of work produced suffered.  In Global Services, the only thing that mattered was utilization, and it was not unusual to have quarterly utilization targets of 120%-130%.  Obviously, in order to meet those targets, especially if you had taken vacation or training time, significant, unpaid, overtime was required on a consistent weekly basis.  Employee raises were very infrequent and small.  Unsurprisingly, morale was very low.

Title: "Poor Leadership Not Customer Oriented"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Name Brand; Entry level Resources
Cons: Sr leaders get bonuses- mid level to entry level bonus minimal.  Yearly bonus last year for high performer was $321.  As a manager of high performing team I was allotted $218 to split between two resources.  Company does across the board furloughs for subKs at a moment's notice.  The only exception if an SLA will be missed.  If IBM misses a committed deliverable without penalty- so be it- they would rather do furloughs so they can meet their numbers.  Resources have not received raised in over 5 years.  Promises to next band level put on freeze and never revisited.

Title: "The Last Bastion of Corporate Bloat in an Agile World"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
* Excellent Paid Time Off policy, particularly for employees in Essential Operations roles.

* Exposure to a very broad array of technologies and systems.

* Progressive values and strong support for equality in and out of the workplace

* Looks good on a resume
Cons:
* Massive corporate bloat. The company has been around for well over 100 years, and it still runs like an old company, with numerous levels of management slowly drip-feeding decisions through a painfully dense bureaucratic process. IBM is slow to react, and when your primary competition are billion-dollar newcomers with better brand recognition, that's not a sustainable position.

* Over-reliance on archaic first-party software and systems. I get it, it looks bad if you sell your own email client but use someone else's, but maybe that's just a sign that Notes is a failed product and we should cut our losses and let Microsoft take the .01% market share we're occupying, because Outlook/Exchange is better at everything we set out to do. This applies to a number of areas of concern.

* Inadequate compensation. There's no getting around it: IBM pays below industry average in any given area, for any given skill level in any given field. Other benefits are pretty average for the industry, so the argument that they're making up for the low dollar figure in other ways doesn't hold up anymore. Career advancement within the technical side caps out really quickly, and the only way to continue your development is by going into management, which is far more stress than it's worth.

* Cultural dissonance. As IBM has made a number of acquisitions in recent years, it's failed to integrate the company cultures of those acquisitions into itself, particularly taking the good from them. Instead, it pushes a preexisting central IBM culture that isn't compatible with the way many of these smaller companies' employees are used to operating. As a result, these employees continue to see themselves as employees of other companies and not as part of IBM, and it creates an us-vs-them mentality in the organization as a whole.

* No clear plan. While we hear all the time about "strategic imperatives" and other buzzwords, the fact is, no plan seems to stay in place longer than a couple of quarters, and we're not gaining any ground against our ever-stronger competition. In fact, IBM is still on a negative growth trend. Everyone knows about Watson, but it's still not making us any money, so what's the plan?

* Self-congratulatory management. Various managers and executives are constantly sending out emails and lectures about how IBM is doing so great innovating in x field over y period of time, which while dubious is understandable. However, every other manager uses the opportunity to suck up to the exec in question. Call it corporate politics, but no manager is willing to tell his boss when they're wrong. It rolls downhill in a way I've never seen elsewhere.

* Ginni Rometty. I always say, anything that happens at a company can be blamed on the CEO. In IBM's case, we've had Ginni for the last 12 years, and of that time, just about half of it has been spent on a constant decline. All the while, Ginni waxes on about her strategic imperatives and how they're going to Make IBM Great Again. Prior to being the CEO, she worked in strategic outsourcing, and everyone who could tell her things she doesn't want to hear, which could help make decisions that would improve our standing, is well aware of that history. There are worse CEOs to work under, but don't expect Jeff Bezos or Satya Nadela.

Title: "Great benefits, work-life balance, but ..."

Pros: Good, stable income.  Great flexibility on work-life balance

Title: "Big company; opportunities await for those who look"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: There are opportunities to do nearly anything within IBM. I have personally be the beneficiary of many good managers and programs. Although my experience has been exceptional, I have seen other not be so fortunate.
Cons: Many managers are removed from their reports and are only focused on utilization. It is a big company and is easy to get lost / challenging to find the right place. Bonuses are a joke; pay bumps are fair, but you won't be getting rich.

Title: "Got Lucky with a Great Team and Non-Legacy Product"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
At the time of my employment, IBM was providing a 3-month bootcamp for new hires, where they essentially walk you through how to design for an enterprise company. I felt extremely fortunate to have started my professional career with this program, as it taught you how to collaborate, organize, present, and execute outside of a college context. 

IBM's Design program also cares deeply about company culture, and hire people that I found to be some of the best to work with in my professional career. They understand that the ability to collaborate is far more important than talent alone.

Additionally, I found extensive room to grow during my career at IBM. My boss allowed us to create our own programs, such as "learning sessions" to learn, for example, Github from our front end dev, and attend conferences. Teammates who stayed on after I left were also promoted to leads to reward their growth and contributions. If you find the right team within the company, the opportunities were invaluable.
Cons: Retention. Unfortunately, the structure of this bootcamp led to lofty expectations of work environments outside of the Austin office. I gave such a high rating because I personally was very fortunate to be part of a great product we have a lot of personal control in, and saw through from research to launch. However, it really comes down to the team and the office location. The design program is large, and every experience I've heard has varied greatly, along with how long they stayed on at IBM.

Title: "Good amount of responsibility; difficult to move around projects"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I was based entirely in Washington, DC, so never traveled. This review is not for public sector consulting, which seems pretty different from private sector. I was given a good amount of responsibility pretty early in my career. Managers were always very supportive of me and were reasonable about deadlines. Since it's a large company, there were regular discussions about my career trajectory and options for growth within the company. Benefits were excellent, with many low fee index funds offered in the 401k. There were lots of happy hours and networking opportunities. I never worked more than 40-45 hours per week.
Cons: I was in the Public Sector Consulting division, and it was basically impossible to move form one project to another. It didn't really feel like "consulting", more like you were IT support for government agencies for certain types of business software. Most of the projects were very long term.

Title: "Worked on two teams, had two very different experiences."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM  for more than 3 years
Pros:
- Mobility within the company, and the culture to encourages it.  I worked for 1.5 years on one team and then moved to another for another 1.5 years that was under different leadership.
- Excitement of being at Watson post-Jeopardy when it transitioned from a research effort to an entire product group.
- First team situated in the Watson CTO org was in a special projects group that valued innovation, attempted to cultivate an edgier company culture.  
- Second team situated closer to Watson research efforts also had exciting projects, provided great mentoring, helped me improve greatly as an engineer.   Fantastic work/life balance, set your own hours etc.
- Paternity leave was adequate.
Cons:
- No to very little in the way of bonuses each year.
- Difficult to move up in the org.  Manager wanted to give me a band adjustment, but wasn't allowed to do it for anyone.
- First team I worked on had a director, who was overly demanding, disliked in the org, manipulative, disqualified for the job technically / creatively, would frequently ask in the morning what you'd accomplished last night and encouraged working through the weekends--a nasty flip-side of a company trying to change its culture.  This director was eventually shutdown, but only after years of bad behavior.
- Second team was frequently moving from project to project, and not linked to efforts that brought a lot of value.  Manager barely managed, and was focused more on his own research and credibility as an academic, than the wellbeing of his team.  He also didn't have many friends in the org.  This team was remote and in my year and half there, the company only flew me out once for the initial interview.  The second time I went at my own expense, since my family was visiting a friend in the city.  Typical of IBM having very constrained budgets for travel.

Title: "Warning: Do your research before you join this company"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: The people you work with are smart and amazing. I will miss them.
Cons: Google IBM age discrimination and Pro Publica, and you'll get a good idea of the state of IBM these days. And even negative exposure doesn't stop this forward movement to chop old heads. Someday the younger folks will be older too - and will you dispense of them too at that point?  Integrity is a value fast disappearing at IBM.  Corporate America is not generally great anyways, but IBM is really over the top. Do your research and think carefully before you join. Check out lawsuits and the EEOC investigation.

Title: "IBM Sales and Technical Sales - Great people, Challenging company"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Great people, large network of smart professionals across sales, marketing, product, development labs, services.  Great customers that respect IBM's historical business stature,
Cons:
- Used to be a a company where you could re-invent yourself, switch jobs and develop yourself into completely new careers, across divisions and in new roles
- Benefits program has become less attractive and less generous over time
- Layoffs are pervasive and really mostly based on being in the wrong place at the wrong time, with many outstanding individuals layed off with 1 month severance regardless of years served
- Great, truly awesome people leaving on their own terms because job security and cultural toxicity has exceeded acceptable levels
- Product line has been mis-managed and is no longer competitive, with rare exceptions in some parts of Systems, Security, Watson, Analytics, Hybrid-cloud and Process Automation portfolios.
- While immediate team members and in many cases immediate managers are great, truly top-notch professionals, there is so much outside of our control and outside of our 1st/2nd line managers' control, that the culture feels toxic in many ways
- Used to be a great place to work and cultivate a career.  Used to have job security.  Use to be a place worth recruiting great people into.  This is no longer the case.
- Even if IBM is able to return to sustainable profitability and growth, the IBM professional family culture that was a big reason to stay has been lost, most likely forever.
- Even if your management and executive chain believes in you, your client loves you, you have a stellar reputation and strong consistent results, no one is safe from an unexpected layoff.

Title: "IBM services division is not a great place to be noticed"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
- Travel (if you like that)
- If you are skilled and well known in certain circles, there are many interesting projects to choose from
- Good benefits
Cons:
- Travel (if you don't like that)
- If you're new or tend to keep to yourself, you may end up on projects that are uninteresting or failing
- You are a cog and with the matrix management system you don't always get noticed outside of your immediate project. 
- You are not always rewarded by how good your performance is on a particular project.  For instance, on a well run project with a good team, you may not require a lot of overtime.  Since billable hours are what gets noticed, a poor performer on a bad project might bill 70 hours per week and therefore get rewarded over you at the end of the year.
- Difficult and time consuming to get promotions

Title: "You are just a number"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Good for an early career person to get experience if they are willing to work long hours.
Cons: No loyalty or personal development for employees. So many experienced (aka older) employees were let go in the last few years, the people left (mostly early career) do not understand what is needed to plan and execute on marketing programs.  There is no work from home, work/life balance (expected to answer your phone at ALL hours), retirement (minimal and only if you are employed on the last day of the year) or mentors (they were laid off) anymore.  Open space seating makes it difficult to concentrate or talk on the phone.  Bring your own phone for company calls,  IBM doesn't supply you (or reimburse you) with an office phone. No privacy.  Morale is very low.

Title: "Co-workers were awesome but the place tried to take my soul"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Co-workers were high caliber, got to learn a lot
Cons: Management is out of touch, they lead you on, if you are not sales then you are unimportant.  R&D not respected.  Especially if you are QA. Every release they play the blame game. If a bug gets out then they flay QA, even though team leads reiterate that the product is not ready and needs more time. They do not listen.  Everyone they hire into Watson Health is led to believe they will work with Watson but the closest they get is using Watson's search algorithm.   Bonuses are nonexistent.  Good people leave and are not replaced which facilitates other attrition, stress, and teams that are too lean.  The first few months I was there no one knew what to do with me and I'd sit idle too much, which I hate.  There is no spare computer. If your hard drive goes, too bad, you have to send it somewhere and wait.  Yeah.  Also, sometimes your IP gets locked out for the day if you're on campus at RTP so you have to go home to work.   I could go on but I think this is enough, when coupled to the fact that I went on a week's vacation, got back to discover that the whole wing of seats behind me (big open agile space) was empty when I returned. Yep, let go...

Title: "My experience at IBM was one of constant change."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Learning possibilities are endless, internal networking was phenomenal, and accessibility to anyone at any level was unlike any other organization I had worked for previously.
Cons: A constant , nervous feeling that there was no ground beneath your feet due to the constant disruptions, transformations, and restructuring. The move from a being a largely telecommuting company back to bricks and mortar is one such painful example where lives were disrupted. I wasn't around for it, but I lived through other disruptions.  The move back to offices must have been horrific for many. While at IBM, many were prepping for the eventual day that they that they are told you are being 'resourced' - that's IBMese for you're laid off. How does one stay productive and focused in such an environment?

Title: "Consulting by Degree - Waste of time"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
Chance to interact with senior executives 
Being part of a big technological movement e.i Blockchain 
Great work and life balance 
Big company, thus it's possible (but hard) to find your own space/voice 
Compensation jump from a consultant to senior consultant is great
Cons:
Often you get assigned to a projects before SOWs are signed and they can take up months to get signed, thus might end up on bench for several weeks or even months
CbD program needs massive improvement, as CbDers we get three managers and all of them are useless 
It's hard to find people to vouch for you
Managers expect you to do work without a code
Some projects are waste of time, chances of it moving from POC or MVP to Pilot can be low 
Not a lot of project on the pipeline

Title: "Stay far far away! Toxic culture, lack of accountability, no company direction."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Higher level positions supposedly pay very well, but I was not exposed to that.
Cons: The corporate culture isn't just toxic, it's nonexistent. At IBM, you are expected to put your head down and do your work, there is no collaboration. I received next to no training, and was expected to succeed immediately. If you don't, it's your own fault. I was a part of the Watson Health business unit, which is a total sinking ship. As many progressive companies move towards flexible work environments, IBM is moving further from it. In my 9 months in this position, I never once had any type of 1:1 or coaching from my manager to discuss performance, much less career goals. There is constant turnover for all of the aforementioned reasons, and as such, I had 4 different managers in my 9 month tenure. I can not stress enough, stay far far away. I regret to even give IBM 1 star.

Title: "Still can't believe how bad"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: Good stepping stone to a different job. Experience working directly with engineers and a variety of different job roles as a designer. Good practice advocating for users to people who aren't used to thinking about them.
Cons: Where to begin. For one thing, IBM is letting middle management is drive it into the ground. Every step forward taken by very talented engineers and designers is eventually ruined by a complete lack of vision, strategy, and alignment by an unbelievably bloated middle management layer. Marketing teams are allowed to set product strategy based on questionable "market research" and also promises product capabilities to the public that are completely unrealistic (e.g. Watson for Oncology). It borders on unethical at times. There is no money for raises and promotions - unclearness and even dishonesty about this is rampant. There is zero transparency, and absolutely no engagement from HR to support individual employees. Every few months hundreds of employees are "RA'd" ("Resource Action," which = layoff).

Title: "Avoid"

Title: "A big ship that's not going anywhere"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
- Flexible work schedule
- Good healthcare benefits
- Some very competent people who are fun to work with
- Early career advancement can happen fairly rapidly if you are remotely competent
Cons:
- Fire drills every other day, including on weekends sometimes. Most are unnecessary and completely avoidable
- Org changes and product direction changes every 3-6months, making it impossible to deliver anything worthwhile
- Leadership micromanages to the extreme with CEO calling out product direction without any sort of due diligence. Lots of failed initiatives as a result of this.
- No clear roles and responsibilities. Result is everyone is talking and everyone thinks they are right. No one makes a final decision. I.e. ton of talking with no resulting worthwhile actions. Specifically this manifests in workshops being held every other week with 95% of them being a total waste of time, feedback falling on deaf ears, and the same organizational and product issues persisting forever.
- Vast majority of leadership is incompetent. They lack knowledge about the market, about running a modern day digital operation, and about running a financially sound business. The number of useless efforts and the resulting waste of capital is appalling.
- Turnover is massive. It is not uncommon to hear about 25-50% of teams leaving in a period of months. 
- Guidance and enablement from manager was non-existent. "You get to go figure it out" is not valid advice when someone has specifically reached out to you for help after trying various tactics on their own.  
- Career growth is unstructured, unfair, and not transparent. After having delivered the biggest project on the product team that had previously been to the graveyard several times before I picked it up, I saw someone who had delivered the most insignificant projects promoted to a key leadership position and then I had to convince the management of my worth over a period of 1 yr to get my promotion. After that advice on career growth included gems such as "you need to think about how to expand your scope". The proposals I came up with were met with suggestions of manipulating teams  or people to roll their scope into mine. It seemed after a certain level, advancement equalled duping people into giving up leadership of their scope and handing it to you.
- Manipulative, deceptive, rude culture.   
- Pay is lower compared to competitors.
- Communication and soft skills are largely lacking. Tech skills are generally there at least.

Bottom line - If getting stuff done that has an impact on the business in a civil way is important to you, this is not the right place for you. If you are looking for a decent pay check and don't mind being manipulative, being accosted by  co-workers, and spinning your wheels to no avail, it's not a bad place to be.

Title: "Great colleagues and opportunities, challenging priorities and workload"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: Over the many years I worked for IBM, no matter what the job, my colleagues were always top-notch.  Great people to work alongside, dedicated, innovative, highly-skilled and resilient.  The opportunities I had the pleasure of working on were tremendous, and while challenging the work was typically interesting. If you had a management chain with the ear of their executive, a lot of good could happen.
Cons: In recent years, there was an unfortunate constant drumbeat of resource actions and mixed priorities which continued to pile work on those that remained, and without a laser focus and necessary support needed for success. Work was typically reactionary, and overtime was significant.

Title: "A Paradox of good and bad.  Old Blue vs New Blue."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- Many co-workers very smart, some of the best I've worked with, though seems the newer hires are more talented than some of the old timers (many of the high performing old timers left)
- High level of professionalism and willingness to help.  Sense of "team".
- Pushing the boundaries of innovation and what's achievable
- Large multinational Research organization to collaborate with
- Frequent communications from Leadership and general understanding of business unit's direction, even despite it's size and breadth
- Great online learning resources for Agile, Project Management, Coding, etc
- Some great processes, strategies
Cons:
- Bureaucracy and unnecessary complexity on par with the Federal government, yet trying to move fast and be agile like a startup, creates ALOT of friction when you're handed an aggressive deadline and yet are mired in procedures and compliance documentation.  You're pushed to run the 1,000 yard dash wearing concrete shoes.
- Hard to tell "what is real"; feeling that about half of any tech they espouse is real, half is marketing exaggeration or forward-looking hopes.  Lots of internal and external "marketing" / spin about how great IBM is and how great they are to work for, etc. 
- Feeling that the "corporation" doesn't care about you, nor has long-term commitment to you, even for the top performers.  IBM has a reputation for trying new business units for 3-5 years, and if they aren't profitable, shut them down.  This implied threat always seems to circle in the background when deadlines (often unrealistic) are missed, etc.  Feeling that in a few years you will need to find a new role (many "float" around IBM).  Also I have seen more people fired here (Product/Offering Managers) than any other company I've worked for, by far.  And not timed with layoffs or anything - just direct terminations.
- Salaries good, but all else cheap - below standard travel stipend, very little / no bonus, new computer only every 4-5 years.  STILL use Lotus Notes / Domino-based webmail, which results in calendar errors and missed meetings, etc.
- Note, many of these reviews are from international employees, which may have a very different perspective.  Many services (HR, IT helpdesk, procurement) are based in India and can be difficult to communicate with.
- Very aggressive goals, deadlines etc, apparently to make up for lost time / "navel gazing" in past, and now facing v. fast moving competitors (Amazon, Google, etc)

Title: "Essentially a contracting company"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Even tho I was with the company for nearly 20 years before retiring, it always seemed like any day could be your last.  I can't think of much good to say. They have a 401k program like most, but did away with their pension plan which provided very little.  They have a mental health program, primarily because they need it for their stressed out employees.
Cons: You have a choice, work at least 1980 hours per year (if US based) by giving up your vacation & other time off or take your time off and work overtime to make up the difference.  Every employee is measured on that.  It used to be in the reviews before someone sued them. It's all about sales... sometimes it's revenue and sometimes its GP, but it's always something and it's always about the quarter and Wall Street.  They can never get away from utilization because it would impact their share price too much.

Title: "IBM Sales"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- IBM gives mobile employees incredible freedom to work from home or from an IBM office 
- IBM generally pays fairly well, but most IBMers are on a leveraged sales quota plan that can vary widely depending on sales success. 
- If you enjoy travel, IBM offers plenty of opportunity to travel.
- IBM provides employees with many options for devices: Apple products - including MacBooks, iPhones & iPads; Lenovo laptops, and B.Y.O.D. options for phone. 
- IBM places a high value on mentoring; there are opportunities to get involved with formal mentor programs and IBMers tend to be very open to "unofficial" mentoring relationships for those seeking advice/guidance in their career
Cons:
- IBM is a highly sales-driven organization and pressure from the top-down has created an ultra-competitive environment that sometimes feels like "everyone for themselves." 
- Job security isn't super strong: Re-organizations and realignments are commonplace and "resource actions" (aka - down sizing) are not uncommon either.
- IBM talks a lot about "career mobility," but doesn't always "practice what they preach."

Title: "sinking ship"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: Still has a good reputation, not a bad place to spend 2-3 years early in one's career for resume padding, but plan and execute your exit strategy accordingly.
Cons: A sinking ship, your salary will quickly fall behind the market, you'll be treated as a faceless and interchangeable unit of production, you will not see any sort of correlation between great work and rewards, the 10 or so levels of management between the CEO and you are reflected in every manager requesting a pointless 0-value-added-to-the-customer report from someone below him which percolates all the way down to rank and file employees having to waste large amounts of time in bureaucracy, made the worse by various execs justifying their positions by starting various initiatives that overlap and are at odds with each other and lead to even more wasted time.  So does the B in IBM stand for Bureaucracy?  Yes, but also the IB of IBM also stands for India-Based, as more and more positions are shifted there, yet the company still allocates way too few resources to be serious about anything it does and to do anything more than a half-baked job....who wants to work in such a demoralizing environment.

Title: "Good Place to Start and Learn but not a Great Place to Stay Long-Term"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Good place to get your start and learn about technology.   You will get to understand the dynamics of different business models(i.e. SaaS/PaaS/Hardware/On-Prem Software) and learn about new technologies (i.e. blockchain, AI, Quantum).   Option to work from home which lets you avoid the commute.
Cons: Compensation is below market; my base pay was comparable to average pay according to Glassdoor but the bonus was basically non-existent.  I literally got ~$700 after tax for the bonus!   Many underfunded products/projects and long lead times to get things done lead to subpar products that aren't competitive.  No ability to retain good talent; see good people who can leave defect to other tech companies (i.e. Google, Microsoft, Salesforce, Startups, etc.) all the time.  Lack of opportunity to grow in the company.  Since IBM is shrinking, there are almost no attractive opportunities to switch roles and get promoted.   IBM is getting it's butt kicked by Google, Amazon, and Microsoft in IaaS/SaaS/PaaS and AI and it is unlikely IBM will be able to reverse this market trend anytime soon.  Senior Management is too secure in their positions.  IBM has underperformed vs. peers for a decade yet most of the Senior Management team have retained their positions.

Cons: Since it is so big there can be a lot of chaotic confusion when it comes to structure. Everybody's experience is completely different because of the lack of structure. I have seen some great, smart, capable people get treated poorly and end up leaving because of timing and luck.  A lot of the people at the top could sometimes care less about the people below and are clearly very much in it for themselves. Because of this, the culture is terrible, however, I did feel a sense togetherness with people of my age group as I feel we are had mutual feelings about the company.

WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: State of the art in every respect. Be prepared to work. Be prepared to make IBM an extension of your family, because you will be expected to give it all you've got (and that can often mean work flowing into your time off - like weekends).
Cons: Sometimes long-term IBM employees can be a tad condescending. I guess that is an occupational hazard when you work for a large corporation, though. Keeping any negative thoughts you may have about individuals to yourself can help you in navigating "office politics." As  said: occupational hazard in a big corporation. IBM is no exception. But if you resolve to do a good job (and are good at "handling" people and their idiosyncrasies) IBM is a company with many paths for advancement.

Title: "Toxic Environment. Bad Products. Don’t Waste Your Time Here"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: It’s a job.  Better than being unemployed.  Sort of.
Cons:
Worked in Sales for 10 years.  It used to be great.  Some of the best products in the market , great culture, etc.  It’s now deteriorated into a toxic culture , employees are miserable , the company that once cared about its people now could not care less about them.   If you are older worker you’ll be pushed out the door soon enough.  But younger workers as your replacement ? They only last a couple years because it’s a terrible place to work 

As a Sales Rep you can be only as good as your products and they have let their products go to crap and aren’t even recognized as remote contenders in most areas because they are so outdated and bad. 

I had to leave because the toxic and stressful culture became too much to bear any longer.  

Company is lost.  Pushing best people out the door while Mgt remains stale and useless .

Treats complex software sales like hardware deals.   
Territories and managers constantly in flux with unreasonable quota.
Layoffs every 2 to 3 months so no one feels safe, and if you don't hit your number for the first 6 months, you're a target for the rest of the year.  
Competing products that do the same thing and sales reps that compete / share the same territory with overlap in product set.
Products not selling and not updated since acquisitions.
No clear strategy for the future
Partnership at IBM = Buy something from IBM, not partner
Product strategy derived from what a customer will pay for, not from what the broader market needs.
