Title: "Short-sighted company does not value its employees"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The pay is not bad, nor are the benefits. IBM does not tolerate any form of discrimination or harassment at the workplace. For the most part, my first-line managers have been people-oriented and tried to look after their employees. The company works on a wide variety of things, and it is sometimes possible to move around to different areas if you want to try something new.
Cons:
Working at IBM is something like an eternal game of Russian roulette, except with layoffs instead of bullets. I survived the layoffs for almost 20 years, but eventually my luck ran out (despite never receiving a bad rating). I am still with the company as of now, but my last day will be in the next 3 months. I have seen this happen to very talented employees many times during my years at the company. The layoffs are often determined by what project you happen to be working on at the time that the layoffs are done, rather than being determined by your skills or value to the company. 

Up until recently, IBM was very good about giving employees the flexibility to work from home or even to work purely remotely from other cities. Recently it was announced that this policy had ended and all employees were expected to be on site for all working hours. For some employees, there was no local IBM office where they could work. Those employees were told they would have to relocate closer to an IBM office or they would not be able to stay with the company. This was another case where very talented employees were essentially forced out of the company.

For the past 10-15 years, it seems like the company tries to reinvent itself and entirely change directions every couple of years. But IBM never sees any of these strategies through. It tries them briefly, and if they do not pay immediate dividends, something new is attempted. On top of this, IBM has had a habit of always being late to the party. Only once cloud computing was well-established by IBM competitors did IBM start trying to get into the market, for example. It is very frustrating as a worker to feel like the company has no real direction or sense of strategy.

It also often feels like the executives making the strategy decisions are too far removed from the reality of the business. IBM has many layers of management between the regular employees and the executives that make the decisions.

Finally, and I imagine this is probably true of many large corporations, IBM treats its employees in a very schizophrenic manner. When a project is behind schedule or high priority, IBM management tells its employees that we are a family, a team, and we all should pull together, work extra hours, go the extra mile, etc, to see the project to completion. However, when IBM decides that they need to cut costs, they'll have one of their frequent layoffs (except they will only refer to them as "resource actions", the same way downsizing to them is "right-sizing"). And when the layoffs happen IBM management makes it clear that this is a business and these things happen. Wait, what happened to being a team and a family?

Title: "Emphatic YES to IBM as LGBT employer with top honors!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Being an LGBT employee is something that you can rely on the backing of colleagues and the company's leadership at IBM. There truly are things we do that make this a top notch company to work for as an LGBT employee. As we focus this year on getting people to be more visibly allies to us all, we see more and more focus on building relationships with our colleagues based more on understanding and less blind acceptance so it feels more "legit" to me to know that people know how to be a good ally and they still want to do it... meaning they have an interest in what's going on in my life and not just that they don't care about what goes on in my life. I have had colleagues talk to me about "how does it make you feel when..." especially now with all the divisiveness perpetrated in my home state... that makes me feel good about my choice of employer.
Cons: Sometimes it can be difficult when IBM goes through points in time when it searches for it's changing place in the world... but I know all companies who grow to a certain size and are around for a long time go through it... it doesn't mean it's not tough some times to feel stress or feel all the things that go along with these changes, but it's certainly at the same time something that makes you evaluate your choices differently.

Title: "Best company for LGBT+"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: As a straight ally of IBM's LGBT+ community, I can share that we do a lot together to recognize and celebrate diversity on all levels.  IBM has a global policy to cover health costs associated with gender affirmation, offers benefits in many countries to same-sex spouses and domestic partners, and offers many programs specifically tailored to LGBT+ just as personal financial planning.
Cons: I have no cons to offer.

Title: "Best employer for LGBT+ employees"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Being out at work as lesbian enabled me to experience helping launch an internal startup -- a business development team dedicated to the LGBT+ B2B market. My management also supported my 6-month assignment in India with my wife, accompanying me, even though homosexual activity is illegal in India; it said that it couldn't get me out of jail if I were jailed due to the country's laws, but that Pat & I could be fully out as a couple within IBM's four walls; we were and local management and colleagues all were lovely to and inclusive of us. My U.S. management also sponsored my Master's at Columbia while I worked full-time. All this while being able to mentor and be mentored by amazing LGBT+ colleagues and allies!
Cons: Join an investment bank, rather than IBM, if you want to be wildly wealthy, but you can earn a healthy living here.

Title: "Great Company with Awesome benefits"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Great benefit package for LGBT+.  Great programs specifically for minority groups: Women, LGBT, Minority Men, etc. to help advance your career in a white male dominated culture.
Cons: Working long hours is pretty typical

Title: "So many great, smart people"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Very bright and driven colleagues
Welcoming of all types of people -- a model of LGBT+ inclusion
A great opportunity to work with people from all over the world
Cons: Sometimes it's so big it can be difficult to get traction

Title: "Challenging but rewarding work"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
IBM is a company which takes its 100 year progressive history seriously.  Meeting with your boss and our executives on a regular basis to discuss your career track is mandatory and professional training is mandatory as well. We strongly encourage mentor relationships and peer mentoring. Senior management is available for shadowing for a day, one on one meetings and mentoring.  Our commitment to  LGBTQ issues came on display as IBM joined other tech companies in sending a letter to North Carolina Governor McCrory urging he repeal H.B. 2 in 2016.  We were so proud of our commitment to diversity over the decades we took our entire department to watch "Hidden Figures" to see some early IBM involvement in the civil rights era. We are also proud to have Ginni Rometty as the only female CEO in the DowJones30, and the third female member at Augusta National Golf Club home of the Master's Tournament. 

I work in an analytics department where we come up with Cognitive solutions to business problems.  Our team is incredibly talented and intelligent, but not aloof. Everyone teaches each other on the job, and our ability to tackle data issues has enormously evolved. I love working on an international team with over 10 spoken languages and which hails from 12 different countries. 

We have moved into an "agile" space, no more cubes for us in the last 18 months.  Our team likes the open environment, easy access to windows and standing desks. Getting a conference room is fairly easy when needed.

Summer time is pure  energy as our team of 80 adds 25 interns, most of our social activities occur over the summer as we attempt to recruit future team members.

The team also balances work/life. Most of the younger team members live in NYC and car pool, so they work 8-5 and occasionally log on after hours and working weekends is nearly unheard of, that's your time.   We tend to be a social group, we have a potluck lunch every 2 months which is always well attended. After hours have a drinking club in NYC that finds unusual places to eat in NY. We have a softball team, a soccer team, and a trivia team that all meet weekly. We host a service day and a golf outing each once a year, and bowling 2-3 times over the summer.  We also have a "What's App" group to go out to see movies.
Cons: We discourage work at home, so our team is always in the office M-Thursday, during the summer we've been more lenient on working from home or working from alternative IBM locations in NYC.  Our location is just north of White Plains NY, this is about a 60-80min trip for our NYC members. Get to the office before 9:30am or parking starts to get tight.

Cons:
IBM has longstanding internal practices of extremely poor ethical behavior.  These unethical practices are commonly known outside the company.  

Evidence in just one of many examples can be found from Technology CEO's and news agencies commentary in the book entitled:  "The Decline and Fall of IBM: End of an American Icon?"  

An internet search on topics such as "IBM employee Morale" or Forbes and CNBC documentary regarding routine, quarterly layoff's to maintain Earnings Per Share are just tip-of-the-ice burg samples of evidence showing how a wonderful company has been driven into the ground thru longstanding, ingrained greed and arrogance that has desensitized the conscience of decision makers.  This has led the proliferation of unethical behavior to the point it is now deeply embedded in IBM's corporate culture.

Title: "Focus on cost reduction"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
1. Good work life balance.
2.  Even though IBM is  considered an old tech company, it is investing a lot of money on new areas.  Even if the new initiatives in AI, Watson, Blockchain do not turn into success stories, you can get hands on experience in them.
Cons:
1. Layers on layers of management.  Nightmare for any kind of change management activity.  Leadership understands this, but they tend to respond by adding separate management chains to cut through the original bureaucracy.   And of course, this ends up adding more confusion.  
2. Very margin driven company.  With declining revenues, they continue to focus on cutting more costs, instead of finding ways to maybe invest and grow.  The management layers sit secure, the cost cutting affects the lower level employees.  Promotions get delayed, frequent hiring freezes etc.  New divisions like Watson get investments, the rest of the company is get cut to the bone, resulting in declining employee morale.

Title: "Watson IOT"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
A paycheck
Medical benefits which are on par with most other places quite frankly.
401k match - although only at the end of the year. You leave before, you get nothing.
Cons: Awful company to work for. I was in one of the supposed strategic imperative areas. Watson IOT but its all a sham. Smoke and mirrors. People work hard but its over shadowed by terrible management that don't have a clue what they are doing. Constant fire drills reacting to the competition. Each quarter there is constant layoffs. Lately they told everyone that was working at home to return or relocate to a bunch of bland offices scattered around the USA in areas you wouldn't want to live. I got out and found another job. I suggest you do the same if you are still there. With declining revenue each quarter the only way ibm can maintain any EPS is share buy backs and resource actions. Don't even think about ibm as a place to work even if you are desperate.

Title: "Unrealistic sales driven deadlines, ridiculous bureaucracy, and general disinterest from management"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
- In the past there has been a liberal work from home policy. I'm not sure how much longer that will last. 
- The company 401k matching contribution is good and is fully vested from the start.
Cons:
- Multiple (one or more) layoffs per year every year I was at the company (almost 10 years). 
- Terrible or none existent bonuses. 
- Management mostly concerned with how to preserve and progress their careers and has little interest in progressing staff careers. 
- Software engineering organization driven by rigid sales motivated deadlines with little consideration for sound software development practices.  This creates substandard software services that are unmaintainable. But Sales doesn't care and engineering management team is too afraid to push back. 
- Bluemix IS an awful mess and any product or service that has to integrate with it WILL be made worse by having to integrate and adhere to the terrible bureaucracy that exists within it.

Cons: I survived almost a constant threat of layoffs in 2016.  I decided that I would not do that again in 2017.   IBM is a financial company, it is only in business to make money.  If you can improve revenues, cut costs, or innovate with very few resources, you are valuable.  If you are here for any other reason, then you will not last long.

Title: "Enjoy culture more than actual job"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: A lot of the people are great. You learn a lot very quickly because there isn't too much training. Very flexible schedule which is fantastic.
Cons: Not as much structure as I was used to. Felt like my job was unnecessary at times and had to find/make my own work and carve out my own role. Not a lot of room for growth. Morale is pretty low right now in marketing because of executive decision to co-locate. We're losing a lot of good talent to competitors. It's extremely difficult to get things done or be innovative at a company this size. Bonuses have been terrible.

Title: "It's not our father's IBM"

Cons: IBM seems to regard employees as they approach retirement as disposable. I had 2 opportunities of managers that wanted to transfer me into their dept and both times were denied by executive levels and / or HR. After 30+ years it's sad to say IBM no longer cares for their loyal and highly productive employees as they are nearing retirement

Title: "There was a time when IBM was considered the best of the best... unfortunately those days are gone."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Great reputation. Recruiters seem to be impressed when they see "IBM" on a resume
Cons: In today’s IBM, many employees are just keeping their heads down trying to avoid a layoff (resource action) before completing their successful job search or vesting of their health and retirement benefits. IBM has a substantial morale and leadership problem.  Each quarter brings another round of layoffs, divestitures, reorganizations or broken promises. This dark cloud of uncertainty impairs our vision to imagine the possible; our ability to innovate; and our focus on clients. The result is that the average IBMer believes that they could be terminated regardless of their individual performance, skills, and contributions.

Title: "Great colleagues, not so great managment"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Depending on your role (if you are client facing) you have the chance to travel and work with some of the best folks in the industry.  Great benefits, PTO/Vacation, work/life balance.
Cons: Depending on the manager  you have, you will be successful. You can end up on the bench once a project is done, and if your manager is "in your corner" you will end up sitting there for a while. It's not a good place to be. If you have a manager who is truly invested in their team, they will put you forth to work on client openings. Additionally, they are pulling folks back who worked remotely. This is completely up ending a lot of good people. They don't give you much of a choice if you are not located near one of the designated cities, you either move, try to get an exception or it's "thanks, but you're being resourced" does not matter if you have been there 5yrs, 10yrs or 20yrs. And, it's worth mentioning,  external training, certifications, etc is rarely paid for.

Title: "Designers, do not work here."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
It pays you. 

Some nice people to work with.
Cons:
If you are experienced but less than 10+ years, they will low ball your salary miserably. I saw people who joined with 2 or 3 years of experience got paid the same as college graduates and taking 3 months Design Bootcamp with folks with zero experience.

Your base pay is basically what you all get. Also, the base pay is slightly below the market average. Do not expect any perks, stocks, or cash bonuses. You won't get any. 

You will not be able to grow. Most of seniors, design leads are not capable of handling projects, mentoring juniors, proper design skills to be a lead. Managers will gossip about your colleagues during your 1 on 1.  True story.

There is no promotion and raises. This makes the morale incredibly low and encourages people to play politics and nepotism. This is place is so polluted, your skills, knowledge and capabilities will not matter. It is all about who you know. 

Most projects in IBM are very technical. Actually there is not much space for designers to play in and create a significant impact. But company is keep hiring designers to use them as a marketing tools to keep the stock price up. 

Most new grads will leave after a year. They lose so many people annually, therefore, always hiring people with a very very low bar. You should not be proud for getting an offer from this company. 

IBM Design Thinking is a joke. Nobody in the company other than IBM Design cares. You will never ever have a chance to practice what you been through from bootcamp for three months, which is totally waste of time.

Project keep gets postponed. You will never ship anything. Even if it gets shipped, developers will basically ignore your design and code whatever they want. So you won’t be able to show your work anywhere. 

Company is suffering 20+ quarters revenue decline. It is obviously failing and barely living up by past reputation. Once you are in, they will try to brainwash you hard about how great IBM is. In reality, nobody cares.

Management rules employees with fear. Blame game is constant.

Title: "IBM design is nothing more than lumpy mashed potatoes"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: There are many smart people that work here. The designers can really push themselves on challenging domains and products.
Cons:
Every business organization is inconsistent on everything. There are many that follow IBM design thinking and others that don’t. Teams struggle to releases any product or any type of software. Which leads to a lot of designers hopping to new teams to find something better. I have seen design teams cut and the project moved to development (great way for a company being “design focus”).
 
I will only speak to what team I was on. The management is all over the place. My team went through three design leads in less than a year and a half. Our Program Director didn’t know how to deal with any of the problems in our business platform/team so they would just move people around never addressing the problem.
 
You could see how overwhelmed and inexperienced some of the design leads were. One in general couldn’t lead the team and placed most of the responsibility on other team members. If you didn’t meet demands we were blamed for failure or even an ultimatum to stay or move teams. When asked what they did they would respond with “going to meetings.” With little to no directions, you scrounged for work. If you didn’t know what you should be doing or asked what you could do you got nothing more than “You should know.”
 
There were no check-ins and the design lead assumed you were taking advantage of them. There are goals and performance system but the lead didn’t effectively use or acknowledge it until it was too late for the designer. Most of the designers left the team for new teams and some tried to stick it out in hope it would get better. Program Director should have intervened but never solved the problem but switched old designers with industry designers (A few months later everyone was moved off and development are performing design).
 
The culture at IBM design can be summed up as everyone's out for themselves and less than teams. It is my observation employees work in secret not sharing their work. If you didn’t have a loud voice or opinions, you were cut down or see as weak. How do you grow at IBM? It’s hard with a culture where you are viewed as weak. Then you are pushed out.

Title: "Self Sufficiency is key"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Great Pay and Benefits. Really smart co-workers. Good Work/Life balance by way of Remote Work option. Opportunity to move around within the company and experience different positions.
Cons: IBM stands for I've Been Moved or I'm By Myself. Manager changes every 12 months. Sales coverage (territory) changes every 12 months. People come and go in your ecosystem rapidly so it is hard to develop long term working relationships. Mentor(s)  will change as people leave. A lot of layoffs have affected morale. Sometimes you get a manager or find a mentor that will help you think through how to grow your career. Sometimes it seems like no one cares about you and your growth. I felt like every time I got a new manager or territory, I would have to start over again to develop my reputation as a high performer.  Most of the time, I suffered from new guy syndrome. A tenured rep was laid off for a low performing territory and IBM would give me the crap territory and 12 months to turn it around. Hard to make a lot happen in a short amount of time. My colleagues told me not to be so hard on myself. If a tenured rep couldn't make the territory perform, there was not a lot more that I, the new guy, could do.  But I tried my damnest, and after 4 or 5 restarts with new territories, IBM finally gave up on me.

Title: "The 'M' stands for 'Meh'"

Pros: Mostly nice people. Super flex work locations (as long as you're not in a "co-lo" unit). Interesting bits of tech are being worked on sporadically here and there. Easy to lay low and float under the radar for a long time, if that's your game.
Cons: The burden of process. Bennies have been cut to the bone - so your health insurance is probably much more expensive than you are expecting. In most offices they even charge you for coffee. Lots and lots of dead weight that adds complexity to processes merely to justify their own existence.

Title: "Software Enginerring"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Job contains lots of tools and peer help to get you going and you can rely on.

Title: "Bad Experience"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: I learned a lot, which will help me with future jobs.
Cons:
Where to start.  I honestly can't decide what was worse, the projects or the people. The project I worked on was miserable, and every single person on the team wanted to leave (and many eventually did, even the manager, who told us she really didn't want to be here anymore). 

And then there was the people. What do you get when you mix inexperience with over confidence? You guessed it! An IBMer.  Every single day I had to sit across from a coworker who continually bragged about his accolades and achievements, meanwhile doing absolutely nothing. Unfortunately, this guy was not an anomaly at IBM Design.  During Design Bootcamp, there was so much immaturity among the new hires that some designers flat out REFUSED to work with each other, and therefore had to be separated (kind of like in Kindergarten when one kid steals the other's crayon). One girl even started crying when another girl critiqued her wireframe "too harshly" and went and told on her to a design lead.  I wish I was joking. I would sit back and watch all this happen, completely floored by the fact that people like this had passed the culture fit part of the interview.

Title: "Former Blue Harmony Team Lead"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The greatest thing about IBM is their work/life balance,  the benefits, the Teams I worked with and the Leadership of the Managers and Team Leads that I worked under.  The best in the business!  IBM was my dream job a long time before I was hired FT.  Before being hired FT with a once then reputable company, I was a contractor.  The IBM Management that I reported to saw my worth and treated me and others with respect.  When I was hired, it was a dream come true.  All my hard work finally paid off.  I worked with phenominal people who were patient, and compassionate with their peers and IBM.  At that time, IBM was doing quite well.  Life was great for all until 9/11/2001 happened.   Todays IBM may be different.  It may be growing in a more positive direction.
Cons: When 9/11/2001 happened, it took a toll on IBM as well as other businesses.  The 9/11 affect was a slow trickle of poison to IBMs business.  However, I loved my job and the area I worked.  I thrived along with my peers.  Things were great until more and more resource actions were happening.  I was fortunate to be where I was until I decided to accept a job offer with no raise but a lateral move where the wind was blowing.  In the first year in this job, I worked the hardest I ever had in a job in my entire working life.  However, because I was at the bottom end of the totem pole I received an 'average' rating and NO raise.  My heartdropped and so did my morale.  I had two counterparts doing basically the same thing, and getting paid significantly more, but they were secure and up on the totem pole farther.   I knew then that I had two more years to go of being resourced.  That was the word in the hallways and it proved to be true.  Very disappointing in a company that I had dreamt of working for, for many years.   Before that, I excelled and received above average ratings and raises.  The fear of being resourced always lingered every time that dreaded news surfaced.   To me and others, this was just a way of resourcing employees.   Offer someone a new opportunity just so they can give you the shaft.  It did not matter how hard you worked.  It all depended on your placement on the totem pole.   So if you have been working in a job for a while, stay where you are at.  Do not leave.  I have applied for jobs at IBM since then, that I was very qualified for, but I am not given a fair chance.  I even had interviewed for a job before I was kicked out,  which I was positive I had, but the response I got was, 'We cannot hire you at this time'.   More disappointing news.   I believe I am flagged from being given an equal opportumity on jobs that I know I meet the qualifications.

Title: "Old Big Blue She Ain't What She Used To Be"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Great experience for college or grad school hires; smart, team-oriented colleagues; some really interesting projects at the leading edge of technology; very committed to diversity in the workforce (other than age); excellent benefits although becoming less excellent; committed to highest level of ethical behavior in the market and with customers; good name to have on resume; work at home when not on site helps with balance, but that's changing.
Cons: 20 consecutive quarters of revenue decline has caused panic and highly reactive management behaviors; large "job actions" (layoffs) every quarter that used to be solidly about losing low performers but last four events even top tier performers are being let go; so much turnover in customer facing roles that its hard to know who you work with, several SW sales roles on an account have churned twice a year for three years; committed to paying just below average; difficult to get through interview and hiring process; quarterly focus now monthly focus; laid off employees are now declared off limits for re-hiring or contracting in some roles; bringing in lots of outsiders with a very transactional view of the world, bad in a relationship business; gloom and fear have driven morale down.

Pros: I had an amazing manager, the environment truly embraces the help everyone out attitude.  Benefits and pay are within standard with the competition.
Cons: Management ontop of management, as with any large company IBM is slow to change direction.  Normally I would not list this as a con abut IBM is trying to be agile and "move the ship" in another direction.   In the sales roles you are "encouraged" to sale what meets the customers needs but in reality you will not be around long if you do since you need to hit the pavement hard on what you do get "paid for".   There is a balance here as with any sales role but long days and nights will be the sacrifice needed.  In sales don't expect any real CRM tool, generating leads will be tough as there is no prospect tools that are reliable.

Pros: Some very good people work at IBM.

I guess if IBM thinks they are the leader in AI then why should there be any human interaction.

Benefits are awful.

Title: "Great for execs or starting your career, not for mid-level"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: The diversity of people and experiences you'll find in your coworkers is great. The breadth of teams an opportunities means you can move around in your job without changing companies.
Cons:
Senior leadership is completely disconnected from the people on the ground doing actual work. Also, every org cares only about their own revenue, which leads to massive inefficiencies as seven different teams in five different orgs with 6 different executives are all trying to do the same thing, and none of them are talking to each other or coordinating. 
From a development perspective, its all still run by engineering with no balance between them, product management and design. 
Also, 20 quarters of declining revenue and an abundant avoidance of risk means that everyone is anxious and pushing stress around without being able to actually do something to fix it.

Title: "Software Developer"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros:
- Smart people working on a no-nonsense technical product.
- Opportunity to work on cutting-edge problems in distributed systems at scale.
- Forward thinking technical architecture. Systems are built to last. There is a constant pursuit and evaluation of technical innovation. This place is practically a patent mill. 
- Favors technical generalists, with many opportunities to take a deep dive into different areas. 
- Opinions are valued. No one will discount your opinion merely because you are junior. 
- Many large and significant projects happening concurrently, you will not be starved for a meaty project to work on. 
- Laid-back and professional culture free of Silicon Valley hype and status-mongering. A lot of people are friends outside of work. 
- Nice perks. Work from home Tuesdays and Thursdays. 

Having talked to coworkers after the buyout, Cleversafe is very well positioned strategically with IBM and is making large contributions to their cloud infrastructure.
Cons:
Cons
- Low Bus-Factor. Development is often bottlenecked by the involvement of a few key, senior people. Management has a hard time properly scheduling their time. 
- Senior technical people often double as managers. Difficult to get their attention from a career-development POV. 
- Unstructured career progression. Unless you take ownership of your path within the company, your fate will be decided by whatever urgent matter that needs to be addressed. 
- Ambitious development schedule favors large projects over incremental improvements. It takes a long time for technical debt to be addressed, if at all. 
- Resistance to internal change. The product is constantly evolving, but developers and management are slow to adopt changes to anything that is not customer facing.

Title: "Senior Managing Consultant"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Referring only to consulting services parts of business: Access to great clients. Name recognition of company provides more client experience opportunities overall. Med and 401K benefits are above average. Better employer value for somewhat unskilled working to gain industry experience, though it can be a commodity environment; lower-level candidates will have more "advancement" opportunity. More financially rewarding for those with strong sales focus and can-do on targets, due to large-public-corp and quarterly profits imperatives for top executive reward.
Cons: Sales goals set at upper management levels often unrealistic, and lower levels penalized with little financial accountability at the top. Client sales numbers are often the incentive, not intelligent or great client delivery as foundation. This is always reflected in your annual reviews, which don't even contain factors that really reflect excellent delivery over the "push more across" factors. Productivity targets are unrealistic for the practitioner, with negative impact for training (which is practically nil opportunity except OJT) or off-time benefits in calcs. Often there is a failure (observed) to recognize resource-in-hand capabilities, with a hire-and-go mentality for commodity skills, without understanding or leveraging the value of can-execute and can-complete-on-time and as-scoped experience. Poor top-to-bottom coordination for doing the right job, with frequent lack of pass-through executive-field understanding of the realities of delivering value to clients, or what is practical and achievable.

I would be shocked if Pepsi continued to do business with them and renewed the contract here in a couple of years.  Overall my experience after 3 years was that the company was sloppy, careless, and remarkably arrogant.

Title: "Operations Support"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: It's a paycheck.  Nice to have the name on your resume. It explains you need to find a new place to work.
Cons: Not allowed to vary from the tasks for your job or risk breaking rules of lean management.  No meaningful career advancement options without working day shift and replacing your next immediate superior when and if they leave.  No realistic career track or mentoring available.  Productivity improvements are gained by heaping more and more work on fewer and fewer full time equivalent employees regardless of what the service level contracts promise customers.  Management meets its performance review targets by double booking man hours on multiple contracts resulting in inadequate staffing levels.  Rank order employees in performance reviews punish mistakes and job requirements leave no room for exceptional performance.  If you stick with this company and you’ll destroy your long term career path options.   Then you'll get an offer to retire early so they can hire a college grad for less than half of you salary.

Title: "Transformation to the Cloud world is never easy"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: The amount of business acumen across industries, languages and cultures is invigorating. There is no problem that cannot be solved - or so it seems. According to IBM's founder's view that "...every problem mankind is confronted with, can be solved, if people only THINK..." is embodied in how this large organism works every day. You get to contribute to solving problems like cancer, water shortages, production impasses, irrigation systems and many more with the solutions you help build. It is very rewarding to play a small - and sometimes not so small - part in solving bib problems.
Cons: It is a big company and not for the faint-of-heart. You need to show persistence, conviction - and, yes, success - to get others to see the world your way. If you are looking for instant gratification, this one is not for you. Chances are, that the people around you are way smarter than you.

Title: "Advisory Software Engineer"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Great colleagues, including very supportive lower management.

Global opportunities - Able to transfer to other geographies (with company need/approval).

Was flexible about working from home, until mid-2016, when IBM decided on how it would interpret "Agile" * (see Cons)
Cons:
*  As a result of IBM's idea of Agile, everyone must go to their office (or nearest hub office), every working day, regardless of what they're working on or whether they're in a team - As a result, many great engineers were forced to leave, as they were unable to comply with this directive (in contravention of prior agreements) - Thus, there has been a sizeable increase to IBM's _real_ carbon footprint (But, who is accounting for all this extra pollution?).

Ever-diminishing morale, as ongoing cuts are made to Systems group, leaving those who remain increased workloads and low job security.

Even after jumping through all the hoops, like writing publications and filing (questionable) patents, employees can still end up being RA'd (laid off).

Too much focus on end of quarter results (and how these can be manipulated to justify the board decisions and the new company direction, regardless of the overall falling revenue).

High-risk of job loss as employment levels and skill needs change; and pitiful severance
A few senior leaders who may mean well but may benefit from more new blood in the org
Hard to change a big complex global org; they're on the path, but change is hard and slow

Title: "Hit and miss..."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
The culture is a mosaic, made up on all its acquisitions.  Some organizations are very cut-throat; others are more cooperative.  In my organization,  all of my colleagues pull together and support each other. Plus, my manager is supportive and one of the best I've ever had. 

There is some room for movement within an organization and between organizations.  I've seen several colleagues make lateral moves.   If you're aggressive, you can move up.
Cons: The company has lost $ for 20 straight quarters, so there are constant layoffs.  Whole divisions disappear overnight.  All this while giving the CEO a HUGE raise. Currently, there is a hiring freeze and internal travel ban.  Also, IBM doesn't invest in R&D.  They buy a company, "blue wash" it, and then allow it to sink or swim without investing in the technology.

Title: "Legal - Typical Problems with a Big Place"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM part-time for more than a year
Pros:
Decent pay
Group I was in had flexible hours
Good management/supervision, but it is very dependent on who your supervisor is

Honestly as part time this was great, it can be good to get some experience in your area. However, I don't see it as being the fulfilling longstanding career that used to be attached with the IBM name.
Cons:
Big place means a lot of bureaucracy
Suggestions often not implemented
Little upward mobility right now

Everyone is pretty stuck in their ways. The processes put in place can be super frustrating, and there are so many different groups that must work together to push a product out, yet nobody knows more than just what their group does. This makes communication difficult at times, slowing pushing out a product, which leads to everyone higher in the development chain putting unnecessary pressure on those lower in the chain.

Title: "Passion, Innovation and Engagement"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
The people: IBMers are smart, passionate, collaborative, committed and driven to deliver value to our clients, the company and each other

The work: Meaningful in impact, global in scale/local in design, partnering with clients to solve some of the world's most challenging problems, always an exciting hill to climb...you will be stretched!

The environment: built on a foundation of values, belief in work-life flexibility, inherent learning culture, collaborative
Cons:
Change and reinvention is a constant in our industry, with our clients and in our company; if you enjoy status quo or a great deal of certainty, IBM would be a difficult environment for you to operate in

IBM is a large company. If you are not a self starter and path finder dedicated to your personal expertise and impact, it will be challenging for you to succeed.

If you prefer to be highly entrepreneurial, your skills will be valued, but you will need to embrace process and procedure governance to work within.

Title: "A good place to work"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: I have had many (25) good years with IBM.  I've worked with real good people, invested in their jobs and the success of their projects.  There is opportunity at IBM to move around and have many different experiences.  I've worked on over half a dozen projects in those years and in a variety of capacities.  Decent benefits including flex time and sick leave.  Every direct manager I've had cared about his/her employees and giving flexibility when 'real life' issues arose.
Cons: This isn't the old IBM.  Now, like any other company, to hang on and avoid layoff you need to acquire and maintain relevant skills and are responsible for your own future.  And you also need a certain amount of luck to not be on the wrong project at the wrong time.  Strives to be 'middle of the road' compensation wise.

Title: ""IBM Way""
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM
Pros:
Higher pay compared to some.  About on par for other large companies though.
PTO/Health is VERY standard.
Cons:
Long working hours (based on team).  But it seems fairly consistent that most are asked to regularly work 50+ hours.  Salaried employees especially.

The "IBM way" phrase that gets thrown around is their way of saying "work longer, for no extra pay, because you work for IBM" (which clearly means you're superior to the competition and should be proud).

They have no real structure, or company goals, other than money.  

In my orientation class, they ACTUALLY said "What does IBM do?  We don't know, but help us define it."..... They actually do not have any core.

Others: 
 You wont be able to move within the company.  If you do well, your boss will not allow you to move, which they must sign off on.  
Consistent fear of RAs for many.
They are very sneaky in their hiring process, in terms of their expectations of you.

Title: "IBM hates doing software development in the US"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: IBM is still a great name to have on your resume. They do some pretty cool projects, and you learn to work hard at IBM. For some people, things turn out really well at IBM if they get the right first project.
Cons: Projects are chronically understaffed. It's hard to get a good assignment. It seems the best work is hand-picked for certain people. YMMV, but the company is not interested in developing you. They will keep you in the same assignment for a long time, and make it very hard to transfer. In my case, I did a stint as a Support person. I then applied to a Development proper position (which I had done previously). I started out doing Development, but in less than 2 months, Support duties were added to my job, and then my job became that almost 100%. After years at that job working hard, I transferred to a new job, and I noticed that once again, I wasn't allowed to go to a Development proper position, they wanted me to do same job again!!!  Even though there was plenty of Development work to do on my new team, they would rather keep the project understaffed and behind schedule, than to hire one more ready and willing developer to help out, and go out of their way to keep me in a position I no longer wanted to perform.

Title: "Culture of fear is killing morale and productivity"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: If you can survive, IBM offers tremendous opportunity to navigate and change direction within your career. IBM offers great education and training, and internal job changes and growth are expected and encouraged. I myself changed direction with my career four times.
Cons: I have survived many years of layoffs (resource actions or RAs) here at IBM and the frequency, intensity, and number of talented folks released each time has become frightening. It no longer matters your contributions, amount of revenue you generate, your performance, your value, how long (or how short) you have been employed... you have simply become a number. As a result, the once dynamic collaboration, teamwork, and pride in this company have disappeared and most live in fear of the next quarterly RA. Many reviews here on Glassdoor talk about the benefits of working from home and IBM's work/life balance; don't believe it. IBM has recently decided to force most employees to come to an office (sometimes to one hundreds, if not thousands of miles away). IBM is hemorrhaging talent as many scramble to leave before they are forced out.

Title: "One of THE Top 5 brands to work for...............globally"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: Continually re-invents itself to stay relevant to changing times.  IBM is 'World Issue' relevant, not just a technology services company - focusing on solving issues such as curing diseases, ensuring that expertise in areas such as healthcare, law, finance is available to ALL, no matter where you live or your socio-economic limitations, etc. IBM has had a focus on equal pay and diversity since long before it became a focus for other organizations. Career development opportunities are second to none, the internal movement of staff to new roles is a constant focus
Cons: Sometimes it can be a little bureaucratic and overly 'matrixed' - but with 400,000+ staff its difficult not to have some of that..........pay/benefits are good but not industry leading - real motivation to join comes from the career opportunity presented, the chance for personal and professional growth once in IBM and the thrill of working for an industry leading brand which is taking Watson to the world.

Title: "Challenging for all the wrong reasons"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Work at home (though rapidly disappearing), some select areas of genuine innovation and distinction. For now, relatively strong brand. Pretty solid employee benefits, but few perks.
Cons:
IBM is an inward-looking organization, and a slow-moving one but with a few fast-moving areas. Every quarter the message from leadership is, "We fell short overall, but our positive results in x, y, or z show that our transformation strategy is working. We all must execute better going forward." Lay offs follow and it's up to the survivors (increasingly hardened operators) to spin even more plates, or appear to, before the axe falls again. IBM spent over a billion dollars last year buying its own stock to keep the price up, and laid off tens of thousands as part of that winning strategy. It's been doing this for many years.

In my experience, every year the volatility and toxicity of the environment grows. Top and bottom performers get smart and leave or are laid off, and what's left are the very senior IBMers and a vast middle management culture, though at this stage the wolf at the door is starting to eat them too. I guess that's the IBM version of "Scrum" and "Agile" (though teams of competing IBM experts would want to argue with me on my use of terms--may the expert with the best positioned senior director win).

My advice: work for a different company, one that cares about its employees' careers and isn't playing a vast and very long shell game.

Title: "Sales - Cloud @ IBM"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
- as IBM is a huge conglomerate, you can have many different career experiences in one place.
- despite all the negative press, the company has a strong balance sheet and strong product margins, i.e. good stability and a cautious view on taking risk
- good benefits, though like most companies they pare back - 401k match (up to $16k annually), deferred comp for high income earners, low-cost medical.
- if you are good at your work, work/life balance is at least possible
Cons:
- need to negotiate starting salary strongly - raises/promotions are very, very rare
- bonuses even on sales plans seem totally subjective and random
- 60% of your colleagues suck, and somehow the resource actions never seem to get those people
- near constant organizational and territory change disrupts client and partner relationships, a competitive disadvantage and leads to a lot of internal "self-promotion"

Title: "This is not your daddy's IBM!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: IBM brings together an amazing array of technology as the basis of real, practical solutions  that power Earth's commerce.  Some people still think of IBM as "that mainframe company", but today's IBM has been transformed into an agile, leading edge technology creator.  As an IBMer, it is amazing to be able to pick up the phone and chat with the very people who are creating and shaping tomorrow.  Blockchain, quantum computing, cognitive computing, and countless other technologies are real-world here.  Yes, we still sell some big iron; but (surprise!) it runs Linux!
Cons: No way to hide it -- IBM is a big enterprise, with nearly a half million employees around the world.  It isn't a startup!

Title: "Bizarre Management"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years

Title: "My IBM Experience"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: IBM is one of the best companies in the world to work for.  They actually care about their employees.   Being at the forefront of technology, there is a lot of room for growth and career opportunities.   I have been working for them almost 3 years and  in my 30 years in the computer industry, it is by far the BEST.  I am proud to say I am an IBMer!!!
Cons: I haven't had a pay raise yet in over 2 years - not even a merit raise.  I wish that would change.  But other than that, I enjoy my job and my team!

Title: "Still one of the places to be if you want to innovate in meaningful ways to affect the world"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Here's an example of what I mean by innovating to affect the world.  I just finished an exercise where I looked back at my multi-year career at IBM to see where I made a difference, not just to IBM but to my clients and beyond.   I remembered a project I helped lead for a world-class academic medical center a few years ago where we developed a first-of-a-kind piece of clinical technology in collaboration with the client using all of IBM, including hardware, software, services, industry expertise and IBM research.  That project several years ago formed the foundation of the long-term relationship that enabled us to build a Watson instance around cancer diagnosis and treatment that is enabling about 30% of their patients to live longer lives with better outcomes from treatment.   That is real impact on the lives of people.  That is what I mean by "meaningful".
Cons: IBM is in the middle of a difficult transition from a traditional hardware/software/services IT company to a new model of a cognitive and cloud company that doesn't exist anywhere yet.  In the process, there are transition pains as the company needs to meet short-term financial targets while accomplishing incredible change and metamorphosis as a company.  If you are looking for a place to come to work, do your job, and not have to deal with change for 20 years, this is not the company for you.

Title: "Be the change you want to see in the world… become an IBMer"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros:
If you want to be successful and change the world you work for a company like IBM.  IBM is on the cutting edge of technology and the opportunities are endless to those willing to work for it and earn it.  Make no mistake about it… its highly competitive, edgy, stressful and at times it can feel like pure madness.  This is what it takes to be a world leader in technology.  IBM can help you tap into the greatest version of you and come out on the other side a contributor to the brilliance that is IBM.
If you are interested in more than just benefits and you want to make a difference in today’s world… IBM is the place for you.  (FYI… benefits are great).  If you are just looking for a paycheck, “swipe LEFT”.  All things being equal IBM has their share of issues just like every other company.  No matter what company you work for, when faced with a challenge, you can complain about it or build a business case to fix it.  At IBM you can be part of the solution that fixes the problem.  
IBM is a wealth of vision and inspiration and always looking forward to the future.  I would challenge anyone reading this to be the change you want to see in the world… become an IBMer.

One piece of advice… It’s called BIG BLUE for a reason… do not get lost in the ocean…NETWORK.
Cons: I prefer to call them challenges... all companies have them.  Nothing major you can't overcome.

Title: "Can't compete with other tech companies on culture, salary, or opportunities"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: In my department, work-life balance is good, although this varies wildly across IBM. People are nice and it's not cut throat. Pretty good benefits -- 3 weeks vacation, 401k match (but only matched at the end of the year), good health insurance, 12 weeks maternity/6 weeks paternity leave (none of the great benefits our competitors give though -- no free food, shuttle buses, social events)
Cons: Very poor manager training leads to terrible managers and lots of politics. Very slow upward mobility. Lower salaries than competitors. Not "millennial" friendly -- feels very old and stodgy, we have lots of millennial panels but their recommendations don't go anywhere at all. Experience is extremely dependent on who your manager is and what department you are in. Constant budget cuts lead to terrible HR coverage, bad office spaces, low morale. Ironically for being an IT company we have slow and clunky internal software and tools.

Title: "AGE DISCRIMINATION"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Large company with lots of interesting technologies to explore and a very fast paced environment but very focused on immediate results.
Cons: Consistently fire top performers over 40 years old - replaced by younger workers or H1B visa workers.  Way to focused on reporting positive Wall Street metrics as sales fall as a result of their most experienced sellers losing their jobs to reduce expense.

Title: "No longer an industry leader for employees"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: For some people may  provide opportunities to pursue interesting and important technology trends.  However, years of a strategy that weakens its delivery capabilities may mean that while IBM could be a good place to try out, it eventually may not be able to support longer term career goals.
Cons: Currently perception may look better than the reality.  Frequent reorganizations, intensive employee churn and unstable strategy and tactics means the dust never settles enough to effectively operationalize the ideas.   This leaves the organization confused, off balance, and struggling with day to day survival down to the individual employee level, instead of successfully delivering solutions.  Sellers drink the coolaid about new capabilities, but a limited ability to actually deliver leaves the rest of the organization in cleanup mode for promises that cannot consistently be kept.   Excitement with great ambitions gives way to disillusioned reality when things move from slides and PoCs to attempts at more complete solutions.   Lesson: stay on the solution sales side, and away from solution delivery.

Title: "Adventure with the High C's (CEO, CFO, CIO, CISO)"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I work with unmatched researchers and engineers that are solving for problems others haven't anticipated yet. In security specifically I have the highest level of confidence about the primary problem we are addressing and that no other provider can even check more than two of the five boxes needed except IBM and that's because of what they decided to do 12 years ago. Our CEO is leading the the most daunting change of any other leader of any other organization on the planet and it's working...the ship is turning and some people are jumping off, some hiding in the berth but the majority are hands on deck. This is an exciting and challenging time to be an IBM'er.
Cons: If you're looking for a place to settle in and not be challenged on a daily basis this would be a bad choice. There's still some complexity with an organization the size of IBM. And some people who protect and hold onto processes or principles of the past on how things 'ought' to be done as if their written in stone convictions, but their either adapting or moving on. Realizing there's a difference between convictions that are unchanging like: honesty, integrity, personal responsibility, etc... and principles like following steps 1,2,3,4,5,6... to closing deals with clients when steps 1,3,5 were sufficient. If you want easy and unchallenging then you should find somewhere else to build a career.

Cons: There are many layers of redundant process supported by a back office function that needs its own transformation, but you can be a part of that change if you bring solutions to the problem into the process.

Title: "Caution: Instability & Layoffs"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Internal education is frequent & diverse. Coworkers are some of the brightest & hardest working people in the industry. Great 401k 100% match to 6%
Cons: Constant & massive resource actions. Very low morale, everybody is nervous, unattainable sales quotas. Legacy top performing employees with 20+ years of valuable knowledge & experience are being let go with a mere 30 day severance for their decades of loyalty in favor of less skilled & lower salaried young college grads. Too many  underwhelming middle & senior managers who should be let go instead. No accountability at the top line for 20 straight quarters of declining revenue.

Persistent disconnect between sales and support, transition & build to steady-state leads to extreme levels of micromanagement which only causes more muddled processes and lack of solid process improvement.

Title: "IBM is a tough place to succeed as a growth seller serving mid-market and enterprise clients"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: There is great technology innovation at IBM, in line with the strategy of becomming more product-driven and less relationship driven. If you want to invest in your knowledge and skills, IBM will help you do that, and does provide great and continuous enablement. Sales people have a lot of autonomy to meet their numbers, which means you'll run your own deals, and also boils down to competing for ever-scarcer resources at a time when revenue continues shrinking.
Cons: In six years I have had have five roles. I joined for one role, and found another when the first role was clearly going away. After that, I wasn't asked or consulted about the other moves...just woke up with a new job each time and found out afterward. While each one has been a deep learning experience, no one seemed to care if I would be good at it or even survive. And it seems that about 80% of colleagues in that position were gone after two years. So IBM = I've been moved. Work fast if you want to build a relationship with your manager. I was assigned to seven in six years. All this can be very alienating. Worse than the change of jobs is the change of clients.  If you value building lasting relationships with clients, forget about doing it at IBM, certainly in all but the very largest revenue-generating accounts that have dedicated teams. In many cases it took at least six months to a year to gain sufficient trust to have honest conversations with clients (which is where real sales forecasts come from by the way). And by then, I was reassigned, the the client's sense of not being important to IBM was only reinforced.  But IBM managers know this. We talk about it all the time.

Cons: Give it   At least until q3 2017 to get its act together on its priorities.  Also they are doing a bit of downsizing in Q2

Title: "No matter how good you are, Corporate doesn't care."

Pros:
Large organization that you can move around and find different opportunities.
Innovative company with leading edge or first of a kind technology solutions.
Corporate Services Corp Leadership Program.
Cons:
Eliminating vast majority of US resources for cheaper off shore labor.
Can be a top performer with all the accolades possible and still be let go in order to be replaced with cheaper labor off shore, which is the path the company continues to do.
Working remotely is now much more rare as most employees have to be co-located in only one of handful of cities in the US.
Poor HR management structure. You are typically on your own as far as career development and have to strongly advocate for yourself even for things as simple as training.
Very expensive health benefits especially if you have more than 1 child.
Minimal bonus and raises even for top performers.

There are way too many VPs that I can't even name.

Cons:
IBM lays off much of their US staff on a regular basis.  The US staff, for many departments, is the backbone of that group.  A lot of the jobs are outsourced.  Company morale has dropped over the years because of it.  IBM no longer seems to care much about it's customer because of the support and knowledge that they let go of. 

There are also too many things that they push on you to learn on a constant basis.  It becomes overwhelming, especially when your daily workload is massive.  While it's great that they provide different educational things, there is no specific direction.  Every year, there's something different.  And what they push and push you to "learn" the year before, doesn't even apply the next year.

Title: "IBM Review"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Great work life balance at IBM.

Title: "Marketing"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: Great compensation & benefits.  Lower level team members are great & hard working.  Good & a wide variety of experience gained quickly. Working from home has been a perk, but they are getting rid of that option for most positions.
Cons:
Written by a millennial: Currently, IBM is going through a massive change where everyone has to relocate to one of 6 cities.  This tactic is to get rid of the middle/higher level positions who are older & cost more for employment & targeting millennials to hire in.  This tactic disregards the expertise that the mid-higher level employees have in their field.  Team members who have been at IBM for 20+ years are unappreciated & forced into retirement or to look for a new job. 

In addition to IBM not appreciating their loyal & experienced employees, IBM has a horrible onboarding process.  Starting as a university hire, I was just dropped in without understanding my role, the dynamics of the team, & was assigned as the lead for large events within the first couple months.  If IBM plans to replace all of the experienced IBM employees with new young hires, they need to have a very thorough training process in plan based on roles that has a single person assigned to the success of the new hire.

Lastly, all direction comes from the top down.  Reorganization happens at least once a year if not more.  The majority of the time people are trying to understand their role & new team members instead of being able to get quality work done.

Title: "IBM is changing, it was a good place to deliver value"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Work with very good people:  Top professionals across the board, committed to working through issues to support their team and the customer.   In the past, pay has been competitive, but due to focus on lower cost over quality, you will need to carefully check both for competitive pay, and how many folks have been laid off from the team you are considering joining .... IBM will lay off a group of strong performers, and then hire a few for those vocal customers that apply significant pressure.    In the past, culture and values has been outstanding, and this may continue with the off-shored/global teams, but exhaustion and low morale are taking a toll.
Cons:
Focus on profit over commitments, rather than profit through excellence while meeting commitments.  
Low moral due to continuous layoffs of top talent..everyone works to gloss over, but it is the undercurrent across teams.   --If you are in managing role, you will spend time helping people be productive in the face of great uncertainty.  You will need to manage teams with the idea that a layoff and loss of productivity and focus may happen at the worst of times.  
Do not count on bonus as part of your pay.  I was predominantly a 1 rating:    the bonuses even for 1 ratings have been minuscule, and a  1 rating is difficult to achieve and largely political: it involves an exorbitant amount of time in a constantly stressful environment.   --You simply may not have the resource talent and experience you need, at the time you need it due to the layoffs.  The  increase in inexperienced resources tends to create a greater need for seasoned professionals.

Pros: In my position, knowing what I did improved the job satisfaction of thousands of other employees was extremely gratifying.
Cons: Incredible bureaucracy means things that can be accomplished with a couple calls or emails at a smaller company, can take days or weeks . IBM has so many overlapping pieces that even the company is no longer aware of what they have.

Very good benefits, the 401K is excellent, the salary can be good for high performers
Finally got rid of their stacked-ranking method for employee evaluations
Investing in AI/Cognitive, Cloud, IoT, Security, trying to be a competitive enterprise cloud company - lots of cool technology being developed
Most people at IBM are very nice, smart, hard working and creative people
A well run company for the most part for its size
Most managers and execs are very good leaders and people
High performers treated very well and have lots of opportunity for advancement
The work can be extremely interesting and challenging
Hiring more outside executives to fill many leadership roles -- this is good
Cons:
Annual budget cuts and layoffs create a lot of fear, no one is safe
Finance seems to be making all the decisions
A big company with a lot of typical big company problems; red-blue tape, budget constrained, slow and out of date processes, slow everything
Struggling to grow revenue and modernize their culture, leadership, and business practices
Too much focus on pleasing Wall Street instead of pleasing customers and employees

Cons:
Our leaders do not do what they preach!
IBM lives a constant dichotomy between what we know we need to do and what we're used to do and know the results that come from it. It's natural for any company going through such a big change, but most of the leaders are the ones not acting as the IBMers of the future and still pressuring their team to do the same so they can stay in their comfort zone - this is making a lot of good talent leave IBM.

Title: "Great at one time"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Wonderful colleagues, good health and dental.  Fairly professional in general.   Up until recently, working from home.
Cons: Very toxic from an employment perspective.  For the last 15 years it has been a case of Russian roulette with annual resource actions.  The last 5 have been particularly bad as the fat has been removed and the staffing is far below minimum.  Off shoring has been a continuous churn with unqualified folks replacing knowledgeable resources and leaving IBM shortly after turnover.  Unrealistic project deliveries, due to under staffing and unrealistic scope.  Expectation to work above and beyond is a daily norm and the knowledge that if you don't you will likely be fired.  Resource actions now quarterly and move back to one of 6 centers are driving moral to new lows.  "new collar" and H1-b visas continue to drive employees away.

Title: "Sr. IT Specialist"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: You can put the job on your resume, which everyone tells you will be of real value, but those days are long gone. If you're young and right out of school with not a lot of experience it is easy to get in.
Cons: A vague shadow of its former self as a corporation. The company is on a steady decline - 24 straight quarters of revenue loss - but still the CEO gets a $5, bonus. Think of that....a bonus for doing a stupendously bad job! Something significant will happen in the next couple of years. Either a take over by another company for salvage parts, or collapse into smaller companies that way it was planned before in the 90's. If you are considering it please discount the supposed advantage of having this job on your resume. It has started circling the drain and there are just too many good money making tech jobs out there for you to waste your time. Please don't believe the propaganda you are starting to see in ads for working here. Its a sign how desperate they are. Over 75% of the company is in India. It is no longer an American company, nor is its future in America. If you are in America, this is not your future.

Title: "ibm"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
- Real engineers work on real problems for actual customers who use the products (as opposed to smaller companies that promise the world, but probably can't back up those promises)
- Dedication to creating good products and maintaining them
- Employees do have integrity regarding supporting customers, and with respect to protecting IBM's intellectual property and finances.
- IBM tends to be very clique oriented. If you are in a clique with power and financial support, then IBM can be a very good place to work.
Cons:
- Very little education offered (lots of talk about education, but they don't actually pay for you to take classes)
- Very, very political environment. 
- Layoffs occur 2-4 times a year, impacting morale and increasing politically motivated behaviors. Low productivity employees were laid off years ago, so now decent employees are laid off
- outsourcing to india taking jobs from service organizations. you could train folks in india then lose your job
- Managers are big into CYA
- Lagging behind on cloud, containers, etc
- IBM no longer allows employees to work at home at all - this impacts IBM's claim to fame as promoting work/life balance and impacts working mothers. 
- IBM tends to be very clique oriented. If you are in a clique with power and financial support, then IBM can be a very good place to work. If are on the outside of the cliques with power, then you are completely out of all loops, and this lack of information impacts your ability to succeed.
- IBM grades on a curve and has quotas for performance review levels. If you are not part of a powerful clique, you can not get a high performance review. And this process discourages collaboration as employees are motivated to "look better" than their peers rather than support and encourage their peers. If you are in an "inner clique" you are only motivated to help others as long as you can take the credit for their work.

Title: "A Dysfunctional Dinosaur"

Cons: IBM Marketing consistently demonstrates a complete lack of strategic thinking coupled with constantly changing and competing priorities which lead to every day being a fire drill. Add management's recent decision to co-locate all marketing activities in six cities, and you have a toxic stew of negativity, a lack of accountability and morale that's so low that most people are working on an exit strategy.  For these reasons and many others, I would not recommend working in marketing at IBM.

Title: "Slow and steady works for some but not all at Rocket Center"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: You will learn every day no matter how piddly the role is you fill. Every experience has pushed me to be better and that is one thing I cannot deny about Rocket Center. Office is quiet and all of the management within the Client Innovation Center are very friendly. Benefits are very good and almost make up for the lower salaries. Absolute job security. Total freedom for making your hours depending on your project and manager as of Spring 2017, this may have been different in the past. They want you to get work done, that is all. Other opportunities to be involved are a bit of a time drain but they have provided a better sense of morale for the staff. Overall facility is nice, onsite cafeteria, onsite gym.
Cons: The office is quite grey and does not benefit from the beautiful mountain backdrop thanks to government issued cubes. IBM artwork is lame and small, doesn't cut it! Salaries are low comparative to the industry. However, the industry is hyper competitive right now and the benefits are pretty good. In addition, the surrounding area is very inexpensive to live in. Much of the management seems to have their hands tied or are too busy to be able to help eager employees make moves. There is limited flexibility in moving beyond the CIC and I see this as a huge talent drain for IBM. If I ever leave the CIC I probably won't return to IBM ever again. Security onsite is tight and sometimes is annoying. The guards have been quite rude toward me, I feel targeted for my age and stature. All internal IBM solutions are largely garbage. I get spammed by IBM corporate about 20 emails a day. Considering quitting just because of the damn emails!

Title: "Middle Management"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Being honest there are some.  lLet me start by sayign this is not a review based on feeling its based on fact. There are a wide range of exciting topics to work on and wide range of departments to work in.  Depending on where you live and who your direct management is will greatly effect your experience.   Great experiences however, used to be a norm,  most all , 80% had great experiences. No one is perfect.  But in today's culture its the opposite.  20% are happy 80% are looking for new jobs or are just trying to hang on
Cons: IBM describes its self as a large ship.  Well the ship is sinking..... IBM has brought on a new set of executive management.  None of which know IBM and each of them trying to put their own spin on how things should be reorganized.   I am very very disappointed in how IBM is treating its employees.  There is zero loyalty and concern for the best part of the company "its incredible employee base"   My recommendation is to run far far away.   If you like working tons of extra hours, with zero work life balance ( which used to be a great benefit for IBM) and zero appreciation from upper management then this is your company.  You will see many new reviews on how wonderful IBM is.  This is because new people are being hired and have yet to experience the true company.

Title: "Great start to a career, but impersonal"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Great start to a career, but impersonal
Great compensation and benefits 
Opportunities to explore different career paths and industries if you're not sure exactly what you want to do 
Work with really smart, interesting people 
Constantly changing clients/projects/locations 
Challenging roles you would not get hired for specifically- plenty of room to grow
To me there doesn't seem to be a glass ceiling at IBM. I worked hard, was often recognized for my work, and found really interesting and challenging roles. The better you do, the more responsibility you are given. 
As a first job out of college, if you're not sure exactly what you want to do and don't mind traveling 4 days/week, this is the perfect job.
Cons:
If you are a consultant, you do not have control over where you are working geographically- at any time you could be placed on a project anywhere for any period of time. This is probably true of any consulting company.

Also if you are a consultant, you likely will not have control over the roles you take in the organization. If a team needs a gap to be filled, you will have to step in even if it's not in the industry you would like or where you want to be. 

One of my largest qualms with working at IBM was that there is no emphasis on manager relationships. You will more than likely not know and not often interact with your manager. This is no fault of theirs-- they have full time jobs, are most often not on the same project or client as you, and are not based in your city. I have not met any of the (many) managers I've had through re-orgs, and infrequently interacted with them. Managers are not rewarded for working with their managees and not motivated to do so.

The culture is fast-paced and demanding. I realized quickly that I did not want to become senior at IBM, as the expectation is that you will always be available and ready to work (weekends, late nights, etc.) This is how people earn respect at IBM. 

I've had several instances in which older men have made unwanted advances toward me. With a company as large as IBM, I can see how this could happen. I was able to quickly deal with these scenarios.
