Title: "dissatisfied employees, company on downward slide"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Well-known brand makes it easy to open conversations with the public and looks good on a resume. If you're early in your career and looking for experience without wanting to commit to a life-long employer, this is still a decent option. You'll get good exposure and rapid-fire training that will serve you well outside of this organization.
Cons:
TL;DR: little opportunity for advancement, bonuses are small (<1%), raises are hard to come by (maybe every 3-5 years) and layoffs are more common, management is too top-heavy to be effective, employees shoulder the blame for poor executive decisions, salaries are non-competitive, benefits are lacking.

Brand has been so diluted over the years that at industry events and tradeshows we frequently hear "I never knew IBM did that..." and many still think of IBM as a computer manufacturer and few are ready to embrace whatever message IBM is pushing - are they a cloud company or focused on quantum processing? What does Watson have to do with it - isn't he a robot? The company's biggest problems, in my experience, have always come from their top-heavy structure. Too many layers of management with too few direct reports makes getting consensus extremely difficult if not impossible. As much as IBM touts their ability to be "agile" that really applies to the software and services they deliver to customers; internally it's a different story. Seemingly simple tasks that can be done in minutes/hours at any other company routinely take weeks or months - if they ever get the 'proper' buy-in from management, which can be rare. The company claims to "treasure wild ducks" but in my experience those who stick their neck out tend to get the axe. Management is very guarded in relation to their employees (seeing as how the managers easily outnumber the employees for most business units) and it makes otherwise nice people into cold managers. Managerial experience varies wildly from one person to the next - you may have someone who is sympathetic and cares about their employees or someone who could not care less about you - and there is no consistency for even small things like acknowledging birthdays or employment anniversaries. In recent years, the managers who were more people-focused have left the organization and the few who remain are outnumbered and pressured by their colleagues to be less caring. This has also created a vacuum of management who doesn't know the duties of their employees; they literally can not execute a single task that they require from their employees because they don't have any experience doing the work. This is being compounded by outside hiring of executive management who bring along some great ideas but cannot execute them because the IBM systems don't allow for it.

The new "co-location" strategy that IBM is employing seems a deliberate attempt to force out older workers who make more money in favor of younger, less costly employees. This maneuver comes at a time with the lowest company morale that I can remember. For the past 2  years we have all struggled with changes to systems, tools, teams, etc. while being told that we aren't doing enough (thus, no bonuses/raises while the CEO continues to get huge payouts) and we are blamed for the declining revenues of the company. For the most part, everyone dug in and rolled up their sleeves to make some headway, only to be told that now we must relocate to a pre-assigned corporate office or resign. Older/higher salary workers tend to have families and homes that can't easily be uprooted and thus are being forced to resign. For many of the long-term employees the only 'saving grace' was the ability to work from home, which saves on expenses and now that is being taken away. Although for many of us, working from home was never an option - we were assigned to a home office so that IBM could relinquish office buildings and save on rent, etc. and we are given an extremely small allowance for the costs of doing business (no compensation for internet service, electricity, furnishings, etc.).

Overall, I see the attempts to make IBM act/feel like a start-up tech company by co-locating its workers in select offices with open floor plans and "fun" stuff like donuts on Friday is too little too late. The company is simply too large and top heavy to function this way and unless they pare down the work staff to hundreds of people (instead of hundreds of thousands) they'll never see the results they're looking for. Which means more blaming the employees for the failures of executive orders, layoffs, and replacement of executives who will bring more new ideas that will continue to fail.

My advice to anyone looking to join IBM is to be mindful. If you're young and flexible and can survive a layoff with no warning, this still might be a good place to cut your teeth and build your resume. If you're an experienced professional looking for stability, you should probably keep looking. Everything from employee support to benefits has been slashed repeatedly and is unlikely to ever come back, so for those looking to build a career or stay long-term, you're going to be hard-pressed to build a 5, 10, 20,or 30 year tenure at IBM.

Title: "Work Experience Highly Dependent On Team & Manager"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: There are a few managers that are great mentors and want to help with your career growth. The opportunity to work with multi-disciplinary groups leads to a lot of learning. It's pretty nice that the pay is above average and more importantly you have the opportunity to work with people who are equally passionate about healthcare as you are.
Cons: In general, the company is not very organized, has a hard time synchronizing among the same groups within offices and among other offices. Depending on location - culture is non- existent. Some groups have no work-life balance, while others do. Some products never see the light of day (lack of funding, lack of organization), it all depends on what team you are on. The quality of managers is a 50/50 toss up, and favoritism among the top managers is apparent. The opportunity to step into leadership is available, but the ability  to continuously grow and learn applicable industry skills in this environment is questionable.

Title: "IBM GBS Consulting by Degrees (CbD) Program"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- PEOPLE: you get to work with some of the greatest and brightest people if you're lucky. You'll get close to your start class and it'll feel like an extension of college. 
- PAY: if you went to a target school, then your pay is probably pretty good compared to your peers' starting salaries at PwC, EY, etc. (hey, that's how they trapped me here)
- TRAVEL PERKS: if you enjoy traveling, then you're in the right place to rack up miles and hotel points. You can also do alternate travel and fly somewhere else for the weekend, which is pretty nice.
Cons:
Despite what the recruiters/interviewers tell you, IBM is NOT a management consulting company. Yes, we do talk to C-Suite, but only the CIO, and when we do, it's because we're either selling or implementing IBM products/solutions, not because we're trying to help you figure out why your company's profits are declining. 

Given the sales-driven and margin-driven nature of the company, here are some cons if you don't do your research thoroughly...

- MENIAL, MINDLESS WORK: as a CbDer, you're hired in to do PMO, testing, and note taking. People have this misconception that CbDers are their assistants, and will treat you as such, making you schedule meetings, book conference rooms, upload a document onto Box. There's no analytical or critical thinking required whatsoever, and definitely don't expect to be challenged. 
- LONG DURATION OF PROJECTS: IBM projects run longer than typical consulting firms, usually ranging from 6-9 months. Again, because they are mostly implementation-type work, you'll be doing the same thing (e.g. testing) the whole time. Don't expect that much exposure to different industries or types of projects. Your first project pretty much pigeon-holes you to do the same thing for the rest of your career, unless you really fight HARD to get onto something you want.
- LACK OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT: in the CbD program, you have 3 mandatory trainings. They're a lot of fun, because you get to hang out with people in your start class. However, the stuff you learn is absolutely useless for your job. They hire a third party vendor to conduct these sessions. They teach you things like how to present better, but it's useless because you'll never be given an opportunity to present to anyone.
- CONSTANT REORG: there's been I think 3 (?) reorgs during the 2 years that I've worked here, both GBS-wide and CbD-specific. Despite IBM being an established corporation, the consulting arm is still relatively young (acquired from PwC a few years ago), so it almost feels as if we're going through the growing pains of a young company... just a general lack of clear direction and constantly shifting corporate strategy.
- LAYOFFS: during my time here, I've seen maybe 3 rounds of layoffs, which has affected people that were on my team, as well as people in my start class (yeah, THAT young). If you think you're immune from layoffs because you're a fresh college grad, think again. No one's safe here, and everyone's always on edge.
- OUTDATED INTERNAL TECHNOLOGIES: it's embarrassing how bad IBM internal technologies are being that we boast we're at the forefront of technology. Most tools employees use (expense system, travel booking system, lotus notes) SUCK. They haven't been refreshed since the 1990's and are extremely cumbersome to use.

Title: "Full of promise, fails to deliver."

Pros: Brand permission, a few star inspirational folks not yet worn down by the machine.

Title: "Great place to start your career. Long term is questionable."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
I started out in the IBM summit program as a technical specialist, and have progressed to a more full time sales position.

-High Quality initial enablement and sales training.
-The vast majority of people I've met/worked with are very talented, likeable, and helpful
-Great starting salary for a college kid coming straight out of undergrad.
-There's a lot of free (expensed by IBM) training/travel to cool locations like New york, Las Vegas, Dallas, and Raleigh,
Cons:
-The technical sales training (for upcoming sales engineers) is virtually nonexistent, which leads to a very rough transition from the summit program to a more full time role.
-Many new hires will get stranded without a team or assignments for months on end. You will sit for weeks or months on end with maybe 10 hours of work to per week. So if you''re lazy it's  nice, but it's pretty terrible for career/skill building.
-The future of the company seems very questionable. There's a constant stream of layoffs, resource actions, and cost cutting measures. Most of my more senior colleagues don't seem to like working here at all, and appear to have settled for sticking around 

Ultimately though, the high starting salary, great initial training, and nice resume boost would make the job worth taking for anyone coming out of college. If you're more experienced, I would probably stay away.

Title: "Run the other direction!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: Decent pay, fair amount of flexibility depending on your job role
Cons: I joined this company just a few years ago with high hopes that it would live up to its name and (former) reputation. I couldn't be more disappointed with my experience here as a "millennial" excited to grow a career here. The culture is terrible, the executive management is greedy and out of touch, and the constant layoffs and disregard for the employee (and customer for that matter) result in the lowest morale I have ever seen in a company. Since I started 2 years ago, almost everyone I have met has been laid off without explanation or beat them to it by leaving on their own. Do not believe the propaganda and run the other way to an employer that appreciates you and compensates you accordingly.

Title: "Employee morale is horrendous... would not recommend as a place to work"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: The people I work with are talented, hard-working and knowledgeable people.  Until IBM does a mass firing and replaces them with cheaper, unexperienced, and sometimes unqualified, individuals.
Cons:
IBM just took away the only positive thing they had going for it - work from home.  After pushing people to work from home, they have now decided it's time to pull everyone back into the office.  I am not arguing that working in the same location is a bad thing, but it's the way they implemented it.  They are now forcing people to move, even if they are close to another IBM location, they are being forced to the one IBM specifies.  Many of these locations are also expensive, but there is no salary bump to compensate.

This company is best at figuring out what it can take away from the employee.  They want the employee's loyalty, but there is NO loyalty in return. Forget about raises, they are minimal (~1%) and once in a while someone may get something larger.

Look elsewhere, if this is the only job you get, take it, get some experience and get out after 2 or 3 years.  The morale is horrendous and it is not an enjoyable place to work.  IBM may try and cite improvements in their "Engagement Surveys", but that is only because most people don't even take the survey.  

There may be pockets of the company that are better than others, but sooner or later the corporate culture will bring them down too.  Such a shame, IBM really was a great company to work for years and years ago.

Title: "If offered a job, don't accept! There are MUCH better companies out there"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 5 years

Cons:
1.) 20+ quarters w/o a profit
2.) Layoffs (or RA's, as they are called internally) are the norm. They happened every year I was there. No rhyme or reason for who is selected. They must reduce head count. Expect this every 1Q. Performance terminations occur in 3Q. Every year like clockwork.
3.) Loads of red tape internally. Good luck getting your work done.
4.) Expect new territories every half. Management likes to mix it up and the customers do not take you seriously as they know they will have new reps. in 6 months.
5.) Products are tough sells. Customers see old outdated products (*cough* Lotus Notes *cough*) from an out-of-touch company. With so many RA's, product management unable to deliver promised features on time. Cuts are too deep. But hey! Ginni got her bonus!
6). Check out the Watching IBM Facebook page for others that have been RA or quit because of co-location.

Title: "A great brand, a terrible place to work"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros: There is groundbreaking research and advances being made in cloud, analytics, and artificial intelligence. If you can work on one of those teams for a manager who has come from outside IBM after 2015, you may be lucky to enjoy the work. Read the next section.
Cons:
IBM is fighting to join the 21st century with outdated thinking and tools from 20+ years ago, before collaboration became a necessity in the workplace. 
Examples: 
- AT&T conferencing: no one knows who's joined a meeting bridge and there’s no way to share your screen or files.
- Notes: The former Lotus product (desktop or cloud version, called Verse) doesn’t properly integrate with modern mobile phones (encrypted emails can’t be opened, invites aren’t properly processed, web version doesn’t have feature-parity with desktop, etc.), but that’s not a big deal since 1/3 to 1/2 of the company doesn’t access email from their phone, so they may not realize this.
- IBM just started using Microsoft Office companywide in 2016; they had been using openoffice. Think about that.
- “Charts.” Strangely, PowerPoint is called charts instead of slides. This is strange quirk that reminds you the culture is stuck in the past, presumably from when people carried binders to meetings and wrote on easels.
- The agreement you sign as you leave the company asks you to be sure to return your floppy disks. 

The culture is one of fear, intimidation, and micromanagement, and it starts from the top. When executives publicly humiliate their extended teams in front of their peers, it shuts down collaboration and ideas and kills morale. There is a constant threat made about resource actions (layoffs) which happen at random times and some people literally disappear without announcements or transitions. IBM announced they are reverting to a command and control model by centralizing on a few locations where the model will completely flip from remote teleworkers they have today to forced presence in the office. They are forcing people to relocate or resign. The offices are classic 1960s or 1980s furniture and decor depending on where you visit, though some are trying to remodel. 

Overall, the company has great potential with a solid brand and some good ideas. Unfortunately, the culture is poisoning the company to where it may be unrecoverable.

Title: "Used to be a great place to work"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years

Cons:

Never, never assume you are safe, no matter how good you are and what you are rated.  I have seen large numbers of amazing people laid off (with one month's severance no matter how many years they had with the company)

Title: "Not your parent's IBM.."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Still some great people left at IBM. The ability to work from home - but now is limited only to sellers.
Cons:
-19 quarters of sales decline in a row under Ginni Rommety. 
-First/second even 3rd line managers no longer have any decision making ability. 
-The forecasting process is non stop - with more time spent forecasting and presenting sales forecasts to multiple mgrs/levels than actual selling. 
-Raises are almost non-existent and usually only 1-2%. 
-Benefits have continued to decline with healthcare contributions continuing to decrease and employee costs skyrocketing. 
-There is no longer a pension plan, the 401k match happens once a year, in January. So most silent layoffs happen in 4th qtr. 
-30 day severance is the new policy whether you have 1 year of service or 40. 

Overall company environment has gone from poor to absolutely toxic. Many of those who remain are looking to leave or actively doing so. 
-There is a huge push to cull older employees and replace with millenials with some mgrs openly stating that "that job is slated for a millenial hire".  
-I would NEVER allow my children to join the new IBM.

Title: "IBM, where your spirit will be broken & stepped on"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
Large organization, great networking opportunities
Company Intranet includes contact information on staff as well as detailed profiles and other internal resources to procedures
Cons:
1. Disconnect between large base of millenials and baby boomers in charge- there is no in between
2. IBM uses Lotus Notes, which is slow, inefficient and outdated 
3. HR is unresponsive in email and over the phone, even when illegal and discriminatory practices are happening- HR looks the other way and/or pretends these activities are not happening
4. Hostile management are brought in the 'clear out' department staff and push them to resign
5. You are required to show up to a physical IBM office, but don't expect your own desk or work space
6.  Medical benefits are poor- prepare to pay thousands in deductibles
7. Empty promises of raises, reorgs & resources never come to fruition
8. Managers across departments play a fun game of calling a selected employee with an urgent request from Ginni/CEO on Friday nights to see if the employee will iterate on the urgent Ginni request all day Sat & Sun, meanwhile many other employees (since there are 300K)  are tasked with the same weekend assignment....who knows if it's a test of dedication or what, but I doubt the work product goes to Ginni....and if it does, the weekend sacrificing employee won't ever get credit 
9. Smart capable employees are expected to do the work of 3-4 people without budget and without complaint and then they get fed up and leave, it's a bad cycle 
10.  You don't feel like you're part of something good, the size takes away from any sense of pride or belonging and the work environment further reinforces this.....employees are left feeling disconnected and out of the loop

The pressure is unrelenting, no one in marketing does any actual marketing they simply take numbers and information, drop them into powerpoint decks or incredibly myopic 'funnel charts' and 'spin the numbers'. Good, decent, seasoned professionals that have spend years trying to right the ship are being let go and replaced by inexperienced college grads and yet management wants to know why the numbers are off, why the pipeline isn't healthier. Marketing is told to sell and promote solutions that do not actually exist and if they do, don't work. The company is all about 'cloud solutions' but the cloud solutions suffer from poor architecture and constant outages.

Title: "Only if you can't find work elsewhere"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: If you get one, the pay rises and bonuses are so small for the lower ranks that there is no reason (other than pride and the fear of the endless redundancies) to go above and beyond. This can be a pro however, as once you have reached the point where you no longer care if you get made redundant (even with the legal minimum redundancy payment now being standard for IBM) and have realised that it's not always the bottom of the pile that are targeted for redundancy so working hard won't necessarily save you, then you are free to be mediocre at work and have a great stress free home life. Also, eventually all the goings on become so ludicrous that it's actually quite entertaining once you learn to laugh at it all. So if the above sounds good and you can accept the fact your starting salary will be similar to your  end salary when you leave, you could fit in quite well.
Cons: It can get a bit depressing reading about Ginni's bonus going up and up and up as IBM's revenue goes down and down and down (just like the lower ranks pay rises, bonuses and perks). However, it inspires further mediocrity in the lower ranks so it's not all bad.

Cons: This company sucks to work for. First they tell you you can work from home, then they tell you, after moving away, to be in the office. The company is rudderless as they have a CEO that has missed 20 months of revenue targets as she pulls down millions in salary and bonuses. If you are in India, Serbia, Mexico, Hungary etc. it is probably a decent company to work for, but if you are in the USA, Australia or western Europe the place is just a factory with average benefits.

Title: "Arrived via acquisition, absorbed and cast aside"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: The only pro I can state was when they built Top Golf next door.  Made it easy to escape the soul sucking numbness that is IBM.  The 401k match used to be great until they changed it to only occur in December instead of with each paycheck.  The office is next to the Domain which has some great lunch choices, so you've got that going for you.
Cons:
If you arrive via acquisition, things will be great until Transfer of Business occurs. Once you reach that milestone, anything you enjoyed about your old company will be swept away with meaningless corporate double-speak and pointless meetings.  My team was about 60 people when we were brought on board, and after three years only 5 remain.

The entire point of US based IBM is to fire all senior people, outsource all work overseas, and hire recent graduates for minimal salaries.  The entire time I was at IBM, there was zero positive feedback from upper level management, which is ironic since IBM acquired my company because we were beating them left and right in the market.  The acquisitions only occur to remove competition.  Other teams will absorb your product and fight for the scraps.  Once Transfer of Business and Bluewashing are complete, you are expendable.

Everything IBM does is to encourage US based employees to quit.  Changing the 401k match to only occur once a year was another example of this mentality. Stack ranking employees and firing a set percentage every quarter has occurred at IBM every year for the past decade.  Zero perks like coffee or even water, obsolete technology, terrible internal tools like Lotus Notes, complete lack of concern for the team.  The only thing that matters is the stock price and delivering dividends to the stockholders.  Respect for employees is not even on the list.

The benefits are minimal.  IBM health insurance charges you per child, up to six kids.  If you have a larger family you will be paying massively for poor coverage. 401k match is insulting, the only free perk is water in the water fountains.  Even the benefit of working from home is being removed, which makes sense since IBM frowns on any type of 'perk' or 'benefit' for the rank-and-file employees.

My advice, don't even consider working here.  You will not be appreciated in any way.  If you are acquired, leave once your stock vests and don't bother contributing while there.  Anything you used to love about your company is meaningless once you were acquired by this place.

Title: "A great company that has gone down the tubes"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
Company Reputation
Excellent medical benefits
Moving between divisions used to be easy (right now it is hard because IBM is laying people off (Called Resource Action (RA) in IBM parlance)
Cons:
Pay raises and promotions are slower than others
Work from home, which had been one of the mainstays, is being cancelled
Very tightly defined roles -- you are pre-sales only, and penalized for giving after sales support. This hurts both your and the company's reputation
Tech team is under the thumb of sales, so it can't produce on its own. If you have a bad seller (e.g., can't close, won't hunt), you will be penalized and held accountable for their performance
In my last group, management was always hunting for someone to throw under the bus if a deal didn't close. Twice, I was asked to say who was responsible for the loss of sale. At other companies I have worked, it was viewed as a team effort and we trained tech people to improve.

Title: "IBM only cares about stockholders, not employees, not customers"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
- Most of my HR partners have been amazing. (Unfortunately they just announced only upline managers will have an assigned HR contact.  That doesn't have a big impact on me, but will be difficult for new managers or new IBMers).

- I've been able to find good talent for my teams internally in IBM.  I'd say that about 1/3 to 1/2 of the employees on each team I've been in have been extremely dedicated to their work and their customers. 

- The sales org seems to be addressing some of the complacency in their ranks, and I've had very positive experiences with most of the newer sellers they have hired.  It seems there is more pressure now for sellers to take ownership of their accounts *after* (and not just until) their commission comes in.

- It's pretty easy to move internally if you have a good reputation or good performance ratings.  You may encounter resistance from your management, but they're not allowed to block your movement indefinitely.
Cons:
- No work life balance.  I work at least 10 hours most days plus reply to email all weekend (as is expected by management).  Similarly, you are expected to check/reply to email and take meetings when you take a vacation day. The vacation time expires every year, so it's not like you can even bank the time when you have to work all day on vacation.   I have taken a lunch break less than 30 times total in the past 10 years.  I hear you have to actually book a meeting on your calendar in order to have time to step away to eat, instead of muting yourself on the phone meeting you've taken.

- Benefits have eroded over the years.  Our health insurance options are still decent but have gotten much more expensive, with higher deductibles and lesser coverage every single year.  This is particularly true for family coverage.  Many of us use our spouse's insurance if they work elsewhere.  Our 401k matching used to be great.  They have cut the matching in half and now only match at the end of the year. This means if they lay you off on Dec 30, you get nothing. (Yes, they did lay people off in December).  Quite a few people who are doing "good" but not stellar work have not seen a raise in 5+ years. 

- Constant layoffs. Of course it doesn't hit every business unit or every group every time, but we are always doing "Resource Actions."  As a manager, I have to constantly be prepared to submit names for upcoming RA's.  The RA's are NOT limited to low performers or areas where there has been a work reduction.  I'm supposedly in a growing part of the business, but the job growth is not in the US.  Despite what our CEO tells Trump or the media.

- I like the new performance review system in theory, but in practice assessments were handled poorly in 2016. We were strong armed into decreasing employee's ratings without any explanation of why or what the expectations were for average or above average ratings.  There is a disconnect as my team is viewed as high performing, but I'm not permitted to give them high performing ratings.  

- We are just wrapping up our bonus planning, which occurs once a year.  I was able to give 0.5%-1% bonuses to employees who were high performing.  It was the worst "bucket" I've ever seen, but not by much.  It's rare to get a bonus of more than a few thousand, no matter how good your results were.  Obviously, it's different for middle & upper management and for sales. 

- The scope of our jobs keeps changing and growing, because they lay off people and add those responsibilities to existing staff.  Currently, I'm doing the work that was spread across three people last year. (I was already pretty busy before this change). My story isn't unique.  There is little or no training when you are forced to assume responsibility for tasks that were previously not part of your job. 

- Lots of favoritism. I say this as someone who is seen as a top performer and a favorite! I've worked in four business units at IBM, and in each, upline management has a very obvious bias towards some employees and against others, which does not align with recent performance.   I also can't believe how much gossiping and in-fighting there is.  I get enough childishness from my children!  Who needs that at work?

- The "back to the office" movement is in full swing, as well as forced relocation.  Yes, getting to work from home at all was a perk, not a right, but it was very transparent, especially in management calls, that this was done to encourage attrition.  Not enough people quit because of this policy, they are now doing layoffs. 

- Constant "transformation" churn. Every year, our execs decide they are going to reinvent the wheel when it comes to internal processes.  Every year we waste tens of thousands of man hours pursuing these "transformation" projects that never actually result in any significant changes.  I'd welcome transformation if our executives were genuinely interested in it instead of just holding many, many meetings to talk about needing to transform.  

- "IBM - I've Been Meeting" - in management, you will spend the vast majority of time in meetings that could have been replaced with a quick email; meetings to discuss what to do in the other meeting about the same topic that day; etc.  We're terrible at collaborating.  Interestingly, despite so many meetings, most people I know at IBM have difficulty understanding and communicating what their organization's objectives and priorities are, as the information that trickles down from upper management is pretty limited.

- Mentoring is talked about constantly, and yet maybe 5% of the people I know at IBM have a mentor.   To be fair, most people don't have the time.  Similarly, we used to have a robust talent program where the top 5-10% of employees were groomed for more senior roles.  This was dismantled and the replacement feels very much like "you're on your own."

Title: "Stay no more than 3 years"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros: IBM is great place to start a career.   Especially right out of school.  There is a ton of online learning material available.  You will have the opportunity to meet a lot of smart people and to learn from them.  You will have access to amazing projects and every major client in the world.   These are increidbly valuable resume builders.  BUT do not stay long or you will be lost to the machine.
Cons:
Do not make a career here. If you stay at IBM at some point you will to expensive for their cost structure and you will be let go.   You can be a top contributor one day and be out the door 30 days later due to a re-org.    departmental re-orgs are used as an excuse to reduce cost and hire fresh talent.  

Plan on 2-3 years here, and leave before you reach your 4th anniversary.   Anything longer than 4 years and the innovators in the job market will consider you a corporate tool and you will be hard to hire.

Cons: IBM feels like an organization that tries to compete with start-ups, but with the administrative and middle management overhead of working for a government agency. Changes at a macro scale, affecting where people work, what territory they support and who their manager is, seem to change at least every 6 months, making it difficult to get settled with clients and make good commissions.

Can no longer work from home if in a marketing position.

Title: "Step away from the offer"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: None anymore, now that they have taken away working from home.
Cons:
f you are living in the US you will be fired in less than 3 years.  And for those 3 years you'll wonder if you are on the list every quarter.  You will be fired.  They want only offshore cheap employees.  And yes you will be training your replacement.  Severance pay was 1 month and now I hear it's nothing.
Morale is terrible.
Management is out for themselves, don't expect any support or backing.
Sell deals they cannot deliver.

Title: "Not disgruntled, just exhausted"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: I've stayed with IBM longer than anticipated for the sole reason that I had the flexibility to work from home. Since that is changing (i.e. "co-location"), I can not think of another reason to remain.  I like my work, but not my job. There is a big difference.
Cons: There is an ongoing level of chaos at IBM that is toxic. At times, it can seem exciting and it gets spun that way (new strategy! new products! new org structure!) until you realize that it never ends. Never. Ever. Then it is just exhausting. Additionally, the top-down mandates keep coming, demanding more and more from fewer and fewer. Also exhausting. Meanwhile, benefits and pay are no longer competitive and they continue to diminish except for the precious few who are in the upper echelons. They tend to be the same people issuing the mandates.

Title: "Opportunities abound if you are a talented and driven individual looking to make a difference!"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: There are so many opportunities, but you have to be willing to be BOLD and take them or even create them.  IBM has been transforming (and like any company, the days of not continuously transforming are over) and that leaves so many avenues to explore and grow and an employee.  Our culture is also changing to encourage big bold ideas, enabling small teams to deliver big ideas...it's a great place to be.
Cons: IBM is big and if you are soft spoken or not self-motivated you may not find it as amazing as I do.  I have been here, in Finance, for over 13 years and am never bored, because when I am I move to something new.  One downside for me, but that some people love, is our move to Agile workspace...no assigned desks or space.  This is not company wide yet...but will be overtime.

Title: "Good company with long history, but some concerns for future direction"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Given the size and breadth of the company, there are many opportunities for career growth. Generally well-respected company at least gets you a foot in the door with clients. Constantly re-inventing itself to stay relevant and ahead of the curve. Flexible work options (e.g., work from home) although this is changing and shifting to greater emphasis on physically being in the same office with your team.
Cons: Constantly re-inventing itself means frequent churn, in some area more than others. Quick to cut funding (marketing, projects, etc.) in order to make quarterly targets. Along the same lines, there are many jobs pushed offshore which can cause unease -- and goes against the push to have teams co-located.

Title: "Veteran friendly, encourages community service"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 5 years
Pros:
As a veteran of the US military, I've always appreciated that IBM recognizes the unique value, skills, and experience each individual brings to the company. Our leadership supports hiring veterans and encourages  veterans working for the company to share their thoughts and help others with military career transitions.

Additionally, I appreciate the company focus on corporate citizenship. As an individual IBM, I've found volunteer opportunities in my community and logged time I committed to nonprofit organizations I've served. I received an IBM community grant for one organization for the time I volunteered. Also, I was accepted into the Corporate Service Corps and spent a month as a corporate volunteer, consulting with an organization in Vietnam.
Cons: IBM is a large, global company. If you're considering employment and have worked for a small company or organization, it may take time to understand the many divisions and organizations within IBM.

Title: "Great place to live a career....just keep learning and self-manage it"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Ability to switch to different roles and completely different jobs while inside the same company.  Access to leading thinkers and do-ers across a very VERY broad range of technical and business topics.  Availability of training programs.  Support for volunteer activities in the local community, as well as key programs like Corporate Services Corp where I spend a month with a team of 10 IBMers addressing IT challenges in central Africa.  Respect that comes from association with the IBM brand and history.  Relentless re-invention toward emerging and strategic areas of technology.
Cons: Not as much flexibility for mid/low level managers as their would be in a small organization.  Be aware that skills atrophy will result in minimal compensation increases and eventually needing to locate alternative roles or even company -- but this is reality of working in a tech business.

Title: "Senior Business Development"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Many very good, intelligent competent workers.
Cons: Poor executive management, little respect for the individual, no loyalty. These were hallmarks of IBM.

Title: "Old School at its core.they are trying to look progressive by doing things others did 15 yrs ago."
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: If and only if.. you find the right group within IBM you may get respected and treated well.. Particularly the groups associated with the high visibility Cloud or Watson development teams. Budgets are ridiculously thin elseware and you are a "Number" at best.
Cons:
Everyone I have come into contact with, (rare exceptions) is a narcissistic, self serving person.. despite age, race, religion or sex.. anyone who has been with them more than a few years will adopt this attitude to survive the environment. They will check you in Blue pages to size up whether they should bother with you/ help you/ mentor you or even respond to an email. 
IBM is NOT a learning environment.. They will hire you because of what you know, and maybe a degree or certification.. but don't expect them to encourage or pay for anything more. Ginny will talk about the value of personal development and creativity and how open the Co. is to it.. Virtually everyone below her level must keep her in the dark about the reality. Because they use budget restriction excuses for not developing people, longer term employees were told within hours after her very public announcement kicking off the Th!nk40 that it was not going to happen for them.. Ask questions during your interview about when the last time was that anyone in the department got external training for their role.. Please, for god's sake.. consider the  offer carefully and read the agreement critically! you will be signing away you life in effect. very old school expectations of blind loyalty and commitment are expected. Which is only possible if you are completely ignorant and have zero experience in business.. I have worked for a few and this is not the cutting edge progressive Co. it should and needs to be to succeed.

Title: "Great opportunities"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros: IBM has a multitude of areas where employees can get involved in emerging trends or tried and true technology.  IBM offers the ability to move to different areas without having to change company's to change career paths.   IBM experts are very accessible to help someone get involved with their passion whether it be something which goes across industries such as cloud or cognitive and something which is specific to an industry including finance, healthcare, banking, transportation, etc.    IBM also has great community service related opportunities to allow employees to give back.
Cons: Continual pressure to reduce costs drives work to lower cost countries resulting in reduced workforce in some countries like U.S.   However, if you are willing to re-educate and retrain in emerging technologies IBM continues to expand U.S. workforce.

Title: "Great place to leverage and build your skills and do work that matters for customers"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Constantly reinventing itself in a fast moving industry
You have great latitude for being entrepreneur and lead
Great focus on driving innovative offerings in the market place and help our customers to transform themselves and disrupt in the marketplace
Ability to move up and laterally in broad solution areas
Right business strategy: focus on high value areas, focusing on delivering outcome vs products
Great investment in employee skills and industry knowledge
Ability to work remotely for the most part
Strong values and customer-oriented culture
Cons:
Takes a bit of effort to understand the organization and the broad portfolio
Can take a while to adjust to a remote way of working.  Most internal meetings are over conference calls, which has positives but could take a bit of effort to adjust and get used to
Technology companies work in fast moving environments to specific divisions can change direction relatively quickly.  People who can't easily adjust/adopt change might find it difficult.

Title: "Trying hard to cut people costs"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Strong culture with desire to change the world with technology
Cons:
Eroding confidence with years worth of continual revenue decline leads to desire to cut costs ("Get expenses in line with revenue").  Therefore death spiral - less revenue, cut people to reduce costs which leads to fewer sales and less revenue therefore cut people.....
Getting rid of many experience people to reduce costs leads to a feeling of many looking over their shoulder on who will be next to get laid off

Title: "Unique opportunity to give back to the community"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: Last year I was selected to participate in the Corporate Service Corp, modeled after the Peace Corp, to provide a month of pro bono consulting in a developing country in an area I knew very little about. It was the most amazing experience. IBM did a tremendous job in preparing me, and making sure that I and the other IBMers on this assignment were well taken care of, well prepared for this assignment, while ensuring that we immersed in the local culture to the maximum. My manager, co workers, clients were so supportive of my taking one month off work to go make a difference in another part of the world, solving a key real world problem. I learnt skills that I would never have an opportunity to learn otherwise. Opportunities such as these and my current role, keep me at IBM. The learnings these roles provide, the global reach is unparalleled.
Cons: Not a leading driver for compensation, but follows the market

WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros: Wonderful co-workers, Ability to work from home.Flexibility.   Travel to conferences which enables learning.  A few good managers and mentors.
Cons: Long hours, extra work every year due to repeated resource actions, which has become demoralizing.   An overly political environment where most management is afraid to take a stand on ANY issue.   Poor marketing framework with "New Work of Marketing Model' not working or capturing leads.  IBM website that doesn't work to capture responses. Inability to be nimble.  IBM moves on turtle time. More important to build consensus than do good work.  New CMO has NO tech experience.  Most new hires have no experience in tech or the markets IBM plays in.  Outsourcing to India and Brazil on the rise. American works are laid off every year.

Title: "Why I Like IBM"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: I consider myself to be a "graybeard" having been around IBM for 20+ years. Over the course of my career I've learned, delivered and succeeded multiple times for multiple clients. Most importantly, I got to decide exactly what I wanted to do each step of the way. During 2016, I participated with the IBM Corporate Service Corps, deployed to Dakar, Senegal with 14 other practitioners to work on several "pro bono" projects that will pay dividends to the Senegalese people and to IBM. I must say this project stands alone as being a highlight of my IBM career.
Cons: Like any other organization you must deal with a bureaucracy; however, IBM continues to re-make itself and to remain relevant all practitioner's are challenged to do the same, continuously.

I was fortunate to be part of a team last year and in this assignment I was able to utilize my existing skills and in the process learn so much more while helping a NGO in China increase their effectiveness.
Cons: It takes a bit to navigate where to find help is such a large company.

Title: "Great Coworkers, Uncertain Future"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time
Pros:
Great Coworkers. It's hard to find a mean or uncooperative person at IBM. I've created great friendships with 85% of the people I've met, and usually the bad eggs don't last long. 
Inspiring Stories. Every day the world hears about how Watson is helping fight cancer, improve security, lower people's taxes, etc. etc. 
Female leadership. As a female employee, 3 out of the 4 managers I've had in the last few years have been exceptional, amazing women! Most of my division are women as well, and it's incredibly empowering to work alongside them day in and day out.
Flexibility. I've been able to work remotely my entire time at IBM, which has allowed me to create the perfect work/life balance. 
Starting salary. Starting salary is great, but don't expect promotions every year.
Cons:
Constant change. There is upheaval in management, direction every couple months. 
Misguided goals. The company has set goals, but the means to get to those goals are very questionable, in that the offerings aren't making any money nor show any signs of doing so.
Middle Managers. You'll have to report to a ton of middle managers, and you sometimes wonder why they're there in the first place.....
Getting a job here. It's incredibly hard to get a job at IBM unless you know someone who's fairly high in the chain.

Pros: Heritage brand that certainly opens doors. IBM is made up of high integrity, intelligent professionals and boasts an incredible array of offerings which are being made even more powerful with the addition of Watson cognitive intelligence.
Cons: IBM can't get out of its own way from an internal operations standpoint.  Too many disparate systems, which in and of themselves are hugely inefficient and make it difficult to navigate quickly and effectively to progress simple tasks, much less the sale.  IBM forges ahead with what they think are great ideas - both from an internal operations standpoint and product development - but they don't involve and ask the right stakeholders before moving forward, often missing the mark because they made the wrong assumptions.

Title: "Potential to be a great company, lacking the right leaders"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
1. Great colleagues, some of the smartest people I have ever worked with and had the privilege to work with. 
2. Access to resources, such as tools to enable you to make data-driven decisions.
3. Work life balance (although this is changing).
4. Benefits are really great.
5. No two days are the same.
Cons:
1. Remote work is no longer allowed. 
2. Salary is not at-market. 
3. Mobility is incredibly tough for such a large company. If you do not push to have that relationship with your manager, it will not happen organically. 
4. Management in general is rough. Those who are in Director/VP roles are too disconnected from the roles of their direct reports that they are not able to give advice on how to fix problems. They have zero knowledge of our tool capabilities causing expectations to not be met. 
5. Lack of accountability makes some employees lazy.
6. Timelines for everything are very, very long. There is a ton of red tape around every corner. Management encourages innovation but there are so many barriers to actually accomplishing innovation (tools). 
7. There is no clear view into what is working and what isn't. While we have access to a ton of tools, no two tools tell the same story. 
8. Constant reinvention/re-branding makes for a poor user-experience and also makes it very costly to get campaigns running and comply with an "always-on" strategy. 
9. Lack of appreciation of employees. If you need positive reinforcement to stay motivated, you will not get that at IBM. Even the yearly review process is incredibly flawed. Also a lack of corporate responsibility to employees with new co-location policies. 
10. Special projects are exciting to get on but mainly come with a lot of unrealistic expectations, faster than fast timelines, and  not enough resources or budget to execute.

Title: "Great team, terrible environment"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: I work on a team of really great people and I enjoy working with them. I get compensated very well, and my job is very secure. IBM also provides good benefits.
Cons: IBM is an old school, misogynistic boys club. The representation of women in technical and technical management is very small from what I've seen. I've also personally experienced sexism in the office from senior management. Most long timers are complacent to be mediocre which is very frustrating. IBM also does not invest in training their employees. They won't pay for in house training, rules for tuition reimbursement programs are incredibly strict and near impossible to use, and when my manager asked to send our team to a developers conference that would have been great for our professional development it was just a flat out no. They are also loathe to hire new people preferring to move people around from other teams to fill gaps or hire recent grads since they can pay them less. There is also a ton of beaurocratic BS that gets in the way of progress and efficiency even though management claims it's supposed to make things better.

Focused on cost cutting by eliminating senior high cost employees with low cost millennials. CEO takes huge bonuses while employees are being cut each month.

Title: "Good not great"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
-The designers, PM's, Managers and Front-End Devs are very smart and very welcoming
-Beautiful studio
-Great healthcare (I have the best plan with only $350 deductible)
-Great work/life balance (varies from team to team)
Cons:
-High turn over

-The pay. I found out with 10+ years of experience I get paid 20K more than a college grad. I got a bonus last year ($1500) and none this year. Pay raise of 5% which wasn't bad as a general statistic but terrible when you look at my base pay. IBM is investing in college grads by trying to pay them more... news flash they leave anyway and then so do your Senior/Lead designers because you pay them an embarrassing amount. You blew your wad on the new shiny toy out of college that bailed 1 year later. Congrats.

-The back end devs are determined to kill the world of good design. We cannot make a wonderful experience and have it be implemented in a reasonable amount of time. By "reasonable" I mean small CSS changes take 2 months and CRITICAL features to help us even half way compete with competitors like AWS take a year. It's filled with old dinosaurs developers who think that they can design and we are just worthless people that wear skinny pants.

-Offering Management (OM) is mostly useless. I have met one or two that were amazing at their job, the rest cannot understand what their job actually is. They are not art directors and they are supposed to deliver to us the main goal of what the design is supposed to be based on actual market research. Most of them have zero clue what actual market research is or what is valid.

Title: "Make Sure You Understand What You Are Getting Into"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
1. Teamwork and fellow employees ... no matter what, almost everyone is completely dedicated and wants to win. Rare to find someone who won't help or team.
2. Decent compensation, good benefits.
3. Strong company reputation, although that has eroded somewhat in recent years.
4. IBM Research is top notch.
Cons:
1. Cutthroat culture and you never know where you stand ... even with good reviews. There is a constant feeling that you have an axe hanging over your neck 24 X 7. You can work your living butt off and be proven ... and be highly regarded by your peers and your customers ... and be fired with no notice no matter how many years of seniority you have and no matter how respected you are. 

In the end, this is a poor reflection on the value the executive team places on their employees. Anyone is expendable and the people who work here know it and live it every day.

Ask yourself if this is really the climate you want to work in. Because even if you are younger and they make you feel wanted/welcome right now, you will eventually reach a point where you are expendable at their whim.
2. Management highly political and is an "old boys" network with no shame and lots of favoritism.
3. The company executive team makes very poor product investment and marketing decisions. They are almost always behind the market with investments and acquisitions, and then they "blame" the product development and sales teams for the poor results by firing and laying them off when the executive team is responsible themselves. Middle management is for the most part, protected no matter what happens.  
4. Executive team hasn't learned that increased profitability is achieved by growing the top line - increasing top line revenue growth. You can only achieve so much improved profitability by cutting costs (people). 
5. Atmosphere of constant layoffs and firings. Not once every few years as a result of a necessary reorg or restructuring, but at least once per year if not more often. And IBM does this in such a fashion that they keep the total number of employees let go under the threshold which the Dept of Labor requires to make the layoffs public.
6. Management and HR can be ruthless and the environment right now is toxic.

Title: "A Work in Progress, Do Your Research"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Amazing programs like these:
Corporate Service Corps - which is like a Corporate sponsored version of the peach corps where if selected you will do a pro bono project in a developing country
Good Maternity and Paternity Leave of up to 6 weeks with pay
The legacy 401k retirement plan match of 6% (if you are not in the GTS business unit)
Good work location, hour flexibility as long as you get the job done well (at least it has been until now)
Good health benefits packages (although quite expensive for family coverages)
A lot of amazing individuals working at IBM, the people are what matter most
Dedication to clients success is a way of life at IBM, it's real and it is how we work!
Cons:
Management, 
I don't know how else to say this but there are a lot of BAD manager at IBM. A lot of secrecy and elitism that is inexcusable. The biggest issue with this, all the many many rounds of "resource actions" that are layoffs, back to office programs being the latest gimmick, never seem to weed out the top heavy command and control culture. CEO Ginni Rometty is different and is trying her best to steer the ship in a new direction. I hope she can succeed, 2016 was the first glimmer of hope in like 10 years. HR practices like not giving ANY of the 401k matching fund until last pay check of December for the entire year, moving one job family into a different 401k program announced at the end of 2015 was also a very strange one done by HR. The management and HR specifically often do not exhibit the company values in my experience over the last 16 years.

Title: "How the mighty have fallen"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: IBM does attract the best and brightest, I have encountered many brilliant people in my time at IBM. Until recently there was flexibility to work remotely. Medical and vacation benefits are better than average. Technology provided to employees is adequate.
Cons:
20 years ago, IBM was a wonderful place to work. Now, I cannot imagine thers is a large US company that is worse to their employees. IBM senior management views employees as depreciating assets, not as human beings. The LAST concern in the company is how moves and strategies will affect employees financially and morale-wise. 

The only area where senior management shows real innovation is in coming up with ways save money by taking things away from employees.  Recent Examples: replacement of lump sum pensions with 'enhanced' 401k contributions, 401k match moved to end-of-year, reduction of severance from a max of 6 months to only 1 month, the essential elimination of raises, elimination of the Thanks program.

Mass firings (Resource Actions in IBM speak) are now a quarterly occurrence.  Employee morale and enthusiasm are incredibly low, most of us wondering when, not if, we will be fired. Work from home is being eliminated & many in the company are being given the choice of moving to an entirely new geographic location or losing their jobs. 

Senior management, starting with Ginni, is inept and rudderless. 19 consecutive quarters of negative growth with no signs of a turnaround in sight. They have completely  abandoned IBM's core values. "Trust and Personal Responsibility in all relationships" is a punchline in the current environment.

Title: "IBM - A mixed bag"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros:
- An enormous brain trust.  So many incredibly intelligent people work there.  It is very easy to be exposed to new ideas.

- A huge portfolio of products, so whatever your interests in technology, there is a good chance you'll be able to work with it.

- A solid benefits package.

- Historically a fairly stable company.  IBM is a place where one can build a long-lasting career.
Cons:
- It is a very large company, so often times it is very easy to feel like just another cog in the machine.

- Many layers of management.  It often feels that the top levels are disconnected from the field work.

- As a large company, IBM can be slow to respond and pivot with shifting technology trends.  This leads to much frustration in the field when dealing with nimble start-ups.

- Getting any sort of raise can be very difficult.

Title: "Bloated company that doesn't know how software works there days"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM  for more than a year
Pros:
- Solid pay
- Awesome odd benefits like cheap rental cars, awesome for traveling
- Work from home allowed (though I hear they are ending this soon)
- There are smart people here who are great to work with
Cons:
Working at IBM was the most confusing and horrifying experience of my professional life.  I joined after the start up I was working for was acquired by them.  At first I thought this would be an amazing opportunity and a place I could build my career at.  I honestly went into this thanking the universe for such an amazing turn of luck.  As time went on this feeling was replaced with more a sense of "it could be worse" to "At least I have golden hand cuffs" to "This place is insane and makes me hate my work life, IBM is making me lazy and stupid"

Some of the worst parts of the job center around how the company organizes itself and the general bloat in employees and management.  There are countless people working at the company that have a vested interest in nothing changing as their skills have stagnated over the last 10-20 years.  This place and their job are literally all they know.  A few examples of this:

- for a company that prides itself on technology it is embarrassing they still widely use Notes as the primary email client.  Some job duties have no other option but to use Notes as the tool even as email has shifted to a web client. The software is unstable, slow, and non-intuitive

- In my department we used a database that was initially written in 1968.  That's not a joke.  When the idea of men walking on the moon was science fiction IBM created the database that is widely used for ticketing in critical needs roles at IBM

- the interface for said DB is again a plugin for a notes client

- Efforts to create a new interface that was web based and levels easier to use were actively thwarted by management that didn't want to change the way things were.

- efforts to change the way we communicate to even just allow us to talk with our colleagues more easily were actively prevented.

The direct manager I had was also verbally abusive and took to screaming at me during a meeting while a colleague was in the room.  The event was so bad I had to involve several upper level managers to get him to stop screaming at me and mentioning my personal life outside the office in a negative context. He didn't understand the product we were on as he took over parts of the team after acquisition.  He would tell us completely wrong information and ban us from performing actions he felt were bad in his gut.  A key example of this was telling us not to suggest to customer to upgrade versions of their software because he felt it "Caused more problems than it solved".  This led to a lengthy talk about how the software we used was actually built using technology that is designed to be upgraded easily and often. I even confirmed this with the engineering lead and lead release engineer who had horrified looks on their face when I told them this.  

That same call also involved a 30 minute debate about whether agile or waterfall was the best way to build software today.  My manager wanted to go back to the way things were and just release software once a year when all the bugs were worked out.  I kept trying to calmly explain no one does that today. He countered with how frustrating it was to have a new release every 2 months.  I tried to tell him many companies have new releases several times a day.  IN any event it was a pointless conversation as I had no power to change the release cycle and neither did he.  The software was built and released as it was but he refused to support it that way. 

For an easy example during start up days the time to solve a Sev 1 support issue would be measures in hours to days at the most.  At IBM this was more like weeks to months.  By the time a fix ever came around the customer had usually forgotten about it or moved on to other projects or products.  

IBM is not innovative enough anymore to create new things itself in the software realm.  Instead they are acquiring companies to jusy buy the tech as they transition to a software model of business.  The problem is they are trying to force software start ups into their very old business model when they should be changing themselves to the new way of doing business.

Title: "Incredible vision and history, stogey work environment"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros: Some of the smartest minds I have ever come in contact with, working on some technology that has, is and will continue to change the world in ways many of us don't understand.  IBM is quietly behind the scenes of so many of mankinds' biggest breakthroughs and businesses that power our economy.  To have a hand in developing and delivering this thinking and these technologies to market is an incredibly exciting opportunity.
Cons: The organization is at times, too smart for its own good.  They prefer slow and perfect over agile and testing and learning.  It is a culture that tends to avoid risk taking, with a rule and process to follow for EVERYTHING - sometimes, multiple conflicting rules for the same process.  IBM is interesting also in the sense that what makes it such a successful and valuable company (the tech intelligence/pure brilliance of its people), is what hurts it when it comes to bringing its cutting edge "stuff" to market.  IBM has a problem translating smart tech jargon into language that clients can understand in terms that address their needs.  We lead with tech, while others like Accenture, lead with problem solving and understanding the client first.

Title: "Senior Software Advisory Engineer"

Pros: Not any to speak of now
Cons: Lay offs, excuse me, workforce rebalancing.  Evey month brings another Resource Action leaving the experienced techs to pick up the slack cause the metrics never change regardless and its wash, later, rinse repeat all the time.  Couldn't pay me enough to work for them ever again

Title: "Tech Sales"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
Love the fact that there are no sick days per say. If you do you job right and you take a day off here and there no one will question you. Taking a day off for kids Dr app or to do some personal stuff really does not matter. Like I said as long as you do your job. 

I actually am not dissatisfied with the Sales organization. Lots of training tools, education and help offered. You just have to ask for it and also know whom to ask. Great resources. 
Sales culture is great. Not a cut throat environment what so ever. 

If you are successful you are taken care of within the sales organization. If you achieve a 100% the 1st Half and 2nd Half (not combination), you are sent to Bahamas or Mexico on a trip (Just you. No Spouse). Its like a huge IBM party. 
If you achieve more than 300%, you get best of IBM to Hawaii along with spouse. 

Great work life balance.
Cons:
The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing or rather does not care.

A little hard to get promoted within the company or even to move around. I was denied to move by my then current manager 3 times even though the new manager was willing to wait. 

They really don't care about your personal growth. Very hard to get promoted. Its not impossible but a lot of red tape and so the management don't want to go thru the hassle. There are a few manager that will do anything for you. 

Once you come into IBM at a certain pay scale, you are pretty much stuck there. Unless you leave and come back. Very hard to stay current with the market rate if you stay here too long. 

With the lay-offs everyone is a little weary.

Title: "IBM"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: I have 25 years at IBM and have loved the journey. The culture is based on a core set of IBM values, but each area has it's own personality. I have had the opportunity to challenge myself to grow my career and responsibilities with each new assignment. I had the opportunity to work from home for the last 15 years  - and that gave me the chance to have a bit of work/life balance while contributing at a very high level.
Cons: Constant 'rebalancing' these days which is an ibm term for 'lay off'. It used to be an annual thing but it has turned to monthly. Morale is down in the areas where this is happening more frequently, as expected. And it very difficult to see talented folks let go.

Title: "It's a different time to be and IBMer"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: It's a diverse company with tons of opportunities and provides very neat experiences.
Cons: The business unit I was in is not a large money maker and has a largely negative air amongst most of the employees. The team I was on was running short on people and although I was a NCG I was expected to perform like a senior developer with 10 years experience, although I clearly had no experience in what they were doing or the tools they were using. I even made it clear to the interviewers I had zero experience with C. It's fine they said. We'll teach you, they said. I got no help from my direct teammates when I asked for guidance and actually got reprimanded for asking questions. Very sink or swim environment and a negative experience all around. It's not like this everywhere in IBM, just be sure to ask more about the environment upfront.

Title: "Consulting Division was a daily struggle against the forces of complacency and chaos..."
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for less than a year
Pros:
The check cashed and I consider that an upside.
They don't call you much after hours which was a big upside having been on call for years.
Everyone worked from home and that was made this place initially so attractive.
When you don't have anything else to do at least you can read manuals or other tech documents and they have some really good ones.
Cons:
No IBMer manager or employee would rock the boat to help the customer at all in my opinion.
They would do whatever it took to ensure that their pay/benefits would continue another day.
They seemed to have some processes so canned that they were painful and others totally without process at all. 
Teams and management seemed to struggle with the most trivial issues.
Each group seemed to fight one another to the detriment of the customer at least in the group for which I was a consultant.

Title: "A Review of the IBM Enterprise"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros: IBM is the most innovative company on the planet.  You are surrounded by brilliant people and resources.  Anything can be accomplished due to what seems like unlimited capabilities and potential. For the best opportunity, you must work in a Strategic Growth Unit, (Watson, Analytics, SW, Cloud, Security)
Cons: Unfortunately, IBM is going through another (and continuous) transformation.  They are moving from a $100 Billion IT Product and Services Company to a much smaller higher value company focusing on Enterprise Innovation.  There is much people damage left in the wake.  They operate with a "king has no clothes" and bully mentality.  Lot's of "yes" men in the management change and very few with the guts to "do what is right" for its people and clients.  From this perspective, IBM is broken.

Title: "IBM - Not what it used to be"

Title: "Used to be a great company, not anymore"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: Great working conditions. If you have a technical job that can be done remotely all you need is a computer, internet connection and a phone. I was able to do my job completely from home for the last year I was there. Prior to that we were only required to be in the physical office 2-3 days a week.
Cons: Management seemed to always be nervous about any changes from the top and it trickles down to the staff. When I was there, IBM seemed to cut staff every other quarter, especially if they have acquired the IT department of another company or state government. The point is, IBM does not care nor do they value the people  quality people that work there. If your department is downsized, it does not matter how long you have been with the company and they make it difficult to transfer to other departments or accounts.

Title: "Relatively poor choice for young professionals - Poughkeepsie"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than a year
Pros:
- The elder people you work with have a tremendous amount of knowledge and experience you can learn from
- Work hours are flexible as long as you do what is expected of you
Cons:
- Poughkeepsie, NY is one of the least attractive places to work. The town offers nothing for young people. The consensus among new hires is to work for 2-3 years and then go work somewhere else, away from Poughkeepsie.
- Salary is sub-par, bonus' are poor, and raises are not definite. Sadly, there is no monetary incentive to stay; pay is much better elsewhere.
- Working from home has been banned. You must come into the office now, or you'll get the boot.
- Generally, cost-saving initiatives are at the expense of the employee reflected in their 401K's, benefits, compensation, and flexibility.

Way behind on market changes with no clear direction on course correction.  Many good people are resigning or have been terminated.

Title: "Toxic Environment"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros: Opportunity to work on a wide range of products and services.
Cons: IBM has, alas, gone from being one of the world's premier employers to being a toxic cesspool, run by managers whose only objective is to cut costs at all costs. They pride themselves on paying 90% of the local market, yet call themselves competitive (by definition, that's 10% below market). They unilaterally cut benefits, 401K contributions, salaries and pensions. Ultimately, their goal is to cut you and send your job to a low cost country, all while enriching themselves. If you're considering a career with IBM, you're a fool.

Title: "Development Consultant"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros: IBM Provides flexible timings, Specially work from home culture distinguishes IBM from other companies.I think it is strong reason, that attracts Professionals. IBM Provides very good training's, that keeps you up to date. Its a sea you can grow, and you can find your Mentor easily. You have access of International teams, I really enjoyed working with different colleagues from different countries and cultures. Its amazing.
Cons:
Employees evaluation system is not good. Your People Manager could be some one who don't knows about your performance. Your project manager is the best person who knows about your performance. In current system, even after good feed back from your project manager, Your People manager has authority to give you low grades. 
There is no auto review process. Employee have to follow People Manager. 
If you can't follow People Manager, No matter for how long you are in IBM, No one will ask you for your salary review.

WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 3 years
Pros:
- Depending on team, can be low stress with good work life balance. Flex time and work from home are nice benefits.
- Generally pretty good culture. People try to help each other and there isn't much backstabbing.
Cons:
- Depending on area, things are in flux and management will constantly being changing priorities.
- Quality of engineers is questionable in general. No technical questions are asked during interviews, so you can get hired without really knowing how to code.
- Flat or pathetic increases in salary.
- Not much room for advancement since everyone has 20 and 30 years of seniority.

Title: "Life at IBM"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM
Pros: IBM (and Watson, specifically) is a major player in the new AI economy that has established itself in the tech industry. A position at IBM means your work may eventually have some very impactful effects on individuals and larger entities who are customers. IBM takes care of its employees, as well, with comfortable salaries, adequate vacation allotments, and a very generous 401(k) matching program.
Cons: The company is just too big to move quickly. Politics and geographical separation make collaboration extremely difficult, and sometimes brings into question the scientific merit of what products get shipped. Specific cities are also not adequately classified for things like salary and cost of living considerations.

Title: "Be cautious"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time
Pros:
- Large company trying to become successful again
- Salaries are competitive
- Might be a good place for new graduates
Cons:
My opinion based on conversations with a lot of friends at IBM:
- Cannot be counted on for long term stability with multiple layoffs per year.
- Layoffs appeared to be mainly talented lifers and hiring appears to be young inexperienced resources. Only time will tell how this change will work.
- A few weeks before the layoffs, IBM changed the severance policy from 2 weeks pay for every year of service to 4 weeks severance no matter how long you were there. 35 years and you still get 4 weeks of pay. To me, that should be of great concern for those interested in IBM.
- Unless the new IBM changes go very well, the stock is artificially inflated due to recent layoffs of 10's of thousands (most likely from the US) and this might be a concern as well.

Title: "Average but improving"
WorkTime: I have been working at IBM full-time for more than 8 years
Pros:
IBM is still a global powerhouse with a lot of opportunities if you can figure out how to navigate the bureaucracy.  I’m on the consulting side called Global Business Solutions, rather than the more famous innovation side called Global Technical Solutions.  As a consulting firm, they are about average.  You tend to work on small teams and get to know people in your cadre.  Those people are usually pretty good.  They have also figured out how to recruit from colleges and hire a lot of very bright college grads and still train them.  Most of the time, you are working with good people.  There is also lots of on-line training available.  On your own time, you can learn just about anything you want related to technology.  They have amazing resources available to all employees, if you can find them.
Senior management seems to be embracing actual change toward more modern business practices.  Performance ratings are a little less arbitrary than they used to be.  They are trying really hard to use agile methods in everything they do.  They seem to have discovered--and are taking seriously--customer satisfaction.
Cons: It is very difficult to find resources.  The benefits are continually reducing.  For example, they no long match 401(k) contributions with each paycheck.  They wait to see if you're still around at the end of the year and make a lump sum payment so they, not you, get the benefits of dollar-cost averaging.  People management is an extra duty assigned to someone who is being rewarded for doing something else.  Getting a helpful manager is luck-of the-draw (and the odds are no in your favor).  Finding your next assignment or developing your skills is entirely up to you.

Title: "Ups and Downs at Big Blue"
WorkTime: I worked at IBM full-time for more than 10 years
Pros:
Lots of opportunity with the GLOBAL presence of IBM.
Able to gain invaluable experience within whatever field of IT you are interested in.
Great internal online education/training program.
Depending on what area/dept./division you work in, you may have a chance to work on cutting edge/state of art technology.
Reputation still seems to be very positive and valuable within the industry.
Cons:
IBM has been "down-sizing" for many years now.
IBM is focused on moving the majority of labor force overseas..... 80% by end of 2017.
IBM is known for changing support strategies that allow them to "retire" older employees while hiring younger talent and moving higher/older skill set overseas.
So big that you almost become a "number" - no personal benefits with many support folks working from home.
Once great benefits are now barely keeping up with the industry.
Current leadership is more concerned with bottom line and stock-price than employees and customers.
Raises and bonuses have declined over the years and have averaged 1-2% over the past 5 yrs.
Work/Life balance is hard to come by - they do not "practice what they preach."  (especially for people that work from home.)  Mainly due to under-staffing.
